questions.text:
A female patient comes to the ER with palpitations and syncopal attacks following exercise. She has had similar episodes in the past. An ECG was performed as follows. What is the most probable diagnosis?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Arrhythmogenic Right Ventricular Dysplasia

 

Explanation:

  • The patient's symptoms of palpitations, syncope following exercise, and a suggestive ECG pattern are characteristic of Arrhythmogenic Right Ventricular Dysplasia (ARVD), a condition that often leads to arrhythmias and sudden cardiac death, particularly in young, athletic individuals.
  • Arrhythmogenic Right Ventricular Dysplasia (ARVD) is an inherited cardiac disorder characterized by the progressive replacement of the right ventricular myocardium with fibrofatty tissue, leading to arrhythmias, particularly ventricular tachycardia and sudden cardiac death.
  • It primarily affects the right ventricle but can involve the left ventricle as well.

 

Etiology

  • Mutations in genes encoding desmosomal proteins (e.g., PKP2, DSP, DSG2, JUP).

 

Clinical Features

  • Palpitations
  • Syncope
  • Exercise-induced arrhythmias
  • Sudden cardiac death, Particularly in young, athletic individuals.

 

Diagnostic Findings

Electrocardiogram (ECG):

  • Ventricular arrhythmias, especially ventricular tachycardia.
  • Epsilon waves on ECG (specific to ARVD).

 

Echocardiography: May show right ventricular dilation and dysfunction.

Cardiac MRI: Shows fibrofatty infiltration of the right ventricle.

Family history: Key in diagnosing genetic basis.

 

Diagnostic Criteria

Based on the Task Force Criteria, which include:

 

  • ECG abnormalities, arrhythmias, imaging findings, and histological evidence.
  • Pathological criteria: Fibrofatty infiltration of the right ventricle.

 

Management

  • Antiarrhythmic drugs
  • Implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD): For preventing sudden cardiac death in high-risk patients.
  • Heart transplantation: In severe cases with progressive heart failure.

 

Uhl's disease (Option A): Also affects the right ventricle but lacks the hallmark epsilon waves and T-wave inversions.

 

Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (Option C): More commonly presents with asymmetric septal hypertrophy and deep Q waves, not epsilon waves.

 

Brugada’s Syndrome (Option D): Characterized by ST-segment elevation in V1–V3, not epsilon waves.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with a Graham-Steel murmur?
questions.solution:
The Graham-Steel murmur indicates pulmonary regurgitation secondary to pulmonary hypertension. This early diastolic decrescendo murmur is heard best at the left upper sternal border (pulmonic area) and is caused by the backward flow of blood from the pulmonary artery into the right ventricle during diastole.

It is specifically associated with pulmonary hypertension, which causes dilation of the pulmonary artery and subsequent incompetence of the pulmonary valve.

 

Cardiac Murmurs and Their Characteristics

 

Common Pathological Murmurs

Condition

Murmur Characteristics

Mitral Stenosis

Low-pitched diastolic murmur with an opening snap, best heard at the apex

Aortic Stenosis

Crescendo-decrescendo systolic ejection murmur, radiates to carotids, best heard at the right upper sternal border

Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA)

Continuous, machine-like murmur, best heard at the left infraclavicular area

Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HOCM) (Option B)

Harsh systolic murmur with a crescendo-decrescendo pattern, best heard at the left sternal border, increases with Valsalva maneuver

Mitral Regurgitation (MR)

Holosystolic murmur, best heard at the apex, radiates to the axilla

Aortic Regurgitation (AR)

Early diastolic decrescendo murmur, best heard at the left sternal border

Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD) (Option A)

Harsh holosystolic murmur, best heard at the left lower sternal border (LLSB)

Atrial Septal Defect (ASD)

Systolic ejection murmur, best heard at the left upper sternal border (LUSB), with fixed, widely split S2

Tricuspid Regurgitation (TR)

Holosystolic murmur, best heard at the left lower sternal border, increases with inspiration (Carvallo’s sign)

 

Special Murmurs & Their Associations

Murmur

Cause & Characteristics

Graham-Steel Murmur (Pulmonary Regurgitation due to Pulmonary Hypertension)

Early diastolic decrescendo murmur, best heard at the left upper sternal border, caused by pulmonary valve incompetence due to pulmonary hypertension

Austin Flint Murmur

(Severe Aortic Regurgitation)

(Option D)

Low-pitched, rumbling diastolic murmur, best heard at the apex, due to turbulent flow in the left ventricle compressing the mitral valve

Mammary Murmur (Physiologic in Pregnancy)

Continuous hissing murmur, heard over the left second and third intercostal spaces, caused by increased blood flow through internal mammary vessels

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with chronic stable angina presents with worsening chest pain during routine activities. His current medications include aspirin, clopidogrel, metoprolol, and atorvastatin, but his symptoms persist. ECG shows ST-segment depression in V5-V6, and coronary angiography reveals 80% stenosis of the left anterior descending (LAD) artery. What is the most appropriate intervention?

choices.text: Percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with drug-eluting stent (DES)
Refer for coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG)

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with drug-eluting stent (DES)

 

Explanation:

  • The patient has significant stenosis (80% in the LAD) and persistent anginal symptoms despite optimal medical therapy.
  • PCI with a drug-eluting stent (DES) is the most appropriate intervention in this scenario, as it restores blood flow and relieves symptoms.
  • DES is preferred due to its lower risk of restenosis compared to bare-metal stents.

 

Medical management

Medication Class

Function/Mechanism

Indications

Side Effects/

Contraindication

Nitrates

Sublingual nitroglycerin (0.4 or 0.6 mg)

Long-acting forms (oral, transdermal)
  • Systemic venodilation
  • Reduces LV end-diastolic volume and pressure
  • Releases nitric oxide (NO) to relax vascular smooth muscle
  • Angina relief
  • Preemptive use before activities
  • Improves exercise tolerance
  • Tolerance development
  • Headaches, dizziness

Beta-Blocker (Option A)
  • Reduces heart rate, arterial pressure, and myocardial contractility
  • Improves survival post-MI
  • Angina relief
  • Reduces mortality and reinfarction rates
  • Asthma
  • AV conduction disturbances
  • Severe bradycardia

Calcium Channel Blockers
  • Coronary vasodilators
  • Reduces myocardial oxygen demand and arterial pressure
  • Dihydropyridines (e.g., amlodipine) and non-dihydropyridines (e.g., verapamil)
  • Angina treatment when beta blockers are ineffective
  • Variant angina
  • Bradyarrhythmias
  • May aggravate LV failure

Antiplatelet Drugs
  • Aspirin: inhibits platelet activation
  • Clopidogrel 75mg: blocks platelet aggregation
  • Reduces coronary events in high-risk populations
  • Stent placement
  • Risk of bleeding
  • Gastrointestinal issues, allergies

 

Other Therapies:

  • Ranolazine: Inhibits late sodium current, minimizing Na and Ca overload in ischemic myocytes. (Option B)
  • SGLT2 Inhibitors: Provide cardiovascular and renal protection, promoting weight loss and reducing plasma volume; beneficial in IHD patients.
  • Nicorandil: Opens ATP-sensitive potassium channels.
  • Ivabradine: Reduces heart rate in patients with IHD and LV dysfunction.

 

Percutaneous Coronary Intervention (PCI) (Option C)

PCI involves balloon dilatation and stenting for symptomatic IHD with suitable stenoses in epicardial coronary arteries.

  • Indications:
    • Symptom-limiting angina despite optimal medical therapy.
    • Evidence of ischemia during stress tests.
  • Post-PCI Management:
    • Aspirin is administered indefinitely, and P2Y12 antagonists for 1-3 months.
    • Current-generation drug-eluting stents reduce restenosis but require prolonged dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT).

Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting (CABG) (Option D)

Involves bypassing obstructive lesions using internal mammary arteries, radial arteries, or saphenous veins.

  • Indications:
    • Safe with low mortality in patients without serious comorbidities and normal LV function.
    • Effective for patients with left main coronary artery stenosis, multivessel disease, or impaired LV function.
  • Outcomes:
    • Angina relief in ~90% of patients after complete revascularization.
    • Long-term survival benefits in specific populations, particularly those with diabetes or impaired LV function.

questions.text: A 72 y/o woman presents with severe chest pain and shortness of breath after a stressful argument. She is post-menopausal with no history of heart disease. O/E, she is slightly tachycardic with normal blood pressure. An echocardiogram shows left ventricular ballooning during systole, and cardiac enzymes are minimally elevated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy

 

Explanation:

  • Takotsubo cardiomyopathy, also known as broken heart syndrome, is characterized by transient left ventricular dysfunction often triggered by emotional or physical stress.
  • The patient’s recent stressful event, post-menopausal status, ballooning of the left ventricle, and minimal elevation of cardiac enzymes align perfectly with this diagnosis.

 

Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (Gebrochenes-Herz syndrome)

About
  • Takotsubo cardiomyopathy, also known as broken-heart syndrome or stress-induced cardiomyopathy, is a non-ischemic condition primarily affecting post-menopausal women.
  • It features temporary left ventricular dysfunction that resembles a heart attack but with minimal cardiac enzyme release and no significant obstructive coronary artery disease.
  • The name "Takotsubo" is derived from Japanese, meaning octopus trap, reflecting the ballooning shape of the left ventricle during contraction.

Pathophysiology
  • Catecholamine Hypothesis: Elevated catecholamines (norepinephrine, epinephrine, dopamine) indicate stress-induced sympathetic overdrive, leading to microvascular spasms and myocardial injury.
  • Microvascular Dysfunction: Impaired function is suggested by abnormalities in coronary flow reserve and microvascular resistance.
  • Inflammation: Imaging may show myocardial oedema, necrosis, and fibrosis, with conditions like myocarditis and autoimmune diseases potentially triggering TC.
  • Estrogen Deficiency: Exaggerated vasoconstriction and increased sympathetic activity in post-menopausal women contribute to TC.

Clinical features
  • Takotsubo cardiomyopathy often mimics acute coronary syndrome.(MI)
  • Common Triggers:
    • Emotional Stress: Events like the unexpected death of a loved one, domestic abuse, or financial loss.
    • Physical Stress: Serious medical diagnoses or natural disasters.
  • Symptoms: Chest pain, dyspnea, and syncope. Some patients may have signs of heart failure, such as tachyarrhythmias or bradyarrhythmias.
  • A late-peaking systolic murmur may be present due to LVOTO.
  • About 10% of patients may develop cardiogenic shock.

 

Hypertensive Heart Disease (Option A):

  • Caused by chronic high blood pressure, leading to left ventricular hypertrophy.
  • This patient's history does not indicate long-standing hypertension.

 

Coronary Artery Disease (Option C):

  • Involves plaque buildup in coronary arteries, causing reduced blood flow.
  • The absence of obstructive disease on angiography and minimal enzyme release suggests this is unlikely.

 

Pulmonary Embolism (Option D):

  • Occurs when a blood clot blocks a pulmonary artery, leading to sudden shortness of breath and chest pain. History of long term immobilization/ DVT is present.
  • The patient's findings indicate a cardiac issue, not a pulmonary one.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old male patient with a history of hypertension presents to the emergency department in acute distress. He is diaphoretic, tachycardic, and complains of severe chest pain. His ECG is given below. Given the patient's condition, what is the most appropriate immediate management for this patient?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Synchronized cardioversion

 

Explanation:

The patient's clinical presentation of acute distress, diaphoresis, tachycardia, and severe chest pain, along with the ECG showing saw-tooth flutter waves indicative of atrial flutter, suggests he is hemodynamically unstable.

  • This necessitates immediate synchronized cardioversion to restore normal sinus rhythm and stabilize his condition.

 

Atrial Flutter

Features
  • Atrial flutter is characterized by a large re-entry circuit, usually within the right atrium, encircling the tricuspid annulus originating from the cavotricuspid isthmus.
  • The atrial rate is approximately 300 beats per minute.
  • It is typically associated with 2:1, 3:1, or 4:1 AV block, resulting in ventricular rates of 150, 100, or 75 beats per minute.

ECG Features
  • The ECG shows saw-tooth flutter waves, often referred to as "F-waves."
  • With a 2:1 AV block, flutter waves may be buried in QRS complexes and T waves, making them difficult to identify.

Diagnosis
  • Atrial flutter should be suspected in narrow-complex tachycardia at a rate of 150 beats per minute.
  • Carotid sinus pressure or intravenous adenosine may help reveal flutter waves by temporarily increasing the degree of AV block.

Management

1. Rhythm Control:

  • Acute Management:
    • Hemodynamically Unstable Patients: Synchronized cardioversion.
    • Stable Patients:
      • Electrical cardioversion (if no intracardiac thrombus).
      • Pharmacological cardioversion:
        • Antiarrhythmic drugs:
          • Amiodarone
          • Class IA: Procainamide, Quinidine, Disopyramide
          • Class IC: Flecainide, Propafenone
        • Calcium Channel Blockers: Verapamil, Diltiazem
        • Beta-Blockers: Metoprolol, Carvedilol, Esmolol
  • Long-Term Management:
    • Radiofrequency catheter ablation of the cavotricuspid isthmus.

2. Rate Control:

  • First-Line Agents:
    • Calcium Channel Blockers (e.g., Verapamil, Diltiazem)
    • Beta-Blockers (e.g., Metoprolol, Carvedilol, Esmolol)
    • Digoxin (use cautiously due to toxicity).
  • Goal: Heart rate < 110 beats per minute.

3. Anticoagulation:

  • Assess stroke risk using the CHADS2-VASC score:
  • Anticoagulation Recommendations:
    • 2 or more points: Strong recommendation for anticoagulation.
    • 1 point: Consider either aspirin or full anticoagulation.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a routine follow-up. She has a history of mild hypertension, which is well-controlled with medication. She reports no symptoms such as palpitations, dizziness, or chest pain. An ECG of the patient is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the ECG findings?



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) First-Degree AV Block

 

Explanation:

  • The ECG shows a prolonged PR interval (>0.20 seconds) but consistently conducts P waves to QRS complexes, indicating first-degree AV block.
  • There are no dropped beats, ruling out higher-degree blocks.

 

First Degree AV Block

Pathology
  • First-degree AV block is characterized by a prolonged PR interval (>0.20 seconds) without disruption of conduction from atria to ventricles.
  • The delay typically occurs in the AV node, but may also involve the atria, His bundle, or Purkinje fibers.

Etiology
  • Commonly attributed to increased vagal tone in younger patients.
  • In older patients, often due to fibrotic changes in the cardiac conduction system.
  • Other causes include coronary heart disease, myocardial infarction, electrolyte abnormalities, inflammation, infections, certain drugs, infiltrative diseases, collagen vascular diseases, and idiopathic degenerative diseases.
  • Lymes disease, Chagas disease, Diphtheria, Rheumatoid arthritis, Scleroderma.

Clinical Features
  • Usually asymptomatic; patients are often unaware of the condition until discovered on an ECG.
  • In cases where the PR interval exceeds 0.30 seconds, symptoms may resemble "pacemaker syndrome," including dyspnea, malaise, lightheadedness, and chest pain.

ECG Features
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by a PR interval greater than 0.20 seconds on an ECG.
  • PR interval can be marked (>0.30 seconds) in some cases, and P waves may appear within preceding T waves.

Treatment
  • Generally, no treatment is required; routine observation is sufficient.
  • Pacemaker placement may be considered for symptomatic patients with PR interval >0.30 seconds or those with coexisting heart disease.
  • No antiarrhythmic medications are indicated, and surveillance with routine ECGs is recommended to monitor for worsening.

 

Second-Degree AV Block (Option A):

  • This block features progressive lengthening of the PR interval followed by a dropped QRS complex, which is absent in this ECG as there are no dropped beats.


 

Third-Degree AV Block (Option C):

  • Here, there is complete dissociation between P waves and QRS complexes.
  • This is absent in the ECG since P waves are consistently followed by QRS complexes.

 

Bundle Branch Block (Option D):

  • This condition shows a wide QRS complex with characteristic morphology.
  • This feature is absent in the ECG, where the QRS complexes are normal in width and shape

questions.text: A patient of CKD has tachycardia. An ECG is taken and shown below. What’s the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Hyperkalemia:

  • Chronic kidney disease (CKD) often leads to electrolyte imbalances due to impaired kidney function. Hyperkalemia is one such common imbalance, which can have significant effects on cardiac function.

  • ECG Findings in Hyperkalemia:

    • Tall, peaked T waves

    • Widened QRS complexes

    • Prolonged PR interval

    • Flattening or absence of P waves

    • Eventually, this can lead to a sine-wave pattern and ventricular fibrillation if untreated.

  • These ECG changes are characteristic of hyperkalemia, particularly in the setting of CKD, where the kidneys are unable to excrete potassium effectively.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Hypokalemia: ECG findings typically include U waves, flattened or inverted T waves, and prolonged QT interval.

Option C - Hypercalcemia: ECG may show a shortened QT interval.

Option D - Hypocalcemia: ECG may show a prolonged QT interval.

questions.text: A 60-year-old lady presents with SOB and angina pectoris episodes. Work up shows aortic stenosis. Which of the following is the reason behind these chest pain episodes?

choices.text: Increase in volume overload of heart

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Increased oxygen consumption in the heart:

  • Aortic Stenosis and Angina:
    • In aortic stenosis, the narrowed aortic valve obstructs blood flow from the left ventricle to the aorta. This obstruction increases the left ventricular pressure as the heart must work harder to overcome the resistance, leading to left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH).
    • The hypertrophied myocardium increases oxygen demand but, due to the narrowed valve, coronary perfusion is compromised, especially during diastole. This imbalance between increased oxygen demand and reduced supply leads to myocardial ischemia and angina.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Increased pressure in the aorta: This is not the primary cause of angina. The pressure increases in the left ventricle, not in the aorta.

Option B - Decreased pressure in the aorta: While aortic pressure may be lower during ejection, this is not the direct cause of angina.

Option D - Increase in volume overload of the heart: Volume overload is more associated with conditions like mitral regurgitation or heart failure, not typically with the chest pain in aortic stenosis.

questions.text: Patient presents with features of right heart failure and exhibits a rapid Y descent on cardiac examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Constrictive Pericarditis:

  • Constrictive pericarditis is a condition where the pericardium becomes thickened and fibrotic, leading to impaired filling of the heart, particularly the right side. A rapid Y descent on jugular venous pressure (JVP) is a classic finding in constrictive pericarditis, reflecting rapid early diastolic filling of the ventricle due to the rigid pericardium. The patient may present with signs of right heart failure, such as peripheral edema, ascites, and hepatomegaly.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Cardiac Tamponade: Cardiac tamponade typically presents with a blunted or absent Y descent on JVP tracing due to the equalization of pressures during diastole, which restricts ventricular filling. The presence of a rapid Y descent makes cardiac tamponade less likely.

Option C - Pulmonary Hypertension: Pulmonary hypertension can cause right heart failure, but it is not associated with a rapid Y descent on JVP. The JVP findings in pulmonary hypertension are usually more related to elevated pressure rather than specific waveforms like a rapid Y descent.

Option D - Right Ventricular Infarction: Right ventricular infarction can present with signs of right heart failure. However, the JVP typically shows an elevated a-wave or a prominent X descent, not a rapid Y descent.

questions.text: A pulmonary artery hypertension patient presented with an irregularly irregular pulse with loud P2 on auscultation. Which JVP finding will be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Absent a waves:

Clinical Context:

  • The patient has pulmonary artery hypertension (PAH) and presents with an irregularly irregular pulse and a loud P2 (second heart sound). The irregularly irregular pulse suggests the presence of atrial fibrillation, which is often associated with PAH due to right atrial enlargement from increased pressure.

JVP Findings in Atrial Fibrillation:

Absent a Waves:

  • In atrial fibrillation, the irregular and often rapid contractions of the atria lead to ineffective atrial contraction. As a result, the a waves, which represent atrial contractions, are absent in the JVP waveform. This is consistent with the finding in atrial fibrillation where the rhythm is irregular and there is no coordinated atrial contraction.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Cannon a Waves: Cannon a waves are seen in conditions where there are atrial contractions against a closed tricuspid valve, as in cases of complete heart block or atrial fibrillation with discordance between atrial and ventricular contractions. However, this finding is not as specific as the absence of a waves in atrial fibrillation.

Option C - Rapid x Descent: Rapid x descent is more associated with conditions like constrictive pericarditis rather than atrial fibrillation, which is the primary condition described here.

Option D - Rapid y Descent: Rapid y descent is indicative of constrictive pericarditis or other conditions where there is rapid filling of the ventricles. It is not typically associated with atrial fibrillation.

questions.text: A young athlete underwent testing for a competition and was found to have hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Which of the following will increase the murmur in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Valsalva Maneuver:

  • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is a condition characterized by the thickening of the heart muscle, particularly the interventricular septum, which can obstruct blood flow out of the left ventricle, leading to a systolic murmur. The murmur associated with HCM is dynamic and can change in intensity with different maneuvers that affect the volume of blood in the left ventricle.
  • The Valsalva maneuver decreases venous return to the heart, leading to reduced left ventricular filling. In HCM, this reduction in ventricular volume increases the obstruction to blood flow, making the murmur louder. This maneuver accentuates the outflow tract obstruction by bringing the hypertrophied septum closer to the anterior mitral valve leaflet.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Handgrip: The handgrip maneuver increases systemic vascular resistance, which typically increases murmurs of regurgitant lesions like mitral regurgitation but decreases the murmur in HCM because the increased afterload reduces the degree of outflow tract obstruction.

Option C - Squatting: Squatting increases venous return and systemic vascular resistance, leading to increased left ventricular filling and a reduction in the outflow tract obstruction. This typically softens the murmur in HCM.

Option D - Leaning Forward: Leaning forward can accentuate murmurs of aortic regurgitation but does not have a significant effect on the murmur of HCM.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs will cause Torsades de pointes if given with erythromycin?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Astemizole:

  • Astemizole is an antihistamine that has been associated with QT interval prolongation, a risk factor for Torsades de pointes, a type of life-threatening ventricular tachycardia. Erythromycin, a macrolide antibiotic, is known to inhibit the cytochrome P450 3A4 (CYP3A4) enzyme. Astemizole is metabolized by CYP3A4, and when given together, erythromycin can increase the levels of astemizole, leading to significant QT prolongation and a high risk of Torsades de pointes. Due to this risk, astemizole has been withdrawn from the market in many countries.

 

Incorrect Options

Option B - Levofloxacin: Levofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic that can also cause QT interval prolongation. However, when given with erythromycin, the risk of Torsades de pointes is lower compared to astemizole because levofloxacin is not as strongly influenced by CYP3A4 interactions.

Option C - Amoxicillin: Amoxicillin is a beta-lactam antibiotic that does not prolong the QT interval and is not associated with Torsades de pointes, either alone or in combination with erythromycin.

Option D - Ceftriaxone: Ceftriaxone is a third-generation cephalosporin that also does not prolong the QT interval or interact with erythromycin to increase the risk of Torsades de pointes.

questions.text: A patient presents with shortness of breath. Vitals are HR= 120/min, BP= 160/100. Echo shows diastolic collapse of ventricles. CT showed money bag appearance. Which is best for management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Pericardiocentesis:

Diagnosis: Cardiac Tamponade

  • The combination of shortness of breath, tachycardia, elevated blood pressure, diastolic collapse of the ventricles on echocardiogram, and the "money bag" appearance on CT strongly suggests cardiac tamponade. The "money bag" appearance refers to the shape of the pericardial sac when it is filled with a significant amount of fluid, leading to the characteristic external compression of the heart.

Management: Pericardiocentesis:

  • The definitive treatment for cardiac tamponade is pericardiocentesis. This procedure involves the drainage of the accumulated fluid in the pericardial sac, which relieves the pressure on the heart, allowing normal cardiac function to resume. This intervention is urgent and life-saving.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Start diuretic with BP monitoring: Diuretics are contraindicated in cardiac tamponade as they can decrease preload, further reducing cardiac output and worsening the patient's condition.

Option B - Intra-aortic balloon pump: An intra-aortic balloon pump is used to support the heart in cases of cardiogenic shock, but it is not effective in cardiac tamponade, where the primary issue is external compression of the heart, not inadequate pump function.

Option D - Ventricular assist device: A ventricular assist device is used in severe heart failure to help the ventricles pump blood. However, it is not appropriate for cardiac tamponade, where the problem is due to fluid accumulation in the pericardium rather than intrinsic ventricular failure.

questions.text: What is the next best step in management of a pulseless patient with the following rhythm?

choices.text: Check pulse and give synchronized DC
Give synchronized DC and continue chest compression

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Defibrillate and continue chest compression:

Management of Pulseless Monomorphic Ventricular Tachycardia:

  • Pulseless monomorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT) is a type of ventricular arrhythmia that requires immediate treatment. The absence of a pulse indicates that the patient is in cardiac arrest and effective treatment is critical to restore circulation and potentially save the patient's life.

Recommended Steps:

  1. Defibrillate:
    • For pulseless VT (or pulseless ventricular fibrillation), immediate defibrillation is indicated. Defibrillation provides an electric shock to the heart to reset the electrical activity and restore a normal rhythm.
  2. Continue Chest Compressions:
    • While defibrillation is being administered, chest compressions should continue as they are essential for maintaining blood flow to vital organs until normal rhythm is restored.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Defibrillate and check pulse: After defibrillation, checking for a pulse is important, but it should not delay the immediate administration of another shock if the patient remains pulseless. Compressions should continue uninterrupted during this process.

Option C - Check pulse and give synchronized DC: Checking for a pulse before defibrillation is inappropriate in the context of pulseless cardiac arrest. Synchronized direct current (DC) cardioversion is used for certain arrhythmias like atrial fibrillation or atrial flutter with a pulse, not for pulseless VT.

Option D - Give synchronized DC and continue chest compression: Synchronized DC cardioversion is not the appropriate treatment for pulseless VT. Defibrillation (not synchronized cardioversion) is required in this case.

questions.text: A patient with a history of hypertension presents with atrial fibrillation, shortness of breath and Bilateral basal crackles on auscultation. Least important in management would be:

choices.text: Start on anticoagulants like warf or Doac
Cardioversion to correct rhythm if hemodynamically remain unstable even after medical management

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Start beta blocker:

  • Beta blockers are used to control heart rate and manage symptoms related to atrial fibrillation. However, in acute settings with symptoms like shortness of breath and bilateral crackles, especially if heart failure is suspected, other treatments might take precedence. In cases of acute heart failure or unstable hemodynamics, immediate rate control might be achieved using other agents.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Start on anticoagulants like warfarin or DOAC: Anticoagulants are crucial in the management of atrial fibrillation to prevent thromboembolic events such as stroke. Given the patient's symptoms and history, anticoagulation should be considered unless contraindicated.

Option C - Cardioversion to correct rhythm if hemodynamically unstable even after medical management: If the patient remains hemodynamically unstable despite medical management, cardioversion is necessary to restore normal sinus rhythm and stabilize the patient. This is crucial in managing acute atrial fibrillation.

Option D - IV Digoxin to control rate: IV digoxin is used for rapid rate control in atrial fibrillation, especially when accompanied by heart failure. It can be beneficial in acute settings for managing symptoms and controlling the ventricular rate.

questions.text: The PR interval was measured at 0.21 seconds in a routine ECG of the patient. What is the correct Interpretation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - First degree HB:

  • First-degree heart block is defined by a prolonged PR interval greater than 0.20 seconds (200 milliseconds). In this case, a PR interval of 0.21 seconds indicates a prolonged PR interval, which is characteristic of first-degree heart block.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Second degree HB: Second-degree heart block (HB) is characterized by intermittent failure of some atrial impulses to be conducted to the ventricles. This is usually identified by a pattern of dropped beats or a varying PR interval. The PR interval in second-degree HB can be normal or prolonged, but it does not specifically represent a fixed interval as seen in first-degree HB.

Option C - Normal rhythm: A normal PR interval ranges from 0.12 to 0.20 seconds. A PR interval of 0.21 seconds exceeds this range, indicating that the rhythm is not normal.

Option D - Complete HB: Complete heart block (also known as third-degree heart block) is characterized by a complete dissociation between atrial and ventricular activity, with no correlation between P waves and QRS complexes. The PR interval is not applicable in this context as the atrial impulses do not conduct to the ventricles.

questions.text: A 70 year old male patient presents to the OPD with multiple, recurrent fainting episodes. An ECG was taken and it shows P waves at a rate of 75 bpm and qrs complexes at a rate of 35 bpm. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Stokes adams syndrome

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations indicate Stokes Adams syndrome, characterized by complete heart block with recurrent syncope. The ECG findings show P waves at 75 bpm with QRS complexes at 35 bpm, demonstrating AV dissociation typical of complete heart block or IIIrd degree heart block.
  • This indicates a complete interruption of electrical conduction between the atria and ventricles, leading to independent atrial and ventricular rhythms.

Third-degree atrioventricular block / Stokes-Adams Syndrome

Definition

Complete failure of conduction between atria and ventricles, resulting in independent beating (AV dissociation).

Ventricular Activity

Maintained by an escape rhythm from:

  • The AV node or bundle of His (narrow QRS complexes).
  • Distal Purkinje tissues (broad QRS complexes).

ECG Findings
  • Prolonged PR interval
  • Broad QRS complex
  • Number of P waves will not be equal to the number of R waves
  • P-R interval (atrial rate) will not match the R-R interval (ventricular rate)

Clinical Features
  • Recurrent syncope or 'Stokes–Adams' attacks- sudden loss of consciousness and collapse.
  • Brief anoxic seizure.
  • Pallor and a death-like appearance during the attack; characteristic flush upon recovery.
  • Rapid recovery distinguishes it from epilepsy.

Management
  • Depends on clinical circumstances.
  • Transient AV block in acute inferior myocardial infarction- no treatment if the patient remains stable.
  • Symptomatic third-degree AV block- intravenous atropine or intravenous isoprenaline to maintain circulation until temporary pacing is inserted.
  • Permanent pacemaker.

 

Mobitz type II heart block (Option A) presents with intermittent failure of AV conduction with normal PR intervals 200ms. Unlike complete heart block, some P waves still conduct to the ventricles, and the pattern is not consistent with the current ECG findings.

First degree heart block (Option C) shows prolonged PR interval >200ms with 1:1 AV conduction. This is typically asymptomatic and would not cause the presenting symptoms of recurrent syncope.

Wolf parkinson white syndrome (Option D) presents with a short PR interval <120ms and delta waves. This represents pre-excitation through an accessory pathway and does not cause the AV dissociation seen in this case.

questions.text: A patient came with the complaints of fatigue and difficulty breathing. On examination, distended neck veins and muffled heart sounds were found. X-ray is shown below. Identify the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Constrictive pericarditis

Explanation:

  • The chest X-ray showing a normal sized heart with thickened pericardium due to pericardial fibrosis/calcification (Egg in cup appearance) and classic triad of symptoms: dyspnea, distended neck veins (indicating elevated jugular venous pressure), and muffled heart sounds which indicates constrictive pericarditis.
  • This condition occurs due to fibrous or calcific constrictive thickening of the pericardium, leading to loss of pericardial elasticity and restricted ventricular filling during diastole.

Constrictive Pericarditis:

Pathophysiology:

  • Progressive thickening, fibrosis, and calcification of the pericardium restrict heart filling.
  • Calcification can extend into the myocardium, impairing myocardial contraction.
  • Restricted ventricular filling leads to elevated atrial pressures, causing:
    • Atrial hypertrophy
    • Atrial dilation
    • Atrial fibrillation (common).
  • Primarily manifests as systemic venous congestion (lung congestion is rare).
  • Shows “Egg in cup appearance” on Xray

 

Examination Findings:

Finding

Description

Elevated JVP with rapid y descent

Reflects rapid early diastolic filling of the right ventricle due to pressure gradient.

Fatigue

Caused by the heart’s inability to meet circulatory demands.

Rapid, low-volume pulse

Restricted filling limits stroke volume, weakening the pulse.

Pericardial knock

A loud early S3 from the thickened pericardium during diastolic filling.

Kussmaul’s sign

Paradoxical rise in JVP during inspiration.

Hepatomegaly

Liver enlargement due to increased venous pressure.

Ascites

Abdominal fluid accumulation due to systemic venous congestion.

Peripheral oedema

Swelling in the extremities from fluid retention.

Pulsus paradoxus

A fall in systolic BP (10mm Hg) during inspiration, potentially impalpable pulse.

Atrial fibrillation

Common due to atrial hypertrophy and dilation.

Acute pericarditis (Option A) presents with a flask-shaped, enlarged cardiac silhouette while in constrictive pericarditis, the heart is normal sized. The chest X-ray appearance is distinctly different from the egg-in-cup appearance seen in constrictive pericarditis.

Bronchial asthma (Option B) shows pulmonary hyperinflation with bronchial wall thickening. The cardiac silhouette and mediastinal structures would not show the pattern seen in this X-ray.

Atrial myxoma (Option D) typically presents with cardiomegaly, left atrial enlargement, and vascular redistribution. The X-ray findings and clinical presentation are not consistent with this diagnosis.

questions.text: A patient has muffled heart sounds with low blood pressure. What is the correct JVP finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Absent y descent

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations such as muffled heart sounds with low blood pressure indicate cardiac tamponade, which is characterized by the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space, leading to compromised cardiac filling and subsequent hemodynamic compromise.
  • In cardiac tamponade, the characteristic finding is absent y descent and non-pulsatile elevated JVP due to impaired right ventricular filling during diastole. The condition presents with Beck's triad, which includes muffled heart sounds, hypotension, and elevated JVP.

Cardiac Tamponade

Definition

A condition where the cardiac chambers are compressed by a tense pericardial effusion, limiting cardiac inflow. Fluid accumulation of as little as 200 ml to upwards of 2L may lead to cardiac tamponade development.

Clinical Features

Beck's triad

  • Jugular Venous Distension: Due to increased central venous pressure. Prominent x descent and an absent y descent.
  • Hypotension: Resulting from impaired cardiac output.
  • Muffled Heart Sounds: Caused by fluid accumulation in the pericardial space, dampening heart sounds.

Other features

Pulsus Paradoxus: A drop in systolic BP during inspiration, greater than 10 mm Hg.

Causes of Pulsus paradoxus:

  • Lung Conditions: Acute asthma, COPD, tension pneumothorax, pleural effusion, pulmonary embolism.
  • Heart Conditions: Cardiac tamponade, constrictive pericarditis.

 

Steep x descent (Option A): Steep x descent is typically seen in constrictive pericarditis. Although prominent x descent is also seen in cardiac tamponade, absent y descent is a more highlighting feature typical of cardiac tamponade.

Steep y descent (Option C): Steep y descent is observed in exaggerated tricuspid regurgitation, which allows for rapid right atrial emptying during diastole.

Blunted x descent (Option D): Blunted x descent is seen in restrictive cardiomyopathy where there is impaired ventricular relaxation. The clinical presentation of muffled heart sounds and hypotension is more consistent with cardiac tamponade rather than restrictive cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: A young male patient presents with sudden onset chest pain for one hour with ECG showing STE in lead 2,3 and aVF. Which is the best treatment for this case of inferior wall MI in a multispecialty hospital?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Primary angioplasty

Explanation:

The clinical manifestations (sudden onset chest pain) with characteristic ECG findings (ST elevation in lead 2,3 and aVF) indicate an acute inferior wall ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI).

Primary angioplasty, also known as Primary Percutaneous Coronary Intervention (PCI), is the gold standard treatment for STEMI when performed at a capable facility within 120 minutes of first medical contact.

  • Immediate Goals:
    • Control cardiac discomfort.
    • Rapidly identify patients for reperfusion therapy.
    • Proper triage of lower-risk patients.
    • Avoid inappropriate discharge of STEMI patients.
  • Overall Aim: Initiate percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) within 120 minutes of first medical contact, including transfer to a PCI-capable facility if necessary.

 

Alteplase (Option A): Alteplase, a tissue plasminogen activator, is only preferred in non-PCI-capable hospitals, where patients are further to be transferred to a PCI capable hospital. In a multispecialty hospital with PCI capabilities, primary angioplasty offers better outcomes with lower bleeding risk.

Streptokinase (Option B): Streptokinase is no longer the treatment of choice according to current guidelines due to its risk of anaphylaxis and inferior outcomes compared to primary PCI.

Dabigatran (Option D): Dabigatran is an anticoagulant and is not indicated for the treatment of STEMI. While anticoagulation is part of STEMI management, direct oral anticoagulants like dabigatran are not the primary treatment strategy in acute STEMI.

PIM050

questions.text: "A 45-year-old female presents to the emergency department with breathlessness. She has a history of a viral infection and chest pain from 7 days ago. A chest X-ray reveals a "water bottle" heart. All of the following statements are true except:"

choices.text: ECG showing RA and RV collapse requires immediate intervention

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Loud S1:

  • In the described scenario, viral pericarditis initially occurred, progressing to pericardial effusion and subsequent diastolic collapse of the ventricles, resulting in cardiac tamponade. Due to the presence of fluid surrounding the heart, muffled heart sounds are expected rather than a loud S1.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pulsus paradoxus is observed: Pulsus paradoxus, characterized by a drop in blood pressure of more than 12 mmHg during inspiration, is a feature of cardiac tamponade.

Option C - Emergency pericardiocentesis may be required: This statement is true as pericardiocentesis is performed as an emergency measure as there is diastolic collapse of the ventricles.

Option D - ECG showing RA and RV collapse requires immediate intervention: This statement is true as there is diastolic collapse of ventricles in cardiac tamponade.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is indicated by the symptoms of chest pain and breathlessness in a 55-year-old male, as revealed by the provided ECG?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Posterior wall myocardial infarction (MI): 

  • ST depression is evident in leads V2, V3, and V4, displaying a predominantly horizontal configuration, with upright T waves. Moreover, the R/S ratio in anterior chest leads is greater than 1. These combined observations suggest the likelihood of a posterior wall myocardial infarction.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A & B - Unstable angina & NSTEMI: The ECG changes observed in both unstable angina and NSTEMI display similarities and show T wave inversion accompanying ST depression.

Option C - Acute myocarditis: There are no pathognomic findings in acute myocarditis as it shows non-specific ST segment changes.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding a 35-year-old male presenting to the emergency department with unconsciousness and the given ECG findings?

choices.text: Occurrence in individuals with normal heart without any significant pathology is impossible.
Direct current cardioversion is universally performed to restore normal rhythm.
Intravenous digoxin is the preferred drug.
Discrepancy in HR and PR used for diagnosis

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Direct current cardioversion is universally performed to restore normal rhythm: 

  • The ECG given shows an irregularly irregular RR interval indicating atrial fibrillation. Direct cardioversion is avoided in these cases due to the associated risk of stroke.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Occurrence in individuals with normal heart without any significant pathology is impossible:

  • This statement is correct as atrial fibrillation is one of the most common arrhythmias seen in individuals with structural damage to the heart rather than with a normal heart.

Option C - Intravenous digoxin is the preferred drug:

  • In case of atrial fibrillation with heart failure, Intravenous digoxin will be administered.

Option D - Discrepancy in HR and PR used for diagnosis:

  • The presence of pulse deficit, that is discrepancy in HR and PR is the most accurate way of diagnosis of the individual. Hence this statement is also correct.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man presents with episodes of chest pain. Physical examination reveals a bisferiens pulse and a heaving apex. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM)

Explanation:

  • The presence of a bisferiens pulse (double-peaked pulse) and a heaving apex are characteristic physical findings of Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM).
  • This condition is characterized by asymmetric hypertrophy of the ventricular septum, which can cause dynamic obstruction of the left ventricular outflow tract.

 

Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM)

Feature

Characteristics

Pathophysiology
  • Autosomal dominant genetic disorder
  • Mutations in beta-myosin heavy-chain, troponin, and myosin-binding protein C
  • Inappropriate left ventricular hypertrophy

Key Physical Findings
  • Bisferiens (jerky arterial) pulse
  • Heaving apex
  • Mid-systolic murmur
  • Dynamic LVOT obstruction

Common Symptoms
  • Angina (chest pain)
  • Dyspnea
  • Syncope
  • MC cause of sudden death

Pathological Features
  • Misaligned myocardial fibers
  • Myocardial fibrosis
  • Rigid left ventricle
  • Impaired diastolic filling

Examination Findings

Clinical Finding

Description

Palpable Left Ventricular Hypertrophy

An enlarged left ventricle can be felt during physical examination, indicating hypertrophy.

Double Impulse at the Apex

A palpable fourth heart sound suggests forceful atrial contraction against a non-compliant ventricle.

Mid-Systolic Murmur at the Base

Turbulent blood flow through the obstructed left ventricular outflow tract produces a mid-systolic murmur.

Pansystolic Murmur at the Apex

Indicates mitral regurgitation caused by abnormal systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve.

Jerky Arterial Pulse

Characteristic of HOCM, contrasts with the slow-rising pulse seen in aortic stenosis.

Pulsus bisferiens

A double pulse noticed during systole in the peripheral pulse is called pulsus bisferiens. It is associated with severe aortic disease accompanied by aortic regurgitation and HOCM.

 

 

 

Dilated Cardiomyopathy (Option A) is characterized by left ventricular dilation and impaired systolic function. Physical exam findings typically include signs of heart failure, such as elevated jugular venous pressure and displaced apex beat, but bisferiens pulse and heaving apex are not typical features.

Mitral Stenosis (Option C) presents with obstruction of blood flow from the left atrium to the left ventricle. Physical exam findings typically include a diastolic murmur best heard at the apex and possible signs of left atrial enlargement, but bisferiens pulse is not a characteristic finding.

Aortic Stenosis (Option D) causes obstruction of blood flow from the left ventricle into the aorta. While it can present with chest pain, the classic physical findings include a systolic ejection murmur and a reduced or delayed carotid pulse, not a bisferiens pulse.

questions.text: Based on the given ECG, identify which wall of the myocardium was affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Anterior wall

Explanation:

  • The ECG demonstrates ST elevation in leads V2, V3, and V4 is indicative of an anterior wall myocardial infarction (MI)
  • The ECG shows ST segment elevation with a convex upward shape (Pardee sign) in the precordial leads, which is characteristic of acute anterior wall myocardial infarction supplied by the left anterior descending artery.

Infarct Localization based on ECG

Infarct Location

Affected Coronary Artery

Leads

Lateral Wall MI (Option D)

Left Circumflex Artery (LCx)

V5, V6, I, aVL

Septal Wall MI

Septal Branch of Left Anterior Descending Artery (LAD)

V1, V2

Anterior Wall MI (Option A)

Left Anterior Descending Artery (LAD)

V1-V4, I, aVL

Extensive Anterior Wall MI

Left Main Coronary Artery (LMCA)

V1-V6, I, aVL

Posterior Wall MI (Option C)

Posterior Descending Artery (PDA)

V1-V4 (ST depression), V7, V8, V9 (ST elevation)

Inferior Wall MI (Option A)

Right Coronary Artery (RCA)

Leads II, III, aVF

NSTEMI (Anterior Wall)

Left Anterior Descending Artery (LAD)

Often subtle changes in V1-V4

 

Inferior wall (Option A) involvement typically shows ST elevation in leads II, III, and aVF, which is not present in this ECG tracing. The absence of these changes rules out inferior wall MI.

Posterior wall (Option C) involvement would show ST depression in leads V1-V4 and ST elevation in leads V7, V8, and V9. This pattern is not seen in the current ECG.

Lateral wall (Option D) involvement would show changes in leads V5, V6, I, and aVL. While there may be some changes in these leads, they are not the predominant finding, and the primary area of involvement is clearly anterior.

questions.text: In which of the following scenarios is Rescue Percutaneous Coronary Intervention (PCI) indicated?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Failed thrombolysis

Explanation:

  • Rescue PCI is specifically indicated when thrombolytic therapy fails to restore coronary blood flow in acute myocardial infarction.
  • This intervention becomes necessary when initial thrombolytic treatment is unsuccessful in dissolving the occluding blood clot, as evidenced by persistent symptoms, ongoing ST-segment elevation, or hemodynamic instability. The procedure serves as a secondary intervention to mechanically reestablish coronary perfusion when pharmacological reperfusion has failed.

 

2013 ACCF/AHA Guideline for the management of ST-elevation myocardial infarction. Reperfusion therapy for patients with STEMI. (CABG indicates coronary artery bypass graft; DIDO, door-in–door-out; FMC, first medical contact; LOE, Level of Evidence; MI, myocardial infarction; PCI, percutaneous coronary intervention; and STEMI, ST-elevation myocardial infarction)

 

Chronic stable angina (Option B) is characterized by predictable chest pain occurring with exertion or stress. While PCI may be performed for relief in cases where medical management has failed, it is not classified as rescue PCI. The intervention in stable angina is planned and elective rather than emergent.

Prinzmetal's angina (Option C) is caused by coronary artery spasm and typically responds to medical management with calcium channel blockers and nitrates. PCI is not usually indicated unless there is a significant fixed obstruction. The primary treatment focuses on managing vasospasm rather than mechanical intervention.

NSTEMI (Option D) management follows a different protocol where initial medical therapy is the standard approach, with PCI timing based on risk stratification and response to treatment. While PCI may be indicated in NSTEMI, it is not considered rescue PCI as it is part of the planned treatment strategy rather than a rescue measure after failed therapy.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with a history of tuberculosis now complains of abdominal distension and pedal edema. On examination, his neck veins are prominent. His chest x-ray is given below. Which of the following findings will be likely seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) SBP falls from 80mmHg to 60mmHg

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation including distended neck veins (elevated JVP), abdominal distension, and pedal edema and chest X-ray findings of increased cardiothoracic ratio are consistent with cardiac tamponade. Also, given the history of tuberculosis, this is likely tuberculous pericarditis leading to tamponade.
  • In cardiac tamponade, there is typically a significant drop in systolic blood pressure during inspiration (pulsus paradoxus), which in this case is represented by the fall in SBP from 80mmHg to 60mmHg (>10mmHg drop).

 

Cardiac Tamponade

Definition

A condition where the cardiac chambers are compressed by a tense pericardial effusion, limiting cardiac inflow. Fluid accumulation of as little as 200 ml to upwards of 2L may lead to cardiac tamponade development.

Clinical Features

Beck's triad

  • Jugular Venous Distension: Due to increased central venous pressure. Prominent x descent and an absent y descent.
  • Hypotension: Resulting from impaired cardiac output.
  • Muffled Heart Sounds: Caused by fluid accumulation in the pericardial space, dampening heart sounds.

Other features

Pulsus Paradoxus: Hallmark finding. A drop in systolic BP during inspiration, greater than 10 mm Hg.

Causes of Pulsus paradoxus:

  • Lung Conditions: Acute asthma, COPD, tension pneumothorax, pleural effusion, pulmonary embolism.
  • Heart Conditions: Cardiac tamponade, constrictive pericarditis.

 

Pulsus biferiens (Option A) is a double-peaked pulse typically seen in aortic regurgitation and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. This finding is not characteristic of cardiac tamponade.

Kussmaul breathing (Option B) refers to deep and labored breathing seen in metabolic acidosis, particularly diabetic ketoacidosis. It is not a characteristic finding in cardiac tamponade.

Fine crepitations (Option D) are typically heard in pulmonary edema or pneumonia. In cardiac tamponade, the heart sounds are usually muffled, but crepitations are not a characteristic finding.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in subclinical acute myocarditis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Elevated pro-BNP, Trop T

 

Criteria

Histological confirmation

Biomarker, ECG, or imaging abnormalities consistent with myocarditis

Possible subclinical acute myocarditis

In the clinical context of possible myocardial injury without cardiovascular symptoms (Option A) but with at least one of the following:

  • Biomarkers of cardiac injury raised
  • ECG findings suggestive of cardiac injury
  • Abnormal cardiac function on echocardiogram or cardiac MRI

Absent

Needed

Probable acute myocarditis

In the clinical context of possible myocardial injury with cardiovascular symptoms and at least one of the following:

  • Biomarkers of cardiac injury raised
  • ECG findings suggestive of cardiac injury
  • Abnormal cardiac function on echocardiogram or cardiac MRI

Absent

Needed

Definite myocarditis

Histological or immunohistological evidence of myocarditis

Histological or immunohistological evidence of myocarditis

Not Needed

Options C and D are incorrect as they are not found in subclinical acute myocarditis.

questions.text: Which of the following describes an aortic regurgitation murmur?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Diastolic murmur

  • A diastolic murmur is seen in aortic regurgitation.

Classification of Murmurs

Murmur Type

Subtype

Conditions murmur heard

Additional points

Systolic Murmurs

Ejection Systolic Murmur

(HAPpy)
  1. Pulmonary Stenosis
  2. Aortic Stenosis
  3. HOCM
  • Early systolic murmur seen with papillary muscle dysfunction.
  • Late systolic murmur is seen in small VSD and mitral valve prolapse (MVP)

Pan Systolic Murmur(MTV)
  1. Mitral regurgitation
  2. Tricuspid regurgitation
  3. Ventricular septal defect

Diastolic Murmurs

Early Diastolic Murmur (GAP)
  1. Graham Steell murmur
  2. Aortic regurgitation
  3. Pulmonary regurgitation (mild)
  • Along with hemodynamic changes the characteristics of flow also changes

Mid-Diastolic Murmur
  1. Carey Coombs murmur
  2. Austin Flint murmur
  3. Mitral stenosis
  • Flow murmur may mimic mid-diastolic murmur

Continuous Murmurs

 
  1. Patent ductus arteriosus
  2. Aortopulmonary window
  3. Ruptured sinus of Valsalva aneurysm
  4. Coronary arteriovenous fistula
  5. Cervical venous hum
  6. Anomalous left coronary artery origin
  7. Mammary souffle of pregnancy
  8. Bronchial collateral circulation
  9. Intercostal or pulmonary arteriovenous fistula
  10. Peripheral pulmonic stenosis
  • Causes are diverse and involve persistent communication between systemic and pulmonary circulation.

 

Examination Findings of Aortic Regurgitation

Blood Pressure
  • Elevated systolic pressure and decreased diastolic pressure result in increased arterial pulse pressure.
  • Atrio-ventricular malformation and Atrio-ventricular ﬁstula also show low diastolic BP due to continuous Korotkoﬀ sounds.
  • Positive Hill’s sign is an abnormal difference in BP in the upper limb and lower limb.

On Palpation
  • Heaving LV impulse is noted, which is displaced laterally and inferiorly
  • Diastolic and Systolic Thrills were noticed at the left lower sternal border and suprasternal notch, respectively.

On Auscultation

 

Heart Sounds
  • A2 is absent
  • In the Bicuspid aortic valve, systolic ejection sound is present
  • Sometimes, A4 is also heard

 

 

 

 

 

 

Murmurs
  • A Decrescendo diastolic murmur, best heard when sitting up and leaning forward, is an early diastolic murmur that becomes holo-diastolic as the condition progresses to a severe stage.
  • Musical diastolic murmur is aortic cusp fluttering in the regurgitant flow.
  • Mid-diastolic murmur
  • Austin Flint murmur is a soft, low-pitched, mid- to end-diastolic murmur caused by mitral valve displacement due to AR.
  • Ejection systolic murmur is commonly heard in AR along with AS.

questions.text: What does the ECG in the following image depict?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Torsades de pointes:

  • The polymorphic VT, spindle-shaped pattern, and prolonged QT interval seen in the ECG show the diagnosis of Torsades de Pointes.

Torsades de Pointes

ECG features:

  • Polymorphic VT: Characterized by variation in QRS direction and amplitude.
  • Spindle-shaped pattern: The QRS complexes form a twisting or spindle-shaped "envelope".
  • Prolonged QT interval
  • PVC initiation: Often triggered by a premature ventricular contraction (PVC) on a prolonged T-U wave, creating an "R on T" phenomenon.
  • Postectopic pause: A pause following the PVC, further prolonging repolarization.

Causes:

Mnemonic: "A TIGERS BITE"

  • A - Antiarrhythmics (Class IA and III)
  • T - Tricyclic antidepressants
  • I - Ischemia (myocardial)
  • G - Genetics (congenital long QT syndrome)
  • E - Electrolyte abnormalities (hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, hypocalcemia)
  • R - Restrictive cardiomyopathy
  • S - Stroke (especially subarachnoid haemorrhage)
  • B - Bradycardia
  • I - Interactions (drug-drug interactions that prolong QT)
  • T - Toxins (organophosphates, arsenic, etc.)
  • E - Endocrine disorders (hypothyroidism, pheochromocytoma)

Treatment:

  • Immediate management: Intravenous magnesium sulfate (even if serum magnesium is normal)
  • Discontinue potential QT-prolonging medications
  • Correct electrolyte abnormalities, especially hypokalemia
  • Consider temporary pacing or isoproterenol infusion to increase heart rate and shorten QT interval

Acute pericarditis (Option A) shows T-wave inversion following ST-segment elevation in the ECG.

Viral myocarditis (Option B) shows prolonged QRS, QT prolongation, diffuse T wave inversion, ventricular arrhythmias, and AV conduction defects in the ECG.

Cardiac tamponade (Option D) shows consecutive normally-conducted QRS complexes that alternate in height (electrical alternans) and low QRS voltage with tachycardia in the ECG.

questions.text:
What is the correct order for cardiac auscultation, from superior to inferior?

a. Pulmonary

b. Tricuspid

c. Mitral
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - a > b > c

  • The correct order for auscultation of the heart sounds from superior to inferior is aortic > pulmonary > Erb’s point > tricuspid > mitral. (mnemonic: APE to Man)

"APE to Man" refers to:

  • Aortic Valve: To listen to the aortic valve closing, place the stethoscope on the right side of the sternum at the 2nd intercostal space.
  • Pulmonary Valve: To listen to the pulmonic valve closing, place the stethoscope on the left side of the sternum at the 2nd intercostal space.
  • Erb’s Point (where S2 sound is best heard): Located on the left side at the 3rd intercostal space.

questions.text: Which of the following jvp findings seen in a patient with muffled heart sounds, hypotension and raised JVP?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Absent y descent:

  • Y descent is the drop in JVP during early diastole when the tricuspid valve opens and blood flows from the right atrium to the right ventricle. In cardiac tamponade, the elevated pressure in the right atrium due to compression prevents normal descent of the JVP during diastole, leading to an absent y descent. This is the correct finding for the given scenario.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Absent x descent: X descent is the drop in JVP during ventricular systole. It's seen in conditions where the right atrium is not excessively obstructed or compressed. In cardiac tamponade, the x descent can actually be exaggerated, not absent.

Option C - C waves are enlarged: C waves on the JVP waveform represent the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during ventricular contraction. Enlarged C waves are often seen in conditions like tricuspid regurgitation, but they are not specifically associated with the given symptoms of muffled heart sounds, hypotension, and raised JVP.

Option D - A waves are absent: A waves correspond to atrial contraction, which occurs just before the tricuspid valve closes. Absent A waves can be seen in conditions like atrial fibrillation or complete heart block, where the atria are not contracting in a coordinated manner. However, absent A waves would not directly explain the combination of symptoms mentioned in the scenario.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding Wolf Parkinson's white syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Broad QRS interval:

  • Wolf-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome is a condition in which an abnormal electrical pathway known as an accessory pathway exists between the atria and ventricles of the heart. ECG finding associated with Wolf-Parkinson-White syndrome is a short PR interval and a characteristic broad QRS complex due to the abnormal electrical pathway. The presence of the accessory pathway can lead to a delta wave, which is an initial slurring of the QRS complex, causing it to appear broader than normal.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Short PJ Interval: In WPW syndrome, the characteristic finding is a shortened PR interval rather than a short PJ interval. The PR interval represents the time it takes for the electrical signal to travel from the atria to the ventricles. In WPW syndrome, due to the presence of the accessory pathway, the signal bypasses part of the normal conduction system, resulting in a shorter PR interval on an electrocardiogram (ECG).

Option C - Tall Tented T Waves: Tall tented T waves are not a typical feature of WPW syndrome. Tall tented T waves are associated with conditions like hyperkalemia (high levels of potassium in the blood) and can be seen in ECGs in those scenarios.

Option D - Prolonged PR interval: As mentioned earlier, the PR interval is actually shortened in WPW syndrome due to the accessory pathway bypassing the normal conduction system. A prolonged PR interval could be indicative of other conditions like first-degree heart block.

questions.text: The patient presented with pedal oedema, raised JVP till mandible and ascites. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Cardiac failure:

The symptoms mentioned - pedal edema, raised jugular venous pressure (JVP) up to the mandible, and ascites - are indicative of congestive heart failure (cardiac failure). Let's go through each option and explain why:

  • Congestive heart failure occurs when the heart's pumping ability is compromised, leading to fluid accumulation in various parts of the body. Pedal edema (swelling in the feet and ankles) occurs due to fluid retention in the lower extremities. Raised JVP is a sign of increased pressure in the veins returning blood to the heart, often observed in heart failure due to the inefficient pumping of blood. Ascites, the accumulation of fluid in the abdominal cavity, can also result from the increased venous pressure caused by heart failure.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Renal failure: While renal failure can lead to fluid retention and edema, it typically doesn't cause the specific pattern of JVP elevation and ascites seen in the case. Renal failure might lead to edema and fluid overload, but these symptoms are more directly associated with heart failure in this context.

Option C - Liver failure: Liver failure can lead to ascites due to disruptions in fluid balance and decreased production of proteins responsible for maintaining proper fluid distribution. However, the elevated JVP up to the mandible is less likely to be caused by liver failure alone. This sign is more indicative of heart failure.

Option D - Brain injury: Brain injury, unless involving specific areas of the brain that control fluid balance, is not a likely cause of the symptoms described. Brain injury might lead to other neurological symptoms, but it wouldn't explain the combination of pedal edema, raised JVP, and ascites.

questions.text: A 20 year old male who is an IV drug user. on examination, a temperature of 38.5 C, and some spots can be noted over the fundus. CBC showed a leukocyte count of 20,000/cu mm. Blood has been sent for culture. Infective endocarditis is suspected. How many minor duke's criteria are satisfied for the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 3:

  • Duke's criteria satisfied for the diagnosis of infective endocarditis is 3.
  • Minor Duke's criteria include:
    • Injection drug use
    • Temperature > 38.0°C
    • Phenomena (such as fundus spots)

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy's father noticed agonal respiration at 5 AM while he was asleep. He was rushed to the ER where an ECG was performed as given. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Brugada Syndrome

Explanation:

  • Based on the given scenario and ECG findings (ST elevation in V1-V3), the diagnosis is Brugada Syndrome- a rare, inherited cardiac disorder that predisposes individuals to life-threatening arrhythmias, often occurring during sleep. The presence of agonal respiration at night strongly suggests a ventricular arrhythmia, a hallmark of Brugada Syndrome.
Brugada Syndrome

About

A rare, inherited disease that predisposes patients to potentially fatal cardiac arrhythmias, characterised by right bundle branch block and ST-segment elevations in the right precordial leads (V1-V3) on ECG.

Clinical features
  • Symptoms range from asymptomatic to sudden cardiac death, often during sleep.
  • Syncope in 80% of patients with ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation.
  • Other symptoms: Palpitations, dizziness, and fever history may trigger symptoms.

ECG findings
  • Type I: Coved ST elevations >2 mm with inverted T wave.
  • Type II: Saddleback-shaped ST elevation >2 mm.
  • Type III: Saddleback-shaped ST elevations <2 mm.
  • Patients with a normal ECG and high-risk factors may need a drug challenge test to reveal ST elevations in leads V1 to V3.

Drug challenge test
  • Drugs used in the challenge test:
    • Class IA antiarrhythmics (Procainamide, Ajmaline).
    • IC antiarrhythmics (Flecainide, Propafenone).
  • Brugada ECG findings can also emerge from Cocaine use or Tricyclic antidepressant toxicity.
  • Electrolyte abnormalities like Hyperkalemia and Hypercalcemia can reveal ST elevations in the right precordial leads.
  • A normal drug challenge test in pediatric patients may need to be repeated after puberty due to hormonal influences.
  • The "Full Stomach Test" can also help expose ST elevations by increasing vagal tone.
  • Additional diagnostic options include genetic testing for SCN5A mutations and invasive electrophysiology.

Treatment
  • Implantable Cardioverter-Defibrillator (ICD) for high-risk patients.

Incorrect Options:

Early repolarization syndrome (Option A) is a genetic condition presenting with life-threatening arrhythmias and J-point elevation in ECG. This is not the given scenario here.

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (Option C) is an autosomal dominant cardiac myocyte disease and presents with shortness of breath and chest discomfort. It does not present with agonal respiration at night and is not the given scenario.

Atrial fibrillation (Option D) is a type of cardiac arrhythmia that presents with an irregularly irregular rhythm in the ECG. This is not the given ECG picture.

questions.text: All of the following are the causes of high-output cardiac failure, except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Cor pulmonale

Explanation:

  • Cor pulmonale is a change in the structure and function of the right ventricle developing as a result of a pulmonary disorder leading to pulmonary hypertension. This is not associated with high-output cardiac failure but with right ventricular hypertrophy.

Causes of high-output cardiac failure

Category

Aetiology

Pathophysiology




 

Metabolic

Hyperthyroidism

Increased thyroid hormone increases contractility, heart rate, and systemic metabolism, causing reduced systemic vascular resistance and eventually cardiomyopathy.

Myeloproliferative disorders

Increased cellular metabolism and turnover, leading to higher metabolic demand and decreased systemic vascular resistance.







 

Myocardial

Sepsis

Inflammatory response leads to vasodilation and high cardiac output; initially hyperdynamic phase with low systemic vascular resistance.

Thiamine deficiency (Beriberi) (Option B)

Thiamine deficiency causes systemic vasodilation and direct myocardial effects, resulting in high venous return and cardiomyopathy.

Chronic lung disease

Chronic hypoxia and hypercapnia reduce systemic arterial resistance, causing chronic volume overload and right-sided heart failure.





 

Peripheral vascular

Arteriovenous fistulas (AVF) (Option D)

Shunt from artery to vein bypasses the arteriolar and capillary bed, increasing venous return to the heart, and requiring increased cardiac output.

Liver cirrhosis

Impaired clearance of vasoactive substances and bacterial translocation lead to decreased systemic vascular resistance and high-output failure.

Obesity

Excessive vasodilation due to adipokines and altered myocardial metabolism contribute to high-output cardiac failure.







 

Other

Erythroderma

Vasoactive changes that may lead to high-output cardiac failure (less defined).

Carcinoid syndrome

Tumor secretion of vasoactive substances can cause vasodilation and reduced systemic vascular resistance.

Mitochondrial disorders

Altered cellular metabolism and energy production lead to increased demand and potential high-output failure.

Acromegaly

Increased growth hormone can lead to increased tissue demand and altered vascular resistance.

Paget disease of bone

Increased bone turnover leads to AVF formation, contributing to high-output cardiac failure.

Conditions

Stress, exercise, fever, pregnancy

Temporary increases in metabolic demand or vasodilation, though not direct causes of high-output cardiac failure.
 

Anemia (Option C)

The attempt to compensate for reduced oxygen delivery by increasing cardiac output leads to high-output cardiac failure later on.

questions.text: What does the ECG depict in the following image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Second-degree infra-nodal heart block

Explanation:

  • Given ECG shows progressive lengthening of PR intervals until a dropped beat occurs, which indicates Mobitz type I block, which is a type of second-degree heart block.

 

Second-degree heart block

Dropped beats occur because some impulses from the atria fail to be transmitted to the ventricles.

Types

Mobitz Type I (Wenckebach)

Mobitz Type II

Description
  • Progressive lengthening of PR intervals until a dropped beat occurs.
  • Cycle repeats itself.
  • PR interval remains constant.
  • Some P waves are not conducted.

Clinical Features
  • Often physiological; can occur in young athletes.
  • May not cause symptoms.
  • Caused by His-Purkinje system disease.
  • Higher risk of asystole.

Management
  • Typically does not require treatment.
  • Monitor for changes; consider underlying heart disease.
  • May require treatment if symptomatic.
  • Consider temporary pacing.
  • Monitor closely due to the risk of progression.

 

First-degree heart block (Option A): The PR interval is prolonged but typically not greater than 0.50 seconds, i.e. > 0.20 seconds but < 0.50 seconds. ECG does not show any dropped beat.

AV dissociation (Option D) is seen in third-degree heart blocks (complete heart block) (Option C) due to complete failure of the conduction between atria and ventricles.

questions.text:
A 75-year-old woman with Type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension, developed features of heart failure and expired. The post-mortem cardiac biopsy slide is given below.



What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Restrictive cardiomyopathy

Explanation:

  • The image given here is of amyloid deposits (pink hyaline) in the myocardium causing myocardial stiffening and restriction leading to restrictive cardiomyopathy.

Restrictive Cardiomyopathy

  • Characterized by abnormal diastolic function, often with mildly reduced contractility and ejection fraction (usually 30–50%).

Causes

  • Infiltrative diseases:
    • Amyloidosis (Most common cause)
    • Sarcoidosis
    • Hemochromatosis
  • Fibrotic conditions:
    • Radiation therapy
    • Scleroderma
    • Endomyocardial fibrosis
  • Storage diseases:
    • Glycogen storage diseases (types II, III)
    • Fabry's disease

Pathophysiology

Abnormal Diastolic Function
  • The primary abnormality in restrictive cardiomyopathy is impaired diastolic filling due to the stiffened ventricular walls.
  • Elevated end-diastolic pressures in both ventricles without significant chamber dilation.

Bilateral Atrial Enlargement

The non-compliant ventricles lead to increased pressures, resulting in dilation of both atria.

Right-Sided Heart Failure

The stiff ventricles result in increased filling pressures, particularly affecting the right side, causing peripheral oedema, ascites, and jugular venous distention.

Amyloid Infiltration (in amyloidosis)

Amyloid fibrils (pink hyaline deposits) accumulate between myocytes, leading to myocardial stiffening and restrictive physiology.

Cardiac amyloidosis (Congo red stain)

Fibrosis

In conditions like radiation-induced cardiomyopathy or endomyocardial fibrosis, stiffening of the myocardium occurs due to scarring, further impairing ventricular filling.


Dilated cardiomyopathy (Option A) can be due to many causes broadly classified as infective, noninfective, toxic, and metabolic causes. The biopsy shows myocyte shape variation, inflammation, interstitial fibrosis, signs of cardiotoxicity (depending on the cause), etc. This is however not the given scenario.


Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (Option C) is a genetic disorder and the histological examination shows enlarged cardiomyocytes with eosinophilic cytoplasm and box-shaped nuclei, normal myocardium in patches, interstitial fibrosis, microvascular ischemia, intercalated discs and desmosomes.


Takotsubo cardiomyopathy (Option D), or stress cardiomyopathy, is a transient condition characterized by left ventricular apical ballooning often triggered by emotional or physical stress, mimicking acute coronary syndrome without coronary obstruction. The given image does not represent Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic male with central chest pain, shortness of breath and palpitations came to the emergency department. An ECG was taken, which showed NSTEMI. Which of the following is the right treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Aspirin + Clopidogrel + LMWH

Explanation:

  • NSTEMI is caused due to a platelet-rich thrombus and so, a dual antiplatelet therapy (Aspirin + Clopidogrel) is to be done (not thrombolysis) along with an anticoagulant like low molecular heparin (Enoxparin).

Management of NSTEMI-ACS

  • Management of NSTEMI involves evaluating patients with a low likelihood of ischemia in emergency settings, continuous ECG monitoring, stress testing, and serum troponin assessments, while those who meet criteria for NSTE-ACS are admitted for further monitoring and medical treatment aimed at stabilizing their condition and preventing future events.

Medical management

Anti-ischemic therapy:

  • Sublingual glyceryl trinitrate/nitroglycerin:
    • DOC for unstable angina
    • For ischemic discomfort
  • IV beta-blockers (Atenolol, Metoprolol):
    • They reduce the oxygen demand of the myocardium
    • They relieve pain, reduce arrhythmias, and reduce short-term mortality
  • Verapamil and diltiazem:
    • Given if symptoms are not relieved by full dose beta blockers and nitrates
    • They decrease the heart rate
  • IV morphine sulfate or diamorphine:
    • For analgesia
  • Antiemetics like metoclopramide (For symptomatic relief)
  • Nifedipine or amlodipine (If chest discomfort persists)
  • Atorvastatin and other HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors: Reduces occurrence of MI and recurrences of acute coronary syndrome
  • Ezetimibe or alirocumab, evolocumab:
    • Given if unresponsive to full dose statins
    • They reduce LDL cholesterol and prevent further cardiovascular events

Antithrombotic therapy:

  • Antiplatelet drugs:
    • Cyclooxygenase inhibitor: Aspirin
    • Platelet P2Y12 receptor inhibitor: Clopidogrel

Anticoagulants:

  • Unfractionated heparin.
  • Low molecular heparin: Enoxaparin.
  • Direct thrombin inhibitor: Bivalirudin.
