  • Synthetic factor Xa inhibitor: Fondaparinux.

Invasive management
  • Done if the medical management fails and symptoms do not improve.
  • Coronary arteriography must be done within 48 hours of presentation.
  • Coronary revascularization includes PCI (percutaneous coronary intervention) or coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG).

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are inadequate for the treatment of NSTEMI as it requires a dual platelet therapy with an anticoagulant.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the culture taken in a suspected case of infective endocarditis is correct?

choices.text: Two samples from peripheral lines 30 minutes apart
Three samples from peripheral lines 1 hour apart
One sample only from the peripheral line
Two peripheral samples, two days apart

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Three samples from peripheral lines 1 hour apart

Explanation:

  • The culture taken in a suspected case of infective endocarditis must be by three or more samples from the peripheral line taken over at least 1 hour apart.

Modified Duke’s Criteria - Major criteria
 

Positive blood cultures
  • Identification of a typical organism from two cultures, or persistent positive cultures drawn more than 12 hours apart.
  • Three or more positive cultures that have been taken over at least 1hour apart. (Option B)
  • A single positive blood culture for Coxiella burnetii or a phase I IgG antibody titre > 1:800.
 

Evidence of endocardial involvement
  • Positive echocardiographic findings such as vegetations, abscesses, or new valvular regurgitation.
  • Oscillating intracardiac masses or partial dehiscence of a prosthetic valve.
  • Additional diagnostic tools like FDG-PET/CT or EKG-gated cardiac CT angiograms also meet major criteria for prosthetic valve endocarditis. (Added by the European Society of Cardiology)

questions.text: Identify the condition associated with the murmur depicted in the image below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Mitral Regurgitation

  • The given image shows a pansystolic murmur, which is characteristic of mitral regurgitation (MR). This occurs when the mitral valve does not close completely during systole, causing a backflow of blood from the left ventricle into the left atrium. It is typically heard best at the apex and radiates to the axilla.

Type

Cause

Features of Murmur

Associated Symptoms

Mitral Regurgitation (MR)

Incomplete closure of the mitral valve, causing backflow from LV to LA.
  • Type: Pansystolic murmur.
  • Location: Best heard at the apex, radiates to the axilla.
  • Intensity: Grade II-IV, soft/absent S1 in chronic cases.

Dyspnea, fatigue, orthopnea, atrial fibrillation.

Aortic Regurgitation (AR) (Option B)

Incomplete closure of the aortic valve, causing retrograde flow into LV.
  • Type: Diastolic decrescendo murmur.
  • Location: Best heard at left sternal border (3rd-4th ICS).
  • Features: High-pitched, decrescendo.

Bounding pulses, wide pulse pressure, Water-Hammer pulse, heart failure symptoms.

Aortic Stenosis (AS) (Option C)

Narrowing of the aortic valve, obstructing LV outflow.
  • Type: Systolic ejection murmur.
  • Location: Best heard at right upper sternal border (2nd ICS), radiates to carotids.
  • Features: Crescendo-decrescendo.

Angina, syncope, left ventricular hypertrophy, paradoxical S2 splitting.

Mitral Stenosis (MS) (Option D)

Narrowing of the mitral valve, obstructing flow from LA to LV.
  • Type: Diastolic rumbling murmur.
  • Location: Best heard at apex in left lateral decubitus position.
  • Features: Low-pitched, with an opening snap after S2.

Dyspnea, pulmonary hypertension, right-sided heart failure, atrial fibrillation.

Heart Murmurs

Definition

Abnormal heart sounds caused by turbulent blood flow through valves or cardiac chambers.

Classification
  • Systolic Murmurs: Occur between S1 and S2 (e.g., MR, AS).
  • Diastolic Murmurs: Occur between S2 and S1 (e.g., MS, AR).
  • Continuous Murmurs: Occur throughout the cardiac cycle (e.g., PDA).

Clinical Assessment

Includes murmur timing, intensity, location, radiation, and associated cardiac or systemic features.

Grading System (Intensity)
  • Grade I: Barely audible.
  • Grade II: Soft but easily audible.
  • Grade III: Loud without thrill.
  • Grade IV: Loud with a palpable thrill.
  • Grade V: Very loud, audible with edge of stethoscope.
  • Grade VI: Audible without a stethoscope.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient came with complaints of chest pain, palpitation, and shortness of breath. On examination, a mid-diastolic murmur was heard, and a prominent 'a' wave was found on JVP. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Tricuspid stenosis

The combination of a mid-diastolic murmur and a prominent 'a' wave in the jugular venous pressure (JVP) suggests tricuspid stenosis (TS).

  • The mid-diastolic murmur, which can also occur in mitral stenosis, is best heard along the left sternal border and over the xiphoid process, increasing during inspiration due to enhanced venous return.
  • The prominent 'a' wave in JVP is a result of increased right atrial pressure, which impedes right atrial emptying during diastole, creating a giant 'a' wave.
  • ECG findings typically show right atrial enlargement, with tall, peaked P waves in leads II, III, and aVF.

Type

Cause

Features of Murmur

Associated Symptoms

JVP Findings

Aortic Regurgitation (AR)

Incomplete closure of the aortic valve, causing retrograde flow into LV.
  • Type: Diastolic decrescendo murmur.
  • Location: Best heard at left sternal border (3rd-4th ICS).
  • Features: High-pitched, decrescendo.
  • Bounding pulses
  • Wide pulse pressure
  • Water-Hammer pulse
  • Heart failure symptoms.

Normal or minimally elevated JVP unless associated with heart failure.

Aortic Stenosis (AS)

Narrowing of the aortic valve, obstructing LV outflow.
  • Type: Systolic ejection murmur.
  • Location: Best heard at right upper sternal border (2nd ICS), radiates to carotids.
  • Features: Crescendo-decrescendo.
  • Angina
  • Syncope
  • Left ventricular hypertrophy
  • Paradoxical S2 splitting.

Normal JVP unless severe.

Mitral Regurgitation (MR) (Option C)

Incomplete closure of the mitral valve, causing backflow from LV to LA.
  • Type: Pansystolic murmur.
  • Location: Best heard at the apex, radiates to the axilla.
  • Intensity: Grade II-IV, soft/absent S1 in chronic cases.
  • Dyspnea
  • Fatigue
  • Orthopnea
  • Atrial fibrillation.

Elevated JVP, prominent V wave due to regurgitant flow.

Mitral Stenosis (MS) (Option A)

Narrowing of the mitral valve, obstructing flow from LA to LV.
  • Type: Diastolic rumbling murmur.
  • Location: Best heard at apex in left lateral decubitus position.
  • Features: Low-pitched, with an opening snap after S2.
  • Dyspnea
  • Pulmonary hypertension
  • Right-sided heart failure
  • Atrial fibrillation.

Elevated JVP with prominent "a" wave due to increased atrial pressure.

Tricuspid Regurgitation (TR) (Option D)

Incomplete closure of the tricuspid valve, causing backflow into the right atrium.
  • Type: Pansystolic murmur.
  • Location: Best heard at the lower left sternal border.
  • Features: Holosystolic, blowing murmur.
  • Hepatomegaly
  • Ascites
  • Edema
  • Right-sided heart failure.

Elevated JVP with prominent "v" wave due to backflow into the right atrium.

Tricuspid Stenosis (TS)

Narrowing of the tricuspid valve, obstructing flow from RA to RV.
  • Type: Diastolic murmur.
  • Location: Best heard at the lower left sternal border.
  • Features: Low-pitched rumbling murmur.
  • Fatigue
  • Hepatomegaly
  • Ascites
  • Peripheral edema.

Elevated JVP with prominent "a" wave due to increased atrial pressure.

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of hypertension on multiple antihypertensive medications came to the OPD. His ECG finding is given below. Which of the following drugs is responsible for the ECG finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D) Spironolactone

  • The ECG finding of tall, peaked T waves suggests hyperkalemia. Among the listed medications, spironolactone is the drug most likely to cause hyperkalemia.

Mechanism of Spironolactone:

  • Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic. It works by blocking the mineralocorticoid receptor in the distal tubule and collecting duct of the kidneys, which inhibits sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion.
  • As a result, it promotes sodium diuresis but retains potassium, potentially leading to hyperkalemia.

ECG Changes in Hyperkalemia: Tall, peaked T waves are a classic ECG finding in hyperkalemia. As the potassium level rises, it affects the ST-T segments and can lead to changes in repolarization.

Serum Potassium Level (mEq/L)

ECG Changes

5.5–6.5

Tall, peaked T waves

6.5–7.5

Loss of P waves

7.0–8.0

Widened QRS complex

> 8.0

Sine wave pattern

Prazosin (Option A): This is an alpha-1 antagonist used in the treatment of hypertension and does not commonly cause hyperkalemia.

Metoprolol (Option B): This is a beta-blocker used for hypertension and cardiovascular issues. It does not typically cause hyperkalemia.

Hydrochlorothiazide (Option C): This is a thiazide diuretic, which actually promotes potassium loss and would more likely cause hypokalemia rather than hyperkalemia.

questions.text: A patient presents with dyspnea and distended neck veins that increase on inspiration. There is no murmur. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A- Constrictive pericarditis

  • Constrictive pericarditis is characterized by inflammation and fibrosis of the pericardium leading to impaired cardiac filling. The diagnosis is supported by the presence of Kussmaul's sign (increased jugular venous distention during inspiration) and absence of murmur.
  • During inspiration, the rigid pericardium prevents normal cardiac expansion, causing exaggerated rise in venous pressure. The condition results from pericardial inflammation and fibrosis, which creates a restrictive envelope around the heart, limiting diastolic filling.

Constrictive Pericarditis:

Pathophysiology:

  • Progressive thickening, fibrosis, and calcification of the pericardium restrict heart filling.
  • Calcification can extend into the myocardium, impairing myocardial contraction.
  • Restricted ventricular filling leads to elevated atrial pressures, causing:
    • Atrial hypertrophy
    • Atrial dilation
    • Atrial fibrillation (common).
  • Primarily manifests as systemic venous congestion (lung congestion is rare).

Examination Findings:

Finding

Description

Elevated JVP with rapid y descent

Reflects rapid early diastolic filling of the right ventricle due to pressure gradient.

atigue

Caused by the heart’s inability to meet circulatory demands.

Rapid, low-volume pulse

Restricted filling limits stroke volume, weakening the pulse.

Pericardial knock

A loud early S3 from the thickened pericardium during diastolic filling.

Kussmaul’s sign

Paradoxical rise in JVP during inspiration.

Hepatomegaly

Liver enlargement due to increased venous pressure.

Ascites

Abdominal fluid accumulation due to systemic venous congestion.

Peripheral oedema

Swelling in the extremities from fluid retention.

Pulsus paradoxus

A fall in systolic BP (10mm Hg) during inspiration, potentially impalpable pulse.

Atrial fibrillation

Common due to atrial hypertrophy and dilation.

Aortic regurgitation (Option B) typically presents with a characteristic diastolic murmur, which is absent in this case. Additionally, aortic regurgitation does not cause increased neck vein distention with inspiration.

Tricuspid stenosis (Option C) presents with elevated jugular venous pressure, but also includes a diastolic murmur and does not demonstrate Kussmaul's sign. The jugular venous pressure in tricuspid stenosis remains constant or decreases with inspiration.

Pulmonary arterial hypertension (Option D) can cause increased jugular venous pressure but does not demonstrate Kussmaul's sign. While it can cause right-sided heart failure symptoms, the characteristic inspiratory increase in neck vein distention is not a typical feature.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs reduce mortality in a patient with heart failure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Metoprolol

  • The clinical evidence indicates that beta-blockers like metoprolol significantly reduce mortality in heart failure patients. Beta-blockers work by blocking the effects of chronic sympathetic activation in heart failure.
  • Metoprolol, specifically, has been proven to reduce the ill-effects of chronic sympathetic activation in heart failure, improve left ventricular function, reduce mortality and decrease hospitalizations. Metoprolol, along with ACE inhibitors, demonstrate mortality benefits in heart failure patients.

First-line drugs used in the treatment of Chronic CHF (mortality-reducing)

ARBs/ACE-inhibitors/ARNI
  • Either of these can be started as initial therapy.
  • ACE-inhibitors: Captopril, Enalapril
  • ARBs: Telmisartan, Olmesartan
  • ARNI: ARB+Neprilysin inhibitor - Valsartan-Sacubitril (most preferred 1st line drug)
  • ADR: Cough, angioedema

Beta-blockers
  • Cardioselective (2nd gen): Metoprolol, Bisoprolol
  • 3rd gen: Carvedilol (both α- & β- blocking action) - Best beta blocker for heart failure
  • ADR: Bradycardia, Hypotension

SGLT-2 Inhibitors
  • Dapagliflozin, Empagliflozin
  • ADR: UTI, Forunier gangrene, Euglycemic DKA

Aldosterone antagonists
  • Spironolactone
  • ADR: Gynaecomastia

Furosemide (Option B): While furosemide is commonly used in heart failure for symptom relief and fluid management, it has not been shown to reduce mortality in heart failure patients. It primarily helps manage congestion and improve symptoms but does not affect the underlying disease progression or survival.

Prazosin (Option C): Although prazosin is an alpha-blocker that can reduce afterload, clinical trials have not demonstrated mortality benefit in heart failure patients. In fact, alpha-blockers may increase the risk of heart failure worsening due to their vasodilatory effects and reflex sympathetic activation.

Torsemide (Option D): Similar to furosemide, torsemide is a loop diuretic that helps manage fluid overload and symptoms in heart failure but has not been proven to reduce mortality. While it may have better bioavailability than furosemide, neither medication has shown a survival benefit in clinical trials.

questions.text: A known case of lung cancer presents with breathing difficulty. On auscultation at the left infrascapular area bronchial breathing is heard with a dull percussion note. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
option a.

  • Dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds near the base of the left lung infra-scapular location are characteristic findings in cardiac tamponade.
  • Cardiac tamponade is a medical emergency that occurs when fluid accumulates in the pericardial space, compressing the heart and impairing its ability to pump blood effectively. As a result, patients with cardiac tamponade may present with symptoms such as shortness of breath, chest pain, tachycardia, and hypotension. Normal SBP falls < 10 mm Hg on deep inspiration if it falls  > 10 mmHg (in the case of cardiac tamponade) this is known as Pulsus paradoxus.
  • Beck's Triad
    • BP fall: Obstructive shock (IV fluid contraindicated)
    • JVP: Elevated, non-pulsatile, Kussmaul sign is absent
    • S1S2 muffled/distant

 

Incorrect Choices:

b. Chronic constrictive pericarditis involves the chronic inflammation and fibrosis of the pericardium, leading to the thickening and stiffening of the pericardial sac. Patients with chronic constrictive pericarditis may present with symptoms such as dyspnea, fatigue, and peripheral edema. However, they are unlikely to have dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds near the base of the left lung infra-scapular location.

c. Pulmonary embolism is a blockage of one or more pulmonary arteries by a blood clot, which can lead to symptoms such as dyspnea, chest pain, and tachycardia. However, patients with pulmonary embolism are more likely to have findings such as tachypnea, pleuritic chest pain, and clear breath sounds on auscultation.

d: Left-sided pleural effusion involves fluid accumulation in the pleural space on the left side of the chest, leading to symptoms such as dyspnea and chest pain. However, dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds are more commonly observed at the base of the affected lung, regardless of the location.

questions.text: Identify the conduction abnormality from the ECG given below?
questions.solution:
Given ECG shows progressive lengthening of PR intervals until a dropped beat occurs, which indicates Mobitz type I block. It can be further classified into two types:

  • Mobitz Type I (Wenckebach) - is characterized by a progressive prolongation of the PR interval until a beat is dropped
  • Mobitz Type II - involves intermittent blocked beats without progressive PR interval prolongation.

 

First-degree heart block (Option A) is characterized by a prolonged PR interval on the ECG. It indicates a delay in the electrical conduction between the atria and ventricles.

 

Ventricular tachycardia (Option B) is a rapid heart rhythm originating from the ventricles. On the ECG, it appears as a wide QRS complex with a heart rate exceeding 100 beats per minute.


Third-degree heart block (complete heart block) (Option C) is a severe conduction abnormality characterised by atrioventricular dissociation.

questions.text: Which of the following would not be indicated by the absence of loud S1 in mitral stenosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (Option B)

Aortic regurgitation is unrelated to the production of the first heart sound (S1). Aortic regurgitation involves the leakage of blood back into the left ventricle during diastole, and it does not directly affect the closure of the mitral valve or the production of S1. Therefore, the absence of a loud S1 sound is not indicative of aortic regurgitation.

 

A calcified valve (Option A) in mitral stenosis can restrict the movement of the valve leaflets and result in a reduced or absent opening snap (OS), leading to a softer S1 sound. Therefore, the absence of a loud S1 sound is consistent with a calcified valve in mitral stenosis.

 

The intensity of the first heart sound (S1) is decreased in patients with first-degree heart block (Option C). Therefore, the absence of loud S1 is consistent with first degree heart block.

 

In mitral stenosis (Option D), the presence of a loud first heart sound (S1) is a characteristic finding. Therefore, the absence of a loud S1 sound would be inconsistent with mitral stenosis. A loud S1 is produced by mobile but stiff mitral leaflets unless the leaflets are substantially calcified. Since elevated left atrial pressure has maintained the leaflets' rather wide spacing, the loud S1 is mostly caused by increased leaflet excursion during closure.

questions.text: Which of the following is the initial treatment of choice for managing the condition in a female patient who comes to the hospital with palpitations, having stable vital signs and an ECG showing the following?
questions.solution:
Adenosine is the first-line management of the presented condition. The ECG pattern shown suggests Paroxysmal SupraVentricular Tachycardia (PSVT), a common arrhythmia characterized by rapid heart rates originating above the ventricles. Adenosine is a potent vasodilator and affects the electrical conduction system of the heart. It activates specific receptors in the heart, particularly the adenosine A1 receptors, which help to slow down the conduction through the AV node. This interruption of the abnormal electrical pathway in SVT can restore normal sinus rhythm.

 

Paroxysmal Supraventricular Tachycardia (PSVT):

  1. Signs and Symptoms:
    • Sudden onset of rapid, regular palpitations
    • Dizziness or lightheadedness
    • Shortness of breath
    • Chest discomfort or pressure
    • Anxiety
    • Fatigue
    • In severe cases: syncope, hypotension, or heart failure symptoms
  2. ECG Findings:
    • Regular, narrow-complex tachycardia (QRS duration <120 ms)
    • Reduced R-R interval
    • Heart rate between 150-250 bpm
    • P waves often not visible or buried in T waves

 

  • Common types include:
    • a) AV Nodal Reentrant Tachycardia (AVNRT): Retrograde P waves may appear as pseudo R' in V1 or pseudo S in inferior leads
    • b) AV Reentrant Tachycardia (AVRT): Retrograde P waves may be visible after the QRS complex

 

  1. Management:

Acute termination:
  • Vagal maneuvers (e.g., Valsalva, carotid sinus massage)
  • If vagal maneuvers fail, IV adenosine is the first-line pharmacological treatment: 6 mg - 12mg fast iv push.
  • Alternative drugs: verapamil, diltiazem, or beta-blockers
  • Synchronized cardioversion for hemodynamically unstable patients

Long-term management:
  • Catheter ablation: Often curative, especially for AVNRT and AVRT
  • Pharmacological therapy:
    • Beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers for prevention
    • Class IC or III antiarrhythmic drugs in selected cases
  • Patient education on performing vagal maneuvers

Lifestyle modifications
  • Avoid triggers (e.g., caffeine, alcohol, stress)
  • Regular exercise
  • Adequate sleep

 

Amiodarone (Option A) is used to treat Stable Monomorphic Ventricular tachycardia.

 

DC Cardioversion (Option C) is used to treat Atrial flutter, Atrial fibrillatio.n

 

Primary PCI (Option D) is used to treat acute myocardial infarctio.n

questions.text: A patient with heart disease has breathlessness when going to the bathroom. What grade does he belong to?
questions.solution:
NYHA 3 indicates moderate symptoms. Patients classified as NYHA 3 experience symptoms such as marked limitation of physical activity, becoming symptomatic with less than ordinary activity (such as going to the bathroom) and having no symptoms at rest. NYHA functional classification assesses the impact of heart disease on a patient's daily activities.

 

NYHA 4 (Option B) indicates severe symptoms. Patients classified as NYHA 4 experience symptoms even at rest and are unable to carry out any physical activity without discomfort.

 

The mMRC (Option C) dyspnea scale is used to assess dyspnea (shortness of breath) in patients with respiratory conditions. mMRC 4 indicates severe dyspnea, where patients become too breathless to leave the house or experience significant discomfort even while at rest.

 

mMRC 5 (Option D) is not a standard category in the MMRC dyspnea scale. The scale typically ranges from 0 to 4, with 0 indicating no dyspnea and 4 indicating the most severe dyspnea.

questions.text: Based on the ECG given below, which of the following is not used in the management of the condition?
questions.solution:
ECG is suggestive of atrial fibrillation as there is an irregularly irregular rhythm and absent P waves with narrow QRS complexes are present.

In atrial fibrillation, synchronised DC shock/cardioversion can be used. Nonsynchronised DC shock (Defibrillation) is not used in the management of these patients.

Verapamil (Option A) can be used in the management of patients with atrial fibrillation.


Metoprolol (Option B) can be used in the management of patients with atrial fibrillation.


Amiodarone (Option C) can be used in the management of patients with atrial fibrillation.

questions.text: Which of the following foods is not included in the DASH diet?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Rich in sodium

Explanation:

  • The DASH diet (Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension) recommends limiting the intake of sodium, as high sodium consumption is associated with increased blood pressure. The DASH diet suggests reducing the use of table salt and avoiding processed foods that are typically high in sodium, such as fast food, canned soups, and salty snacks.

DASH-type dietary plan:

  • A diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and low-fat dairy products with reduced saturated and total fat content.
  • Diet is also rich in potassium (Option A), calcium (Option B), and magnesium (Option D).

DASH Diet

  • Originated in the 1990s through NIH-funded research, found to lower systolic BP by 6-11 mm Hg. It promotes fruits, vegetables, lean meats, and low sodium (~1500 mg/day) and encourages fresh, minimally processed food.

Key Nutrients in DASH diet:

  • Carbohydrates: Whole grains, legumes, leafy greens.
  • Fats: Healthy fats (olive oil, nuts, omega-3 fish), avoid trans fats.
  • Proteins: Plant-based proteins preferred, lean meats, low-fat dairy.
  • Electrolytes:
    • Potassium: Helps lower BP, prevents muscle cramps, and supports heart function. Sources: bananas, oranges, spinach, beans.
    • Sodium: DASH limits sodium to ~1500 mg/day to reduce hypertension risk.
    • Calcium: Essential for bone health and muscle function. Sources: dairy, leafy greens.
    • Magnesium: Aids blood vessel relaxation and BP control. Sources: whole grains, nuts, seeds.

Clinical Significance of DASH diet:

  • Lowers BP, blood glucose, LDL, triglycerides, and insulin resistance.
  • Helps with metabolic syndrome, diabetes, and heart failure.
  • Linked to reduced risk of colorectal cancer, liver disease, and celiac disease.
  • Reduces hospitalization and mortality in heart failure patients.
  • Meets ADA recommendations for diabetes management.

questions.text: A patient has presented with features of cardiac tamponade. Which of the following is correct regarding this condition?

choices.text: Jugular veins column is visibly distended without pulsations

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Jugular veins column is visibly distended without pulsations

Explanation:

  • Cardiac tamponade refers to the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial sac, which puts pressure on the heart and impairs its ability to pump effectively. Jugular veins column distending without pulsations is a characteristic finding in cardiac tamponade. Due to the increased pressure in the pericardial sac, the jugular veins become visibly distended, but the normal pulsations with each heartbeat are diminished or absent.

Cardiac Tamponade

Definition

A condition where the cardiac chambers are compressed by a tense pericardial effusion, limiting cardiac inflow. Fluid accumulation of as little as 200 ml to upwards of 2L may lead to cardiac tamponade development.

Beck's triad
  • Jugular Venous Distension: Due to increased central venous pressure. Prominent x descent and an absent y descent.
  • Hypotension: Resulting from impaired cardiac output.
  • Muffled Heart Sounds: Caused by fluid accumulation in the pericardial space, dampening heart sounds.

Other Clinical features

Pulsus Paradoxus: A drop in systolic BP during inspiration, greater than 10 mm Hg. It is present in most of the conditions but not always(Option A) and can vary depending on the severity of tamponade and other factors.

Causes of Pulsus paradoxus:

  • Lung Conditions: Acute asthma, COPD, tension pneumothorax, pleural effusion, pulmonary embolism.
  • Heart Conditions: Cardiac tamponade, constrictive pericarditis.

 

Kussmaul sign refers to an abnormal rise in jugular venous pressure during inspiration. It is not specific to cardiac tamponade (Option B) and can be seen in various cardiac and respiratory conditions. It is not always present in cardiac tamponade.

The A wave represents atrial contraction on the jugular venous pulse waveform. In cardiac tamponade, the elevated pressure in the pericardial sac can impair atrial filling, leading to a reduced or absent A wave rather than a tall A wave (Option C).

questions.text: What is the clinical diagnosis for a young male who has no symptoms but is found to have a wide fixed split S2 during auscultation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) ASD

Explanation:

  • A wide fixed split S2 on auscultation is a characteristic finding in atrial septal defects (ASD), where there is abnormal communication between the atria. It allows increased blood flow from the left atrium to the right atrium, causing a delay in the closure of the pulmonic valve, resulting in a wide fixed split S2.

Types of S2 split

Conditions causing split

Narrow split S2
  • Mild Left Ventricular Failure
  • Early Aortic Stenosis

wide split fixed S2

  • Atrial Septal Defect (ASD)

Wide split variable S2

  • Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD)
  • Right Bundle Branch Block (RBBB)

Paradoxical split S2
  • Left Bundle Branch Block
  • Severe Aortic Stenosis

Atrial Septal Defect:

  • Congenital, low-pressure, left to right shunt.
  • The right ventricle will have volume overloading.
  • Types of ASD: Ostium Secundum (most common), Ostium Primum, Sinus Venosus
  • On auscultation: Wide fixed split S2 sound
  • Chest x-ray: May show enlarged right atrial and right ventricular enlargement and increased pulmonary markings
  • Transthoracic echocardiogram: Gold standard imaging modality, helps to detect size and assess the direction of blood flow.

 

A ventricular septal defect (Option A) is another type of congenital heart defect where there is an abnormal opening in the septum between the two ventricles. It typically produces a harsh holosystolic murmur, rather than a wide fixed split S2 heard on auscultation.

Tetralogy of Fallot (Option C) is a congenital heart condition characterized by a combination of four heart defects: ventricular septal defect, pulmonary stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, and overriding aorta. The characteristic murmur in TOF is a systolic ejection murmur and not specifically associated with a wide fixed split S2.

Bicuspid Aortic Valve (Option D) can be associated with aortic stenosis or regurgitation, it is not specifically associated with a wide fixed split S2.

questions.text: Which of the following is not done in W.P.W?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Treadmill test

Explanation:

  • Treadmill test is not done in Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome because it does not reliably induce arrhythmias and may produce false-positive ST-segment changes, mimicking ischemia.

Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) Syndrome:

WPW Syndrome

Most common type of ventricular preexcitation syndrome, characterized by preexcited QRS during sinus rhythm and episodes of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT).

Mechanism

Abnormal conduction pathway from atria to the ventricle (Bundle of Kent) bypasses the rate-slowing AV node, causing partial early ventricular depolarisation.

ECG Findings

Delta wave with widened QRS complex and shortened PR interval.

Clinical Consequence

May lead to a reentry circuit, causing paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT).

 

Electrophysiological studies (Option B): Used to assess conduction properties and locate the accessory pathway in WPW syndrome. It is particularly useful in risk stratification and guiding catheter ablation.

Oral beta blocker (Option C): AV nodal blocking agents, including beta-blockers, may be reasonable only in the setting of orthodromic AVRT or WPW pattern on ECG. However, they are contraindicated in WPW with atrial fibrillation, as they can promote conduction through the accessory pathway, leading to ventricular fibrillation.

Procainamide (Option D) is the pharmacologic treatment of choice for antidromic atrioventricular reentrant tachycardia (AVRT) and atrial fibrillation with preexcitation, as it blocks conduction through the accessory pathway. It is also an accepted treatment for conversion of tachycardia in WPW.

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about Defibrillation?

choices.text: Only be used by a trained person
Decrease in success rate with delay in initiation

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 1 minute gap between 2 shocks

Explanation:

  • A 1-minute gap between 2 shocks is incorrect, as defibrillation should be delivered without delay to maximize the chances of successful resuscitation.

Defibrillation:

  • Indications:
    • Ventricular fibrillation (VF)
    • Pulseless ventricular tachycardia (VT)
  • Personnel Involved: Defibrillation is typically performed by medical personnel trained in Advanced Cardiac Life Support (ACLS) or Pediatric Advanced Life Support (PALS). (Option A)
  • Preparation:
    • Resuscitation (CPR) continues while preparing the defibrillator.
    • Once available, the defibrillator should be used immediately, taking precedence over other measures.
  • Defibrillation Technique:
    • Manual defibrillator paddles or hands-free defibrillator pads are placed on the chest (right sternal border and cardiac apex, or in anteroposterior configuration).
    • The defibrillator is charged and set to the manufacturer’s recommended initial energy level (120-200 joules for biphasic defibrillators, 360 joules for monophasic).
    • A shock is delivered after confirming no one is in contact with the patient.
  • Post-Defibrillation:
    • CPR is resumed immediately for 2 minutes after the shock.
    • The pulse and rhythm are checked to assess if VF or pulseless VT has been terminated.
    • If VF or VT persists, defibrillation is repeated, with increasing energy as per guidelines.
  • Medications During Resuscitation:
    • Epinephrine (1 mg IV every 3-5 minutes) should be given after the first unsuccessful shock.
    • Amiodarone (300 mg IV bolus) may be administered if VT or VF persists, with additional doses (150 mg) as needed.
    • Lidocaine can be used in place of amiodarone in some cases, but epinephrine and amiodarone are preferred.
  • Clinical Significance: Early defibrillation increases the chances of survival in VF. After 10 minutes of VF, the chances of successful resuscitation decrease significantly. (Option B & C)
  • Contraindications: There are no contraindications for defibrillation in the presence of VF or pulseless VT.

questions.text: Modified duke criteria are used for diagnosis of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Infective endocarditis

Explanation:

  • Modified duke criteria are used for diagnosis of infective endocarditis.

Modified Duke Criteria (2023 update):

I. Definite Endocarditis:

A. Pathologic Criteria

1. Microorganisms identified in the context of clinical signs of active endocarditis in a vegetation from cardiac tissue; from explanted prosthetic valve or sewing ring; from ascending aortic graft (with concomitant evidence of valve involvement); from an endovascular intra cardiac implantable electronic device (CIED) or from an arterial embolus OR

2. Active endocarditis in the same above mentioned locations.

  • Microorganisms identified in appropriate sample by PCR, amplicon or metagenomic sequencing, or in situ hybridization

B. Clinical Criteria (mentioned below)

1. 2 Major Criteria OR

2. 1 Major and 3 Minor Criteria OR

3. 5 Minor Criteria

II. Possible Endocarditis:

A. 1 Major Criterion and 1 Minor Criterion OR

B. 3 Minor Criteria

III. Rejected Endocarditis:

A. Firm alternate diagnosis explaining signs/symptoms OR

B. Lack of recurrence despite antibiotic therapy for only < 4 days OR

C. No pathologic/macroscopic evidence of IE at surgery or autopsy with antibiotic therapy for less than 4 days OR

D. Does not meet criteria of possible IE

 

Clinical Criteria

I. Major Criteria

A. Microbiologic Major Criteria

(i) Positive blood cultures

Microorganisms that commonly cause IE isolated from 2 or more separate blood culture sets

OR

Microorganisms that occasionally or rarely cause IE isolated from 3 or more separate blood culture sets

(ii) Positive laboratory tests

Positive polymerase chain reaction (PCR) or other nucleic acid-based technique for Coxiella burnetii, Bartonella species, or Tropheryma whipplei from blood

OR

Coxiella burnetii antiphase I immunoglobulin G (IgG) antibody titer > 1:800 or isolated from a single blood culture

OR

Indirect immunofluorescence assays (IFA) for IgM and IgG antibodies to Bartonella henselae or Bartonella quintana with IgG titer ≥ 1:800

B. Imaging Major Criteria

(i) Echocardiography and cardiac computed tomography (CT) imaging

Echocardiography and cardiac CT showing vegetation, valve/leaflet perforation, valve/leaflet aneurysm, abscess, pseudoaneurysm, or intracardiac fistula

OR

Significant new valvular regurgitation on echocardiography as compared with previous imaging.

Worsening or changing of preexisting regurgitation is not sufficient

OR

New partial dehiscence of prosthetic valve as compared with previous imaging.

(ii) 18F-FDG PET/CT imaging

Abnormal metabolic activity involving a native or prosthetic valve, ascending aortic graft (with concomitant evidence of valve involvement), intracardiac device leads, or other prosthetic material

C. Surgical Major Criteria

Evidence of IE documented by direct inspection during heart surgery neither Major Imaging Criteria nor subsequent histologic or microbiologic confirmation

II. MINOR CRITERIA

A. Predisposition
  • Previous history of IE
  • Prosthetic valve
  • Previous valve repair
  • Congenital heart disease
  • More than mild regurgitation or stenosis of any etiology
  • Endovascular intracardiac implantable electronic device (CIED)
  • Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy
  • Intravenous drug use

B. Fever

Temperature greater than 38.0°C

C. Vascular Phenomena

Clinical or radiological evidence of arterial emboli, septic pulmonary infarcts, cerebral or splenic abscess, mycotic aneurysm, intracranial hemorrhage, conjunctival hemorrhages, Janeway lesions, purulent pericardium

D. Immunologic Phenomena

Positive rheumatoid factor, Osler nodes, Roth spots, or immune complex-mediated glomerulonephritis

E. Microbiologic Evidence (Falling Short of Major Criterion)

Positive blood cultures for a microorganism consistent with IE but not meeting the requirements for Major Criterion

OR

Positive culture, PCR, or other nucleic acid-based test (amplicon or shotgun sequencing, in situ hybridization) for organisms consistent with IE from a sterile body site other than cardiac tissue, cardiac prosthesis, or arterial embolus

F. Imaging Criteria

Abnormal 18F-FDG PET/CT within 3 months of implantation of prosthetic valve

G. Physical Examination Criteria

New valvular regurgitation identified on auscultation if echocardiography is not available.

questions.text: Which of the following indicators shall be seen with use of a small-sized BP cuff?

choices.text: Cancels the effects of calcified arteries

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) False elevation of BP

Explanation:

  • False elevation of BP is observed when using a small-sized blood pressure cuff.

Errors in Blood Pressure Measurement Due to Improper Cuff Size:

  • Cuff Too Narrow:
    • Overestimates blood pressure.
    • Applies excessive pressure to a smaller area, leading to falsely high readings.
  • Cuff Too Wide:
    • Underestimates blood pressure. (Option B)
    • Distributes pressure over a larger area, resulting in falsely low readings.
  • Importance of Proper Cuff Size:
    • Ensures accurate blood pressure measurement.
    • Avoids misdiagnosis of hypertension or hypotension.

 

Cancels the effects of calcified arteries (Option C): A small-sized BP cuff does not negate the effects of calcified arteries. While arterial calcification can lead to inaccurate BP measurements, using the correct cuff size is essential for obtaining accurate readings.

Increases trans-arm impedance (Option C): A small-sized BP cuff does not directly increase trans-arm impedance. Trans-arm impedance refers to resistance encountered in certain BP measurement techniques, but it is not specifically affected by cuff size.

questions.text: Elderly male patient has presented with recurrent falls. Which of the following medicines is responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Prazocin

Explanation:

  • Prazosin is an alpha-1 adrenergic antagonist that can cause orthostatic hypotension and syncope, leading to an increased risk of falls, particularly in elderly patients.

Prazosin:

  • Quinazoline derivative that acts as competitive alpha-1 adrenergic receptor antagonist
  • Mechanism of Action:
    • Alpha-1 adrenergic receptor antagonist
    • Smooth muscle relaxation → ↓ systemic vascular resistance → ↓ blood pressure
    • Affects various tissues (blood vessels, prostate, urethra, iris dilator muscle, brain)
    • Crosses the blood-brain barrier → contributes to cognitive effects (basis for PTSD use)
  • Metabolism: Hepatic (via CYP450 enzymes)
  • Half-life: ~2.5 hours (prolonged in chronic renal failure and congestive heart failure)
  • Uses:
    • FDA-approved Indication: Hypertension (alone or in combination with other antihypertensives) but not a first-line agent.
    • Non-FDA-approved Indication:
      • Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH)
      • Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD)-associated nightmares
      • Raynaud phenomenon
      • Pheochromocytoma
      • Scorpion envenomation
  • Adverse Effects:
    • Serious Adverse Effects:
      • First-dose hypotension (recommend initial dose at bedtime)
      • Orthostatic hypotension
      • Syncope
      • Intraoperative Floppy Iris Syndrome (IFIS)
      • Priapism
    • Common Adverse Effects:
      • Dizziness
      • Headache
      • Drowsiness
      • Lack of energy
      • Weakness
      • Palpitations
      • Nausea

 

Metformin (Option B) is used for managing type 2 diabetes. While it may cause gastrointestinal side effects like nausea and diarrhea, it does not directly contribute to falls.

Acarbose (Option C) is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor used to manage diabetes by delaying carbohydrate absorption. It can cause gastrointestinal issues but does not lead to falls.

Thiazide (Option D) diuretics can sometimes cause orthostatic hypotension, especially in elderly patients, but this side effect is less common and less pronounced compared to prazosin, which is more strongly associated with orthostatic hypotension and falls.

questions.text: What is the waist to hip ratio that is associated with an increased risk of heart disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) > 0.85 in females

Explanation:

  • The waist to hip ratio that is associated with an increased risk of heart disease is > 0.85 in females.

Waist-to-Hip Ratio:

  • Waist-to-hip ratio is a more accurate measure of obesity-related cardiovascular risk than BMI, with specific cut-offs of 0.83 for women and 0.9 for men significantly increasing the risk for myocardial infarction.
  • Physicians should prioritize measuring waist-to-hip ratio, along with waist circumference, to assess cardiovascular risk, particularly in specific ethnic groups.
  • Reducing abdominal obesity and increasing hip circumference, potentially through muscle mass development, may reduce cardiovascular risk.

questions.text: Best management of a hemodynamically stable patient with ECG showing Broad QRS complex with antidromic tachycardia is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Intravenous Procainamide

Explanation:

  • Intravenous procainamide is the best management for a hemodynamically stable patient with broad QRS complex antidromic tachycardia, as it terminates the arrhythmia by slowing conduction through the accessory pathway.

Atrioventricular Reentrant Tachycardia (AVRT):

  • AVRT is a type of supraventricular tachycardia that occurs in patients with an accessory pathway, such as in Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome.
  • Pathology:
    • AVRT involves a reentrant circuit that includes the normal AV conduction system and the accessory pathway.
    • Two types exist:
      • Orthodromic AVRT (more common): Conduction travels down the AV node and up the accessory pathway.
      • Antidromic AVRT (less common): Conduction travels down the accessory pathway and up the AV node.

  • ECG Features:
    • Orthodromic AVRT:
      • Narrow QRS complex tachycardia (QRS < 120 ms)
      • Regular rhythm with heart rates typically 150-250 bpm
      • Retrograde P waves often visible in the ST segment or early T wave
    • Antidromic AVRT:
      • Wide QRS complex tachycardia (QRS > 120 ms)
      • Regular rhythm with heart rates typically 170-240 bpm
      • Retrograde P waves may be obscured by the wide QRS

  • AVRT can be initiated by premature atrial or ventricular complexes that block one pathway and conduct through the other, setting up the reentrant circuit.
  • Management:
    • Acute Termination of Orthodromic AVRT:
      • Stable patients: Start with vagal maneuvers (Valsalva or carotid sinus massage).
      • If unsuccessful: IV adenosine (first-line pharmacologic treatment), IV verapamil, IV procainamide or IV beta-blockers.
    • Acute Termination of Antidromic AVRT:
      • If confirmed, avoid AV nodal blockers (adenosine, beta-blockers, verapamil, digoxin). (Option A & B)
      • IV procainamide is the preferred treatment.

 

Cardioversion (Option D): Reserved for hemodynamically unstable patients; unnecessary in a stable patient where pharmacologic management with IV procainamide is effective.

questions.text:
What is the diagnosis for a 23-year-old female who has been experiencing fever for the past week and displays the following rhythm on the monitor?


{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Atrial fibrillation

Explanation:

  • The given image shows Atrial fibrillation
  • Atrial fibrillation is a cardiac rhythm disorder characterized by rapid, irregular electrical impulses in the atria.
  • This results in a rapid and irregular ventricular response, leading to an irregular heart rate on the monitor.

 

Atrial flutter (Option B): typically appears as a regular, sawtooth pattern on the monitor, rather than the irregular pattern seen in this case.

 

Supraventricular tachyarrhythmia (Option C):

  • is a broad term that encompasses various rapid heart rhythms originating from above the ventricles.
  • It includes conditions like atrial fibrillation, atrial flutter, and other supraventricular tachycardias. While atrial fibrillation is a type of supraventricular tachyarrhythmia, it is more specific than the general term used in this option.

 

Ventricular tachyarrhythmia (Option D): refers to abnormal rapid rhythms that originate in the ventricles. This rhythm disorder is characterized by a wide QRS complex on the monitor, unlike the narrow QRS complex typically seen in atrial fibrillation.

questions.text: An intern observed that a patient in the ward was unresponsive, and an ECG which was performed urgently showed a rhythm as depicted below. DC shock was delivered but the arrhythmia persisted and the patient is still unresponsive. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Start CPR

Explanation:

The next best step in the management of an unresponsive patient with the displayed ECG rhythm, despite the delivery of a DC shock, is to start CPR (Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation).

 

The ECG rhythm depicted suggests ventricular fibrillation (VF), which is a life-threatening arrhythmia characterized by rapid, irregular, and disorganized electrical activity of the ventricles.

 

Ventricular fibrillation results in ineffective pumping of the heart, leading to a lack of blood flow to vital organs and tissues. This can result in a sudden loss of consciousness, cessation of pulse, and, if not promptly treated, irreversible brain damage or death within minutes.and ultimately cardiac arrest.

 

Ventricular fibrillation (VF) is a serious and life-threatening abnormal heart rhythm that occurs when the electrical signals controlling the heart's contractions become chaotic. Instead of a coordinated contraction, the ventricles (the lower chambers of the heart) quiver or fibrillate, leading to ineffective pumping and a significant decrease in blood flow.

 

Ventricular Fibrillation

 

 

Ventricular Tachycardia

 

Management of Shockable (VT/ V Fib) Conditions:

Immediate Recognition

Identify Shockable Rhythm: Recognize VF or pulseless VT.

Activate Emergency Response: Call for advanced life support.

↓

Initiate CPR

Start High-Quality CPR: Perform chest compressions at a rate of 100-120/min, with a depth of 5-6 cm. Continue CPR for 2 minutes.

↓

Defibrillation

After 2 minutes of CPR, deliver a Non-Synchronized DC Shock to restore normal rhythm.

If no change, administer a second shock immediately.

↓

Continue CPR

Resume CPR for 2 Minutes

Place an intravenous or intraosseous line for drug administration.

↓

Administer Epinephrine

Epinephrine 1 mg (1:10,000): Given IV/IO after 2 minutes of CPR to enhance coronary perfusion pressure.

↓

Advanced Airway Management

Secure Airway: Perform endotracheal intubation if necessary.

Capnography: Monitor end-tidal CO2 levels.

Ventilation: Provide 1 breath every 6 seconds post-intubation.

↓

Further Defibrillation

Third Shock: If VF or pulseless VT persists, deliver a third non-synchronized shock.

Continue CPR for 2 More Minutes: Follow with additional CPR.

↓

Administer Antiarrhythmic Medication

Amiodarone 300 mg IV: Administer for shock-refractory VT to stabilize heart rhythm.

↓

Identify and Treat Reversible Causes

 

While synchronized cardioversion (Option A) is a potential treatment for certain arrhythmias, such as supraventricular tachycardia or atrial fibrillation, it is not appropriate for ventricular fibrillation.

Ventricular fibrillation requires immediate CPR followed by defibrillation (DC shock) (Option C) as the initial treatment. Since the patient has already received a DC shock without conversion of the rhythm, repeating the shock without CPR in between is unlikely to be effective.

Administering 1 mg of epinephrine (Option D) is a component of advanced cardiac life support and is typically given during CPR after a shock has been delivered. However, starting CPR should take priority over administering epinephrine.

questions.text: Pulsus paradoxus is seen in:

choices.text: Severe Asthma or Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Severe Asthma or Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease

Explanation:

  • Pulsus paradoxus is an ominous sign in a patient with obstructive lung disease, as it is associated with significant negative intrathoracic (pleural) pressures, affecting venous return to the heart and causing a drop in systolic blood pressure during inspiration. During severe asthma attacks or exacerbations of COPD, airway resistance increases significantly during inspiration and significant rise in negative intrathoracic pressure.

Pulsus Paradoxus

Definition:

A fall in systolic blood pressure >10 mmHg during inspiration.

Pathophysiology:

Exaggerated interventricular dependence → Increased right ventricular filling during inspiration shifts the septum leftward, reducing left ventricular output and causing a more pronounced drop in systolic pressure.

Associated Conditions:
  • Pericardial tamponade (classic association)
    • External pressure on the heart limits filling
    • Inspiration compresses the RV, preventing normal inspiratory RV filling
    • Interventricular septum shifts left, restricting LV filling and output → Marked fall in BP
  • Massive pulmonary embolism
  • Hemorrhagic shock
  • Severe obstructive lung disease (e.g., asthma, COPD)
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Effusive Constrictive Pericarditis
  • Restrictive Cardiomyopathy

Measurement:

 
  • Auscultatory method:
    • Identify the systolic pressure during expiration and independent of respiration.
    • The difference between these two is the pulsus paradoxus.
    • If the difference exceeds 15 mmHg, pulsus paradoxus may be palpable at the brachial or femoral artery.
  • Tachycardia, atrial fibrillation, tachypnea will make it difficult to measure.

Respiratory Changes in Cardiac Output, Blood Pressure, and Pulse Rate:

  • Physiological Changes with Respiration:
    • Inspiration:
      • ↓ Intrathoracic pressure → ↑ Venous return to the right heart
      • ↑ Right ventricular (RV) output
      • ↑ Pulmonary vascular capacitance → Blood is sequestered in the lungs, reducing flow to the left heart
      • ↓ Left ventricular (LV) output → ↓ Blood pressure (BP)
    • Expiration:
      • ↓ Venous return to the right heart → ↓ RV output
      • ↑ Venous return to the left heart → ↑ LV output → ↑ BP

questions.text: A 64-year-old man presents with complaints of palpitations and syncope. He has a history of inferior-wall myocardial infarction a year ago. Holter study was done and his 24 hour ECG strip obtained is given below. What is the long-term treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer : C) Permanent pacemaker

Explanation:

  • The 24-hour ECG strip suggests the presence of sinus node dysfunction (sick sinus syndrome) characterized by bradycardia (slow heart rate), pauses, and sinus arrests. This condition is commonly seen in individuals who have had a previous myocardial infarction. Long-term treatment for this would be a "Permanent pacemaker."

Sinus bradycardia

Definition

Sinus bradycardia is a cardiac rhythm with normal sinus node depolarization but a rate < 60 bpm.

Diagnostic Criteria

ECG showing sinus rhythm at a rate lower than 60 bpm.

Common Etiologies
  • Normal in athletes
  • Medications (beta-blockers, calcium channel blockers, digoxin)
  • Hypothyroidism, hypothermia
  • Sick sinus syndrome, myocardial infarction
  • Vagal stimulation (e.g., vasovagal syncope)

Clinical Features
  • Asymptomatic (in many patients)
  • Fatigue
  • Dizziness or lightheadedness
  • Exercise intolerance
  • Syncope or presyncope
  • Cognitive slowing
  • Worsening angina or heart failure symptoms

Evaluation
  • Assess hemodynamic stability
  • ECG to confirm sinus rhythm
  • Review medication list for bradycardic agents
  • Evaluate for comorbidities (e.g., hypothyroidism, myocardial infarction)

Management
  • If Hemodynamically Unstable:
    • IV atropine 0.5 mg every 3-5 minutes (max 3 mg)
    • If there is no improvement, consider a temporary pacemaker
  • If Stable, for long term mamagement:
    • Treat underlying causes
    • Withdraw bradycardia-inducing medications
    • Permanent pacemaker

 

Amiodarone (Option A) is an antiarrhythmic medication used to treat various cardiac arrhythmias. However, it is not the primary treatment for sinus node dysfunction.

Atropine only (Option B) is a medication used for acute management of symptomatic bradycardia. It is used only in emergency situations or as a temporary measure before definitive treatment such as a pacemaker is implemented.

Isoproterenol is a medication that acts as a cardiac stimulant and can increase heart rate. While it may be used in certain acute situations, it is not an appropriate long-term treatment for sinus node dysfunction. Additionally, combining atropine and isoproterenol (Option D) is not a typical approach for managing this condition.

questions.text: A 5 year old child has flexible fingers and can even touch the back of his hand with his wrist extended. The child also demonstrates the sign shown in the image below. On auscultation, a click is heard after S1, followed by a late systolic murmur. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ehlers-Danlos syndrome

Explanation:

  • Hypermobility of joint, the ability to touch the back of the hand with the wrist extended, tongue to nose sign (Gorlin’s sign) and auscultatory findings of mitral valve prolapse suggests that this could be Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS) which is a genetic disorders that affects the connective tissues and shows various systemic manifestations, primarily involving the skin, joints, and blood vessels.

Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome (EDS):

  • Genetically heterogeneous connective tissue disorders
  • Common features:
    • Skin: Soft, hyperextensible, fragile, slow healing, atrophic scars
    • Joints: Hypermobility, subluxations, chronic pain
    • Vascular fragility: Risk of arterial & organ rupture in some types
    • Gorlin’s sign is seen

Classification:

  • 13 clinical types (linked to 20 genes)
  • Common mutations: COL1A1, COL1A2, COL3A1, COL5A1, COL5A2

Major EDS Types & Features:

Type

Gene

Key Features

Classical (cEDS)

COL5A1, COL5A2

Hyperextensible skin, atrophic scars, joint hypermobility

Vascular (vEDS)

COL3A1

Thin skin, visible veins, arterial/organ rupture,

Hypermobile (hEDS)

Unknown

Joint hypermobility, chronic pain, POTS, mitral valve prolapse

Kyphoscoliotic

PLOD1, FKBP14

Severe scoliosis, hypotonia, vascular rupture

Arthrochalasia

COL1A1, COL1A2

Congenital hip dislocation, severe joint hypermobility

Dermatosparaxis

ADAMTS2

Severe skin fragility, sagging skin, large hernias

Periodontal

C1R, C1S

Severe gum disease, tooth loss, vascular fragility

Diagnosis:

  • Clinical criteria + genetic testing (except hEDS)
  • hEDS diagnosed using:
    • Modified Beighton Score ≥4
    • Arthralgia in ≥4 joints
  • Differential diagnoses:
    • Marfan syndrome
    • Osteogenesis Imperfecta
    • Loeys-Dietz syndrome

Management:

EDS is a diverse group of connective tissue disorders with no cure, requiring symptom-based management and specialized care.

  • Multidisciplinary care
  • Musculoskeletal: Physiotherapy, braces, joint protection
  • Vascular monitoring (for vEDS)
  • Low-impact exercise (swimming, walking)
  • Avoid high-impact sports (gymnastics, weightlifting)
  • Emergency preparedness (MedicAlert, ER protocol for vEDS)
  • Psychological support for chronic pain & genetic diagnosis

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate position for placement of single lead pacemaker ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Right ventricle

Explanation:

  • The pacemaker lead is typically placed in the right ventricle for most pacemaker implantations. This positioning allows the electrical impulses generated by the pacemaker to be delivered to the right ventricle, which then stimulates the heart muscle to contract and maintain an appropriate heart rhythm.

Pacemakers of the Heart:

Natural Pacemaker sites and their depolarization rates:

  • Sinoatrial node: 60 to 100 beats per minute
  • Atria: less than 60 beats per minute
  • Atrioventricular node: 40 to 60 beats per minute
  • Ventricles: 20 to 40 beats per minute

Artificial Pacemaker:

  • An artificial pacemaker is a small battery-operated device that helps regulate the heart's rhythm by producing electrical impulses. It typically consists of three parts: a generator, leads (wires), and sensors (electrodes). Traditional pacemakers are implanted under the skin, usually on the chest just below the collarbone or in the stomach area, and they connect to the heart through tiny wires.
  • There are several types of traditional pacemakers:
    • Single-lead pacemakers: One lead is placed in the right ventricle.
    • Dual-lead pacemakers: One lead is placed in the right atrium and one in the right ventricle.
    • Biventricular pacemakers (CRT): Three leads are used, placed in the right atrium, right ventricle, and left ventricle.

Wireless pacemakers are smaller and consist of a pulse generator and electrodes in one device. They are implanted inside the heart through a catheter inserted via internal jugular or femoral or subclavian vein, sending impulses to the right ventricle without the need for traditional surgery.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a female patient, aged 65, who visits the outpatient department with symptoms of breathlessness and fatigue? During examination, the patient's neck veins were engorged, and her jugular venous pulse displayed a swift X and Y descent.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Constrictive pericarditis

Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis is constrictive pericarditis.
  • Constrictive pericarditis is a condition characterized by inflammation and fibrosis of the pericardium, the sac-like structure surrounding the heart. It leads to the stiffening of the pericardium, impairing the normal filling and functioning of the heart.

Constrictive Pericarditis:

  • Progressive inflammation, thickening, fibrosis, and calcification of the pericardium restrict heart filling.
  • Calcification can extend into the myocardium, impairing myocardial contraction.
  • Restricted ventricular filling leads to elevated atrial pressures, causing:
    • Atrial hypertrophy
    • Atrial dilation
    • Atrial fibrillation (common).
  • Primarily manifests as systemic venous congestion (lung congestion is rare).

Examination Findings:

Finding

Description

Elevated JVP with rapid y descent

Reflects rapid early diastolic filling of the right ventricle due to pressure gradient.

Fatigue

Caused by the heart’s inability to meet circulatory demands.

Rapid, low-volume pulse

Restricted filling limits stroke volume, weakening the pulse.

Pericardial knock

A loud early S3 from the thickened pericardium during diastolic filling.

Kussmaul’s sign

Paradoxical rise in JVP during inspiration.

Hepatomegaly

Liver enlargement due to increased venous pressure.

Ascites

Abdominal fluid accumulation due to systemic venous congestion.

Peripheral oedema

Swelling in the extremities from fluid retention.

Pulsus paradoxus

A fall in systolic BP (10mm Hg) during inspiration, potentially impalpable pulse.

Atrial fibrillation

Common due to atrial hypertrophy and dilation.

 

Cardiac tamponade (Option B): Typically presents with elevated JVP, but it shows a prominent X descent and an absent Y descent (due to impaired filling), not rapid X and Y descents.

Dilated cardiomyopathy (Option C): This condition generally presents with signs of heart failure and an elevated JVP, but the JVP waveform does not typically show rapid X and Y descents.

Restrictive cardiomyopathy (Option D): This condition can present with symptoms similar to constrictive pericarditis, but it usually has a slow Y descent in the JVP rather than a rapid one.

questions.text: A 35 year old female patient with fever and malar rashes was found to have vegetations on either side of the heart valves. What can be the diagnosis of the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Libman sacks endocarditis

Explanation

  • A 35 year old female presents with fever and malar rashes suggests that this could be systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and the cardiac involvement of SLE shows Libman-Sacks endocarditis (LSE).
  • Libman-Sacks endocarditis is a form of nonbacterial endocarditis (also known as nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis) that is commonly associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). It is characterized by the presence of small, sterile vegetations on both sides of the heart valves, particularly the mitral and aortic valves.

Systemic Involvement in SLE

System

Manifestations

Pulmonary system
  • Pleuritis (most common): Prevalence (30 - 50%)
  • Pneumonitis
  • Atelectasis
  • Reduced lung volume and
  • Pulmonary ﬁbrosis
  • Shrinking lung syndrome, (< 5%)
  • Intra-alveolar hemorrhage
  • Pulmonary HTN (< 5 %) (Option C)
  • Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) (< 5%)

Musculoskeletal system
  • It is the most commonly involved system
  • Polyarthritis (symmetrical)
  • Polyarthralgia
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Myositis
  • Jaccoud arthropathy is a reversible deformity caused by ligament laxity, capsule fibrosis, and muscular imbalance.
  • Axial skeletal involvement is uncommon.

Renal system
  • Lupus nephritis (most common)
  • Proteinuria
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Rarely End-stage Renal Disease (ESRD)

Nervous system
  • Headache, Seizures, Stroke, Polyneuropathy, TIA, Acute confusional state, Movement disorder, Aseptic meningitis, Myelopathy, Psychosis and Mood disorders.

Cardiovascular system
  • Coronary artery disease - common cause of death
  • Pericarditis
  • Coronary vasculitis
  • Myocarditis
  • Libman sacks endocarditis
  • Accelerated atherosclerosis

Hematological manifestations
  • Anemia of chronic disease
  • Leucopenia
  • Lymphopenia
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Autoimmune Hemolytic anemia-MCC of anemia in SLE
  • Splenomegaly

GI involvement
  • Abdominal pain
  • Nausea, diarrhoea
  • Abnormal liver enzymes

Ocular manifestation
  • Sicca syndrome: Dry eyes (keratoconjunctivitis sicca) and dry mouth (xerostomia).
  • Conjunctivitis
  • Episcleritis
  • Vasculitis

 

While infective endocarditis (Option A) can also cause vegetations on the heart valves, the presence of malar rashes suggests an autoimmune condition like SLE rather than an infectious etiology.

questions.text: PR segment in ECG indicates:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Atrioventricular nodal conduction

Explanation:

  • The PR segment represents the period of atrioventricular nodal conduction in the cardiac cycle.

Component

Cause

Normal Duration and Size

P wave

Atrial depolarization is initiated by the SA node. (Option A Ruled Out)
  • 0.08–0.11 seconds
  • 2–2.75 small boxes
  • <2.5 mm (0.25 mV) in amplitude/ height
  • <0.12 sec (120 msec or 3 small boxes) in width

PR interval

Time from onset of atrial depolarization (P wave) to onset of ventricular depolarization (electrical impulse passing through AV node) (Option B)
  • 0.12–0.20 seconds
  • 3–5 small boxes

Q wave

Initial depolarization of the interventricular septum, directed from left to right.
  • <0.04 seconds
  • <1 small box
  • Depth: <1/4 of R wave or ~1–2 mm (<0.5 small boxes)

QRS complex

Ventricular depolarization - the time taken for the electrical impulse to spread through the ventricles. (Option C Ruled Out)
  • <0.10 seconds
  • <2.5 small boxes in width
  • Height: 5–30 mm (1–6 big boxes)

QT interval

Time from the start of ventricular depolarization to the end of ventricular repolarization.
  • Duration depends on HR.
  • HR inversely proportional QT length. Rate-corrected (QTc) 330–350 msec
  • ~11 small boxes

ST segment

Represents the early part of ventricular repolarization. It is isoelectric (flat). (Option D Ruled Out)

 
  • 0.08–0.12 seconds
  • 2–3 small boxes
  • Normally isoelectric (flat), deviations >1 small box indicate pathology

T wave

Represents the later stage of ventricular repolarization.
  • <0.04 seconds
  • 2.5–6.25 small boxes
  • Height: Varies. Normally <5 mm (1 big box) in limb leads, <10 mm (2 big boxes) in precordial leads

U wave

Unknown origin; possibly related to repolarization of Purkinje fibers or ventricular walls.
  • Not always measurable

questions.text: Most sensitive and specific marker for MI is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Troponin

Explanation:

  • Troponin as the most sensitive and specific biomarker for myocardial infarction (MI). Troponin is a regulatory protein complex found specifically in cardiac muscle tissue. It begins to rise within 3-6 hours of injury, peaks at 24-48 hours, and can remain elevated for 7-10 days, providing a wide diagnostic window. Cardiac troponins (cTnI and cTnT) have nearly absolute myocardial tissue specificity and high clinical sensitivity.

Cardiac Biomarkers for Acute Myocardial Infarction (AMI):

1. Cardiac Troponin:

  • Preferred biochemical markers due to their sensitivity and specificity.
  • Criteria for ACS: Requires rise and/or fall in biomarker values, with at least one value above the 99th percentile upper reference limit.
  • Troponin T (cTnT) and Troponin I (cTnI) increase significantly after STEMI.
  • Can detect concentrations <1 ng/L in non-ischemic conditions.
  • Troponin levels:
    • Increase within 3-6 hours.
    • Peak at around 36 hours.
    • Remains elevated for 7-10 days after STEMI.
  • Troponin should be measured at presentation and repeated at 1-3 hours (high-sensitivity assays) or 3-6 hours (conventional assays).
  • Further troponin tests are advised beyond 3-6 hours if AMI remains a possibility or there is diagnostic uncertainty.

Causes of elevated Serum Troponin other than MI

Cardiorespiratory Causes

Non-Cardiorespiratory Causes

  • Pulmonary embolism
  • Aortic dissection
  • Acute pulmonary edema
  • Tachyarrhythmias
  • Myocarditis/Myopericarditis
  • Cardiac trauma
  • Cardiac surgery/ablation
  • Prolonged hypotension
  • Severe sepsis
  • Severe burns
  • Stroke
  • Subarachnoid hemorrhage
  • End-stage renal failure
  • Cardiac troponin levels remain elevated for several days after an acute myocardial infarction (AMI), making them unreliable for detecting reinfarction.

2. Creatine Phosphokinase (CK) and CK-MB:

  • CK rises within 4-8 hours.
  • Peaks by 24 hours.
  • Returns to normal within 48-72 hours.
  • CK lacks specificity for STEMI since it can be elevated in skeletal muscle disease, trauma, or injections.
  • CK-MB isoenzyme is more specific for the heart
  • CK-MB elevated:
    • Cardiac surgery
    • Myocarditis
    • Electrical cardioversion
  • CK-MB/CK ratio >2.5 suggests a myocardial source, though it's not diagnostic.
  • CK-MB levels normalize within 48 to 72 hours, so a subsequent rise can confirm reinfarction.

3. Lactate Dehydrogenase (LDH):

  • Increase in the blood 6 to 12 hours after ACS.
  • Peak within 24 to 72 hours.
  • Normalize within 8 to 14 days.
  • LDH is no longer used to diagnose myocardial infarction because it is not specific to cardiac myocytes.

4. Heart-type Fatty Acid-Binding Protein (H-FABP):

  • Sensitivity of H-FABP in detecting AMI within 4 hours of symptom onset was 60%, significantly higher than troponin (18.8%) and CK-MB (12.5%).
  • But the specificity of H-FABP in detecting AMI was less than that of troponin and CK-MB.

 

Cytokeratin (Option B): Cytokeratin is a protein found in epithelial cells and has no role in cardiac injury detection. It is primarily used as a tumor marker for certain types of cancers and has no relevance in diagnosing myocardial infarction.

Myoglobin (Option C): While myoglobin is released during muscle injury and rises earlier than troponin (2-3 hours after injury), it lacks cardiac specificity as it is found in both cardiac and skeletal muscle.

CPK-MM (Option D): Creatine Phosphokinase-MM is the skeletal muscle isoform of CPK. It is predominantly found in skeletal muscle. Its elevation can occur in condition causing skeletal muscle damage, making it a poor choice for specific MI diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is given lifelong for patient receiving prosthetic mitral valve replacement?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Warfarin

Explanation:

  • Warfarin is given as the lifelong medication for patients with prosthetic mitral valve replacement. All mechanical valves require long-term anticoagulation because they can cause systemic thromboembolism or may develop valve thrombosis or obstruction.
  • Warfarin, a vitamin K antagonist, works by inhibiting the clotting proteins in the blood, providing necessary anticoagulation to prevent thromboembolic complications in patients with mechanical heart valves.
  • For patients with mechanical heart valve replacements, warfarin therapy requires a higher target INR range of 3.0 to 3.5. This higher intensity of anticoagulation is necessary to prevent thromboembolic complications associated with mechanical valves.

Warfarin Use

Target INR Range

Atrial Fibrillation

 

 

 

 

2.0 - 2.5

Venous Thromboembolism (VTE) Prophylaxis

Bioprosthetic Heart Valves (first 3 months)

Post-Myocardial Infarction

Treatment of DCT, PE, TIA

2.5 - 3.0

Mechanical Prosthetic Heart Valves

 

3.0 - 3.5

Recurrent Thromboembolism

 

Aspirin (Option A): While aspirin is an antiplatelet agent that acts on blood platelets, it alone is insufficient for mechanical valve anticoagulation. Unlike warfarin, which inhibits the circulating blood clotting proteins, aspirin's antiplatelet action is not potent enough to prevent valve thrombosis in mechanical valves.

Clopidogrel (Option B): Clopidogrel, like aspirin, has anti-platelet action and is not adequate for mechanical valve anticoagulation. Both these drugs act on platelets and not on clotting proteins, making them insufficient for preventing mechanical valve thrombosis.

Atorvastatin (Option C): Atorvastatin is an anti-dyslipidemic drug that has no anticoagulant properties. While patients with prosthetic valves may require statins for other cardiovascular indications, the primary requirement is anticoagulation, not lipid management.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male presents with palpitations and shortness of breath. His medical history includes hypertension, diabetes, and coronary artery disease. On examination, irregularly irregular heartbeats are noted. An electrocardiogram (ECG) reveals irregularly irregular rhythm, no P waves, and absence of an isoelectric baseline. His blood pressure is 132/84 mmHg, heart rate 130 bpm, and oxygen saturation 94% on room air. Given the patient's clinical presentation and history, which of the following treatment options should be considered as a first-line approach for managing this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Metoprolol

Explanation: The clinical scenario of a patient with a history of hypertension, diabetes, and coronary artery disease, irregularly irregular heartbeats on examination, along with an ECG showing irregularly irregular rhythm, no P waves, and absence of an isoelectric baseline, points towards a diagnosis of atrial fibrillation. The first-line approach for managing this case is beta blockers, such as metoprolol, to achieve rate control.

Atrial Fibrillation

Features
  • Characterized by abnormal automatic firing and multiple re-entry circuits.
  • Atria beat rapidly and ineffectively; ventricles activated irregularly
  • Produces an "irregularly irregular" pulse
  • Palpitations, syncope, and breathlessness can be present
  • Asymptomatic AF: Can present as systemic embolism and stroke

ECG Features
  • QRS Complexes: Irregular but normal
  • P Waves: Absent; baseline may show irregular fibrillation waves
  • Ventricular Rate:
    • Fast at onset (120-160 beats/min)
    • Slower in chronic AF due to medication effects and AV nodal fatigue

Management

Paroxysmal Atrial Fibrillation

  • First-line Therapy: Beta-blockers are effective in patients with CAD, hypertension, and heart failure. 
  • Class Ic Drugs: Propafenone or flecainide to prevent episodes (not for patients with CAD or LV dysfunction).
  • Class III Drugs:
    • Amiodarone: Most effective but with significant side effects; used when other treatments fail. (Option A)
    • Dronedarone: Alternative to amiodarone; contraindicated in heart failure.
  • Rate Control: Digoxin and verapamil for AV node conduction slowing, but not for AF prevention. 
  • Catheter Ablation: Considered for patients with drug-resistant AF; prevents AF in ~75% of cases but may have complications.

Persistent Atrial Fibrillation

  • Rhythm Control:
    • Cardioversion: Electrical or pharmacological (e.g., intravenous flecainide or amiodarone).
    • Timing: Immediate if AF <48 hours in unstable patients. (Option C)
    • Anticoagulation is required if AF ≥48 hours to prevent thromboembolic events. (Option D)
    • Prophylactic Amiodarone: To reduce recurrence risk.
  • Rate Control:
    • Medications: Digoxin, β-blockers, or rate-limiting calcium antagonists (verapamil, diltiazem).
    • Combination Therapy: Digoxin with β-blockers; avoid combining calcium antagonists with β-blockers.
    • Pace and Ablate: Permanent pacemaker with AV nodal block for symptomatic AF.

questions.text:
All are true regarding heart failure except:

HFpEF- Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction; HFrPF- Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction

choices.text: Regardless of ejection fraction and the type of heart failure, the 5-year mortality rate is around 50%
Non-cardiovascular death is more in HFrEF-30-40% as compared to HFpEF-15%
Angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors cause cough in 15% and angioedema in 1%
Atrial fibrillation is common in elderly and is the cause of stroke in quarter of the stroke cases

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Non-cardiovascular death is more in HFrEF-30-40% as compared to HFpEF-15%

Explanation: Non-cardiovascular death is more common in HFpEF (62%) than in HFrEF (35%), making option B incorrect.

 

Classification of Heart Failure by Left Ventricular Ejection Fraction:

Type of Heart Failure

Definition

Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF)

LVEF ≤40%

Heart failure with improved ejection fraction (HFimpEF)

Previous LVEF ≤40% and a follow-up LVEF >40%

Heart failure with mildly reduced ejection fraction (HFmrEF)

LVEF 41%–49%

Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF)

LVEF ≥50%
  • HFrEF has the highest rates of cardiac death compared to other heart failure categories.
  • Noncardiac causes account for a significant proportion of deaths, with 62% in HFpEF, 54% in HFmrEF, and 35% in HFrEF.

Regardless of ejection fraction and the type of heart failure, the 5-year mortality rate is around 50% (Option A): The 5-year mortality rate for heart failure patients, regardless of ejection fraction, is approximately 50%. The development of symptomatic heart failure carries a poor prognosis, with around 30-40% of patients dying within 1 year of diagnosis, and 60-70% dying within 5 years, which is correct.

Angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors cause cough in 15% and angioedema in 1% (Option C): ACE inhibitors are known to cause a cough in 15% of patients and rarely cause rashes or angioedema in 1% due to the accumulation of bradykinin and substance P, which is true.

Atrial fibrillation is common in elderly and is the cause of stroke in quarter of the stroke cases (Option D): Atrial fibrillation is common in elderly patients, with more than 95% of patients being over 60 years old. It increases the risk of stroke by five-fold and is responsible for around 25% of strokes, which is accurate.

questions.text:
In atrial fibrillation, choose the correct statements:


	Novel oral anticoagulants (NOACs) used in the treatment of moderate to severe MS
	Anticoagulants should be given in patients with ischemic stroke due to atrial fibrillation
	NOACs are contraindicated in prosthetic valves
	All patients with atrial fibrillation who are not candidates for cardiac surgery can be started on beta-blockers
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 2 and 3 correct

Explanation:

The correct statements are 2 and 3.

Atrial Fibrillation

Features
  • Characterized by abnormal automatic firing and multiple re-entry circuits.
  • Atria beat rapidly and ineffectively; ventricles activated irregularly
  • Produces an "irregularly irregular" pulse
  • Palpitations, syncope, and breathlessness can be present
  • Asymptomatic AF: Can present as systemic embolism and stroke

ECG Features
  • QRS Complexes: Irregular but normal
  • P Waves: Absent; baseline may show irregular fibrillation waves
  • Ventricular Rate:
    • Fast at onset (120-160 beats/min)
    • Slower in chronic AF due to medication effects and AV nodal fatigue

Management

Paroxysmal Atrial Fibrillation:

  • First-line Therapy: Beta-blockers are effective in patients with CAD, hypertension, and heart failure. (4)
  • Class Ic Drugs: Propafenone or flecainide to prevent episodes (not for patients with CAD or LV dysfunction).
  • Class III Drugs:
    • Amiodarone: Most effective but with significant side effects; used when other treatments fail. 
    • Dronedarone: Alternative to amiodarone; contraindicated in heart failure.
  • Rate Control: Digoxin and verapamil for AV node conduction slowing, but not for AF prevention. 
  • Catheter Ablation: Considered for patients with drug-resistant AF; prevents AF in ~75% of cases but may have complications.
 

Persistent Atrial Fibrillation:

  • Rhythm Control:
