    • Cardioversion: Electrical or pharmacological (e.g., intravenous flecainide or amiodarone).
    • Timing: Immediate if AF <48 hours in unstable patients. 
    • Anticoagulation is required if AF ≥48 hours to prevent thromboembolic events. 
    • Prophylactic Amiodarone: To reduce recurrence risk.
  • Rate Control:
    • Medications: Digoxin, β-blockers, or rate-limiting calcium antagonists (verapamil, diltiazem).
    • Combination Therapy: Digoxin with β-blockers; avoid combining calcium antagonists with β-blockers.
    • Pace and Ablate: Permanent pacemaker with AV nodal block for symptomatic AF.
 

Thromboprophylaxis:

  • Anticoagulation: Required for ischemic stroke prevention due to blood stasis in the left atrium. (2)
    • Warfarin: INR target of 2.0–3.0; start 4 weeks prior to cardioversion.
    • DOACs/NOACs: Rivaroxaban, apixaban, edoxaban, and dabigatran as alternatives to warfarin; no monitoring needed; contraindicated in atrial fibrillation with rheumatic mitral stenosis (1) or mechanical heart valves due to insufficient evidence supporting their safety and efficacy in these conditions. (3)
  • Risk Assessment:
    • CHA2DS2-VASc Score: For stroke risk; anticoagulate if score ≥2. 
    • HAS-BLED Score: For bleeding risk; monitor patients with score ≥3.
  • Aspirin: Not recommended due to low efficacy in preventing embolic stroke.

questions.text:
A 60 year old male patient with critical mitral stenosis presented with atrial fibrillation. He has a history of multiple episodes of transient ischemic attacks. Which of the following are true regarding the prevention of stroke in this patient?


	Only aspirin is given
	Warfarin is given
	Direct oral anticoagulants are not indicated
	Mitral valvotomy should be recommended
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 2 and 3

Explanation: The true statements regarding the prevention of stroke in this patient are 2 and 3.

Atrial Fibrillation

Features
  • Characterized by abnormal automatic firing and multiple re-entry circuits.
  • Atria beat rapidly and ineffectively; ventricles activated irregularly
  • Produces an "irregularly irregular" pulse
  • Palpitations, syncope, and breathlessness can be present
  • Asymptomatic AF: Can present as systemic embolism and stroke
ECG Features
  • QRS Complexes: Irregular but normal
  • P Waves: Absent; baseline may show irregular fibrillation waves
  • Ventricular Rate:
    • Fast at onset (120-160 beats/min)
    • Slower in chronic AF due to medication effects and AV nodal fatigue

Management

Paroxysmal Atrial Fibrillation:

  • First-line Therapy: Beta-blockers are effective in patients with CAD, hypertension, and heart failure. 
  • Class Ic Drugs: Propafenone or flecainide to prevent episodes (not for patients with CAD or LV dysfunction).
  • Class III Drugs:
    • Amiodarone: Most effective but with significant side effects; used when other treatments fail. 
    • Dronedarone: Alternative to amiodarone; contraindicated in heart failure.
  • Rate Control: Digoxin and verapamil for AV node conduction slowing, but not for AF prevention. 
  • Catheter Ablation: Considered for patients with drug-resistant AF; prevents AF in ~75% of cases but may have complications.
 

Persistent Atrial Fibrillation:

  • Rhythm Control:
    • Cardioversion: Electrical or pharmacological (e.g., intravenous flecainide or amiodarone).
    • Timing: Immediate if AF <48 hours in unstable patients. 
    • Anticoagulation is required if AF ≥48 hours to prevent thromboembolic events. 
    • Prophylactic Amiodarone: To reduce recurrence risk.
  • Rate Control:
    • Medications: Digoxin, β-blockers, or rate-limiting calcium antagonists (verapamil, diltiazem).
    • Combination Therapy: Digoxin with β-blockers; avoid combining calcium antagonists with β-blockers.
    • Pace and Ablate: Permanent pacemaker with AV nodal block for symptomatic AF.
 

Thromboprophylaxis:

  • Anticoagulation: Required for ischemic stroke prevention due to blood stasis in the left atrium. 
    • Warfarin: INR target of 2.0–3.0; start 4 weeks prior to cardioversion; recommended in patients with moderate to severe mitral stenosis or mechanical valves. (2)
    • DOACs/NOACs: Rivaroxaban, apixaban, edoxaban, and dabigatran as alternatives to warfarin; no monitoring needed; contraindicated in atrial fibrillation with rheumatic mitral stenosis or mechanical heart valves due to insufficient evidence supporting their safety and efficacy in these conditions. (3)
  • Risk Assessment:
    • CHA2DS2-VASc Score: For stroke risk; anticoagulate if score ≥2. 
    • HAS-BLED Score: For bleeding risk; monitor patients with score ≥3.
  • Aspirin: Not recommended due to low efficacy in preventing embolic stroke. (1)

Mitral valvotomy should be recommended (Option 1): Mitral valvotomy is not recommended for stroke prevention in this patient as it is indicated for symptomatic patients with isolated severe mitral stenosis and a valve area < 1.5 cm². It is contraindicated in the presence of left atrial thrombus, which is a common concern in atrial fibrillation.

questions.text: For the diagnosis of resistant hypertension, the patient should have uncontrolled hypertension despite taking three antihypertensive drugs. This should include at least one:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Diuretic

  • For the diagnosis of resistant hypertension, the patient must have uncontrolled hypertension despite taking three antihypertensive drugs, including at least one diuretic. While calcium channel blockers, beta blockers, or alpha blockers can be part of the treatment regimen, the inclusion of a diuretic is essential to confirm the diagnosis of resistant hypertension.

Resistant Hypertension:

  • Refers to blood pressure persistently greater than 140/90 mmHg despite using three or more antihypertensive agents, including a diuretic.
  • Population at Risk: It is more common in individuals over 60 years old and those at higher cardiovascular risk.
  • Causes:
    • Nonadherence to therapy.
    • Secondary causes such as obesity, primary aldosteronism, and excessive alcohol intake.
    • Use of certain nonprescription or prescription drugs.
  • Evaluation:
    • Home blood pressure monitoring can help determine if office readings are accurate.
    • Secondary hypertension evaluation is recommended if no apparent cause of resistance is found.
  • Management: Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists, particularly spironolactone, are effective as add-on therapies.

questions.text: Identify the disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Mitral stenosis:

  • The reduced area of the mitral valve with a "fish mouth" appearance is a hallmark feature of mitral stenosis.

Mitral Stenosis (MS):

  • Aetiology:
    • Primary Cause: Rheumatic fever is the leading cause of mitral stenosis, accounting for about 40% of cases in patients with a history of rheumatic heart disease.
    • Congenital abnormalities (e.g., parachute valve, cor triatriatum)
    • Mitral annular calcification with involvement of leaflets
    • Autoimmune diseases (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis)
    • Left atrial myxoma
    • Infective endocarditis with large vegetation

  • Pathology: Chronic inflammation leads to thickening of the valve leaflets, fibrous tissue formation, calcific deposits, and fusion of the mitral commissures and chordae tendinae. This process results in a narrowed, funnel-shaped valve. (Fish-mouth Appearance)
    • Normal mitral valve area: 4-6 cm²; significant obstruction of <2 cm².
    • Hemodynamics: In severe MS (<1.5 cm²), a left atrial (LA) pressure of ~25 mmHg is needed to maintain normal cardiac output (CO).
    • Effects of Heart Rate: Increased heart rate diminishes diastolic filling time, raising the LA pressure and transvalvular gradient
  • Symptoms:
    • Exertional dyspnea, cough, and progressive limitation of daily activities.
    • Orthopnea and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea can develop as MS worsens.
    • Atrial fibrillation (AF) often accelerates symptom progression.
  • Complications:
    • Pulmonary Hypertension (Leading to RVH & RHF)
    • Atrial Fibrillation (Due to Left atrial enlargement)
    • Thrombus Formation: Stasis of blood in the enlarged left atrium, increases the risk of thrombus formation, especially in patients with atrial fibrillation.
    • Hemoptysis (Elevated pulmonary venous pressure - rupture of small veins)
    • Infective Endocarditis
    • Pulmonary Infections
  • Findings:
    • Inspection: Malar flush, jugular venous distension, and right ventricular (RV) enlargement.
    • Auscultation: A loud S1, an opening snap (OS) after S2, and a low-pitched, rumbling mid-diastolic murmur with presystolic accentuation- heard best at the apex.
      • Characteristics of a murmur in severe MS:
        • Decreased interval between A2 & OS.
        • Wide splitting of S2.
        • Palpable systolic thrill.
        • The duration of the murmur increases.

  • Investigations:
    • ECG: Often shows LA enlargement, right axis deviation, and RV hypertrophy.
    • Echocardiogram: Measures mitral inflow velocity and transvalvular gradients and evaluates for associated mitral regurgitation (MR) or other valvular lesions.
    • Chest X-ray: Shows LA enlargement, pulmonary vein dilation, and Kerley B lines indicating pulmonary congestion.

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of atherosclerosis underwent a circumflex artery bypass. The stent is now placed successfully. He's already taking lisinopril, verapamil, and metoprolol. Which drug should be added?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) P2Y12 receptor blocker

Explanation:

  • P2Y12 receptor blockers, such as clopidogrel, ticagrelor, and prasugrel, are antiplatelet medications commonly used in patients undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI), including the placement of stents.

Percutaneous Coronary Intervention (PCI)

PCI involves balloon dilatation and stenting for symptomatic IHD with suitable stenoses in epicardial coronary arteries.

  • Indications:
    • Symptom-limiting angina despite optimal medical therapy.
    • Evidence of ischemia during stress tests.
  • Post-PCI Management:
    • Aspirin is administered indefinitely, and P2Y12 antagonists for 1-3 months.
    • P2Y12 receptor antagonists are used with aspirin for up to 12 months.
      • Clopidogrel (300mg, followed by 75 mg daily) with aspirin reduces death, reinfarction, and stroke risks in STEMI patients.
      • Newer drugs like ticagrelor (180 mg, followed by 90 mg twice daily) and prasugrel (60 mg, followed by 10 mg daily) are more effective than clopidogrel for ischemic complication prevention in STEMI patients undergoing PCI but have a higher bleeding risk.
    • Current-generation drug-eluting stents reduce restenosis but require prolonged dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT).

Incorrect Options:

Phosphodiesterase-3 (PDE 3) inhibitors (Option A) are commonly used in the treatment of heart failure and peripheral vascular disease.

Direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) (Option B) may be considered in some patients with certain indications, such as atrial fibrillation or mechanical heart valves. The routine use of DOACs may not be necessary in all patients who undergo a circumflex artery bypass for atherosclerosis.

Phosphodiesterase-5 (PDE 5) inhibitors (Option D), such as sildenafil, tadalafil, and vardenafil, are primarily used for the treatment of erectile dysfunction and pulmonary arterial hypertension.

questions.text: A male patient had feeble femoral pulses with an upper-limb blood pressure of 186/90 mmHg. Chest x-ray showed enlarged intercostal arteries. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Coarctation of aorta

Explanation:

  • The feeble femoral pulses and raised upper limb blood pressure indicate the diagnosis of coarctation of the aorta. The enlarged intercostal vessels indicate collaterals.

Coarctation of the Aorta:

  • It is a congenital condition leading to the narrowing of the aortic arch.
  • This narrowing causes a shelf-like obstruction in the descending aorta, typically near the junction of the main and left pulmonary arteries. Less commonly affects the transverse aortic arch.

Physical Examination Findings:

  • Characteristic features:
    • Elevated blood pressure in the upper limbs.
    • Brachiofemoral delay: Diminished or delayed femoral pulses compared to brachial or radial pulses.
  • Lower extremity blood pressure and pulses are lower and delayed than upper extremities (systolic pressure gradient > 20 mmHg between upper & lower extremities) unless significant aortic collaterals have developed.
  • A continuous murmur may be heard over the scapula due to collateral blood flow.

Hemodynamic Effects:

  • Increased afterload on structures receiving oxygenated blood, including the left ventricle, coronary arteries, ascending/transverse aorta, cerebral and arm vessels, and proximal descending aorta.

Associations:

  • A bicuspid aortic valve (typically with right-left commissural fusion) is commonly seen.
  • Turner syndrome should be considered, especially in women with short stature, webbed neck, lymphedema, and primary amenorrhea. Turner syndrome often indicates a more severe condition with increased risks.

Prognosis and Risks Post-Surgical Repair:

  • Generally good prognosis after surgical repair.
  • However, patients remain at risk for:
    • Systemic hypertension
    • Premature atherosclerosis
    • Left ventricular failure
    • Aortic aneurysm, dissection, and recurrent coarctation.


Incorrect Options:

Atrial septal defect (Option B) typically causes right heart volume overload, with a fixed split S2 and a systolic ejection murmur at the pulmonary area, reflecting increased pulmonary flow. It does not produce a blood pressure difference between the upper and lower limbs or weak femoral pulses.

The bicuspid aortic valve (Option C) has a varied presentation and has findings of low-pitched systolic ejection murmur and ejection click.

Patent ductus arteriosus (Option D) is a congenital anomaly of the heart where the ductus arteriosus fails to completely close and leads to a continuous machinery murmur below the clavicle, prominent precordial impulse, tachycardia, and bounding peripheral pulses.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of hypertension presented to the emergency room with loss of consciousness, chest pain, and diaphoresis. On examination, she was grossly unstable, and the bilateral pulses were unequal. ECG showed nonspecific ST-T changes. What is the next best investigation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Transoesophageal echocardiography

Explanation:

  • The clinical features here point to the diagnosis of aortic dissection, and the most sensitive and specific investigation for this is transesophageal endoscopy.

Transesophageal Echocardiography (TEE)

  • TEE uses a transducer at the tip of an endoscope inserted into the oesophagus for clearer views of the heart.
  • Provides better image quality and spatial resolution, especially for posterior structures.
  • Preferred for assessing small cardiac lesions like valvular vegetations, intracardiac thrombi, and congenital abnormalities.
  • Requires topical and systemic anaesthesia, usually conscious sedation.
  • Risks include oesophagal damage, perforation, aspiration, and anaesthesia complications.
  • Used in intubated patients and for intraoperative monitoring during cardiac surgeries.

Clinical Features of Aortic Dissection:

  • Pain: Sudden onset, severe, tearing chest pain, often associated with diaphoresis.
    • Pain location: Can be anterior or posterior chest, commonly in the interscapular region, and may migrate as the dissection progresses.
  • Associated Symptoms:
    • Syncope, dyspnea, and weakness.
    • Neurological symptoms (e.g., hemiplegia, hemianesthesia due to carotid artery obstruction, paraplegia due to spinal cord ischemia).
    • Bowel ischemia, hematuria, and myocardial ischemia.
  • Physical Findings:
    • Hypertension or hypotension, loss of pulses, aortic regurgitation, pulmonary oedema.
    • Horner's syndrome, superior vena cava syndrome, hoarseness, dysphagia, and airway compromise (from adjacent structure compression).
  • Complications:
    • Acute aortic regurgitation (in >50% of proximal dissections), often causing bounding pulses, wide pulse pressure, and diastolic murmur.
    • Hemopericardium and cardiac tamponade, especially in type A lesions with retrograde dissection.

Investigations/Diagnosis of Aortic Dissection:

  • Chest X-ray: (Option D)
    • Widened superior mediastinum, left-sided pleural effusion in ascending aorta dissection.
    • Widened mediastinum and potentially wider descending aorta in descending aorta dissection.
    • Not highly specific, especially in cases suspecting cardiovascular events.
  • Electrocardiogram (ECG):
    • No myocardial ischemia on ECG helps differentiate aortic dissection from myocardial infarction.
  • Transthoracic Echocardiography:
    • Simple and rapid, with a sensitivity of 60-85% for aortic dissection.
    • Most effective for proximal ascending aorta dissections.
  • Transesophageal Echocardiography:
    • Highly sensitive (98%) and specific (~90%) for detecting dissections of the ascending and descending aorta.
    • Less effective for diagnosing arch dissections.
  • CT and MRI: (Option A)
    • Highly accurate (>90% sensitivity and specificity) for identifying intimal flaps, dissection extent, and involvement of major arteries.
    • Useful for detecting intramural haemorrhage and penetrating ulcers.
  • Selection between CT, MRI, and echocardiography depends on institutional resources and patient hemodynamic stability.


Cardiac enzymes (Option C), such as troponin and creatine kinase-MB elevation, indicate injury or infarction of the heart muscle, which can occur in conditions like a heart attack. While cardiac enzymes are essential in the evaluation of chest pain and suspected myocardial injury, they do not provide immediate information about the current hemodynamic instability and the cause of the patient's symptoms.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with a history of recurrent retrosternal chest pain, with each episode lasting for 3-5 min and subsiding with sublingual nitrate. ECG shows left ventricular hypertrophy and flat T-wave. He has a known case of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and hypercholesterolemia and is currently on aspirin, atenolol, metformin, and lovastatin. What is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Increase the dose of beta blocker

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Injection enoxaparin

Explanation:

  • The patient's clinical presentation, history of recurrent chest pain, and ECG findings of left ventricular hypertrophy and flat T-waves raise concerns for NSTEMI-acute coronary syndrome. Injection enoxaparin, a low molecular weight heparin, is often used as an initial treatment to prevent clot formation and progression of coronary artery disease.

Management of NSTEMI-ACS

  • Management of NSTEMI involves evaluating patients with a low likelihood of ischemia in emergency settings, continuous ECG monitoring, stress testing, and serum troponin assessments, while those who meet criteria for NSTE-ACS are admitted for further monitoring and medical treatment aimed at stabilizing their condition and preventing future events.

Medical management

Anti-ischemic therapy:

  • Sublingual glyceryl trinitrate/nitroglycerin:
    • DOC for unstable angina
    • For ischemic discomfort
  • IV beta-blockers (Atenolol, Metoprolol):
    • They reduce the oxygen demand of the myocardium
    • They relieve pain, reduce arrhythmias, and reduce short-term mortality
  • Verapamil and diltiazem:
    • Given if symptoms are not relieved by full dose beta blockers and nitrates
    • They decrease the heart rate
  • IV morphine sulfate or diamorphine:
    • For analgesia
  • Antiemetics like metoclopramide (For symptomatic relief)
  • Nifedipine or amlodipine (If chest discomfort persists)
  • Atorvastatin and other HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors: Reduces occurrence of MI and recurrences of acute coronary syndrome
  • Ezetimibe or alirocumab, evolocumab:
    • Given if unresponsive to full dose statins
    • They reduce LDL cholesterol and prevent further cardiovascular events

Antithrombotic therapy:

  • Antiplatelet drugs:
    • Cyclooxygenase inhibitor: aspirin
    • Platelet P2Y12 receptor inhibitor: clopidogrel

Anticoagulants:

  • Unfractionated heparin.
  • Low molecular heparin: Enoxaparin.
  • Direct thrombin inhibitor: bivalirudin.
  • Synthetic factor Xa inhibitor: fondaparinux.

Invasive management
  • Done if the medical management fails and symptoms do not improve.
  • Coronary arteriography must be done within 48 hours of presentation.
  • Coronary revascularisation includes PCI (percutaneous coronary intervention) or coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG).


Incorrect Options:

IV glyceryl trinitrate infusion (Option A) is given in case of patients presenting with ongoing chest pain. The given scenario here gives a history of recurrent chest pains but does not specify that the patient suffers from it at presentation. Hence, it is not the best step for management.

Add clopidogrel (Option C): Clopidogrel is an antiplatelet drug that has antithrombotic action, however, enoxaparin is a better agent than clopidogrel and hence not preferred.

Increase the dose of beta-blocker (Option D): This step is not preferred over anticoagulation therapy using enoxparin.

questions.text: Evaluation of a patient revealed the presence of a mid-diastolic murmur. JVP showed prominent a-waves. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Tricuspid stenosis

Explanation:

  • The mid-diastolic murmur and the prominent a-waves on the JVP suggest the narrowing of the tricuspid valve, called tricuspid stenosis.

Tricuspid Stenosis

Aetiology

  • Congenital
  • Rheumatic origin (often coexists with mitral stenosis)

Pathophysiology

  • RA pressure ↑ , due to the diastolic pressure gradient between RA and RV, results in systemic venous congestion.
  • Restricted forward flow of blood leads to ↓ cardiac output.

Clinical features

  • Fatigue
  • Mild dyspnea
  • Venous congestion (right-side heart failure): Hepatomegaly, ascites, oedema and may lead to cardiac cirrhosis.
  • Physical examination:
    • Jugular venous distension with prominent ‘a’ waves
    • Auscultation: Mid-diastolic murmur at left lower sternal border
    • Murmur increases with inspiration (Carvallo's sign).
  • If mitral stenosis coexist
    • Pulmonary artery hypertension
    • Orthopnea due to pulmonary oedema

Investigations

  • Chest X-ray and ECG show features of RA enlargement
  • Echocardiogram: Thickened tricuspid valve with diastolic doming and increased pressure gradient between RV and RA.

Management

  • Medical management: To reduce systemic venous congestion symptoms
    • Dietary salt restriction
    • Loop diuretics
  • Surgical intervention: Valvular repair or Prosthetic valve replacement.

Incorrect Options:

Mitral stenosis (MS) (Option A) causes left atrial pressure overload, leading to pulmonary congestion and dyspnea, often with orthopnea and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. It is associated with a low-pitched rumbling mid-diastolic murmur with an opening snap but no prominent a-waves in JVP unless it is a severe case.

Mitral regurgitation (Option C) presents with a holosystolic murmur radiating to the axilla, which is not the given scenario. The JVP changes are seen only in severe cases.

Tricuspid regurgitation (Option D) is associated with a ‘C-v’ wave and steep ‘y’ descent in the JVP and has a blowing holosystolic murmur.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents with breathlessness and chest pain. She is a known case of mitral stenosis. Her pulse is irregularly irregular. No thrombus is seen on echocardiography. What is the best agent to prevent future thrombotic events?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Oral warfarin

Explanation:

  • Oral warfarin is the best agent to prevent thrombotic events in case of mitral stenosis.

Mitral Stenosis (MS):

  • Aetiology:
    • Primary Cause: Rheumatic fever is the leading cause of mitral stenosis, accounting for about 40% of cases in patients with a history of rheumatic heart disease.
    • Congenital abnormalities (e.g., parachute valve, cor triatriatum)
    • Mitral annular calcification with involvement of leaflets
    • Autoimmune diseases (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis)
    • Left atrial myxoma
    • Infective endocarditis with large vegetation
  • Symptoms:
    • Exertional dyspnea, cough, and progressive limitation of daily activities.
    • Orthopnea and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea can develop as MS worsens.
    • Atrial fibrillation (AF) often accelerates symptom progression.
  • Complications:
    • Pulmonary Hypertension (Leading to RVH & RHF)
    • Atrial Fibrillation (Due to Left atrial enlargement)
    • Thrombus Formation: Stasis of blood in the enlarged left atrium, increases the risk of thrombus formation, especially in patients with atrial fibrillation.
    • Hemoptysis (Elevated pulmonary venous pressure - rupture of small veins)
    • Infective Endocarditis
    • Pulmonary Infections

Management of Mitral Stenosis:

  • Medical Management: Patients with mild symptoms may be managed medically.
    • Penicillin Prophylaxis: Essential for preventing rheumatic fever in risk patients.
    • Symptomatic Relief: Sodium restriction, diuretics, beta-blockers, and Calcium channel blockers help manage symptoms and control heart rate in atrial fibrillation (AF).
    • Anticoagulation: Warfarin is for patients with AF, a history of thromboembolism, or left atrial thrombus; INR target 2–3.
    • Cardioversion: For recent-onset AF, ensure anticoagulation for at least three weeks.
    • Infective Endocarditis Prophylaxis: Routine antibiotic prophylaxis is no longer recommended.
  • Interventional: Considered if patients remain symptomatic despite medical management or if pulmonary hypertension develops/Severe MS (<1.5 cm²)
    • Balloon valvuloplasty
    • Mitral valvotomy/Mitral valve replacement

Incorrect Options:

Dabigatran (Option A) is an alternative anticoagulant but is not preferred as the first-line treatment as it has an increased risk of causing thromboembolic events.

Aspirin + Clopidogrel (Option B & D) is not approved for use in mitral stenosis to prevent thrombotic events.

questions.text: Resistant hypertension is defined as?

choices.text: BP >160/90 mmHg with three or more antihypertensive
BP >140/90 mmHg with three or more antihypertensive

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) BP >140/90 mmHg with three or more antihypertensive

Explanation:

  • Resistant hypertension is defined as persistently elevated blood pressure (BP) that remains >140/90 mmHg despite the use of three or more antihypertensive medications, being one of them is diuretic, and at optimal doses.

Hypertension Diagnosis Based on ABPM (ambulatory blood pressure monitoring)

Asleep (night-time) average

Measurement of automated office Blood Pressure (AoBP) :

  • 3 readings to be taken
  • Discard 1st reading
  • The next 2 readings need to be averaged
  • HTN if BP> 135/85 mmHg

questions.text: Which among the following investigations is the most suitable for diagnosing myocardial infarction (MI) within a timeframe of 2-4 hours of onset of chest pain?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Troponin-T

Explanation:

  • Troponin-T is a cardiac biomarker that is highly specific to cardiac muscle injury. It typically starts to rise within 3-4 hours after the onset of myocardial injury and remains elevated for several days. Therefore, it is considered the best investigation for diagnosing MI within 2-4 hours of symptom onset.

Cardiac Biomarkers for Acute Myocardial Infarction (AMI):

 

1. Cardiac Troponin

  • Preferred biochemical markers due to their sensitivity and specificity.
  • Criteria for ACS: Requires rise and/or fall in biomarker values, with at least one value above the 99th percentile upper reference limit.
  • Troponin T (cTnT) and Troponin I (cTnI) increase significantly after STEMI.
  • Can detect concentrations <1 ng/L in non-ischemic conditions.
  • Troponin levels:
    • Increase within 3-6 hours
    • Peak at around 36 hours
    • Remains elevated for 7-10 days after STEMI.
  • Troponin should be measured at presentation and repeated at 1-3 hours (high-sensitivity assays) or 3-6 hours (conventional assays).
  • Further troponin tests are advised beyond 3-6 hours if AMI remains a possibility or there is diagnostic uncertainty.

Causes of elevated Serum Troponin other AMI

Cardiorespiratory Causes

Non-Cardiorespiratory Causes

  • Pulmonary embolism
  • Aortic dissection
  • Acute pulmonary edema
  • Tachyarrhythmias
  • Myocarditis/Myopericarditis
  • Cardiac trauma
  • Cardiac surgery/ablation
  • Prolonged hypotension
  • Severe sepsis
  • Severe burns
  • Stroke
  • Subarachnoid hemorrhage
  • End-stage renal failure
  • Cardiac troponin levels remain elevated for several days after an acute myocardial infarction (AMI), making them unreliable for detecting reinfarction.

2. Creatine Phosphokinase (CK) and CK-MB (Option B):

  • CK rises within 4-8 hours.
  • Peaks by 24 hours.
  • Returns to normal within 48-72 hours.
  • CK lacks specificity for STEMI since it can be elevated in skeletal muscle disease, trauma, or injections.
  • CK-MB isoenzyme is more specific for the heart
  • CK-MB elevated:
    • Cardiac surgery
    • Myocarditis
    • Electrical cardioversion
  • CK-MB/CK ratio >2.5 suggests a myocardial source, though it's not diagnostic.
  • CK-MB levels normalize within 48 to 72 hours, so a subsequent rise can confirm reinfarction.

3. Lactate Dehydrogenase (LDH) (Option A):

  • Increase in the blood 6 to 12 hours after ACS.
  • Peak within 24 to 72 hours.
  • Normalize within 8 to 14 days.
  • LDH is no longer used to diagnose myocardial infarction because it is not specific to cardiac myocytes.

4. Heart-type Fatty Acid-Binding Protein (H-FABP):

  • Sensitivity of H-FABP in detecting AMI within 4 hours of symptom onset was 60%, significantly higher than troponin (18.8%) and CK-MB (12.5%).
  • But the specificity of H-FABP in detecting AMI was less than that of troponin and CK-MB.

5. BNP (B-type natriuretic peptide) (Option D):

  • BNP is a hormone released by the ventricles of the heart in response to increased stretching of cardiac muscle cells.
  • It is primarily used for diagnosing and assessing the severity of heart failure. BNP levels are not specific to myocardial infarction and do not provide timely diagnosis within 2-4 hours

questions.text: Which of the following treatment options is not suitable for managing a patient with non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Streptokinase

Explanation:

  • In a patient with Non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI), streptokinase is not typically used for treatment.
  • Streptokinase belongs to the class of fibrinolytic agents and is commonly used for the management of ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) to dissolve blood clots causing the blockage in the coronary arteries. However, in NSTEMI, the underlying mechanism is often different, and the management approach focuses on antiplatelet therapy and anticoagulation rather than fibrinolysis.

Management of NSTEMI-ACS:

  • Management of NSTEMI involves evaluating patients with a low likelihood of ischemia in emergency settings, continuous ECG monitoring, stress testing, and serum troponin assessments, while those who meet criteria for NSTE-ACS are admitted for further monitoring and medical treatment aimed at stabilizing their condition and preventing future events.

 

Medical management

Anti-ischemic therapy:

  • Sublingual glyceryl trinitrate/nitroglycerin:
    • DOC for unstable angina
    • For ischemic discomfort
  • IV beta-blockers (Atenolol, Metoprolol):
    • They reduce the oxygen demand of the myocardium
    • They relieve pain, reduce arrhythmias, and reduce short-term mortality
  • Verapamil and diltiazem:
    • Given if symptoms are not relieved by full dose beta blockers and nitrates
    • They decrease the heart rate
  • IV morphine sulfate or diamorphine:
    • For analgesia
  • Antiemetics like metoclopramide (For symptomatic relief)
  • Nifedipine or amlodipine (If chest discomfort persists)
  • Atorvastatin and other HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors: Reduces occurrence of MI and recurrences of acute coronary syndrome
  • Ezetimibe or alirocumab, evolocumab:
    • Given if unresponsive to full dose statins
    • They reduce LDL cholesterol and prevent further cardiovascular events

Antithrombotic therapy:

  • Antiplatelet drugs:
    • Cyclooxygenase inhibitor: aspirin (Option A)
    • Platelet P2Y12 receptor inhibitor: clopidogrel, Prasugrel (Option B, D)

Anticoagulants:

  • Unfractionated heparin.
  • Low molecular heparin: enoxaparin.
  • Direct thrombin inhibitor: bivalirudin.
  • Synthetic factor Xa inhibitor: fondaparinux.

Invasive management

  • Done if the medical management fails and symptoms do not improve.
  • Coronary arteriography must be done within 48 hours of presentation.
  • Coronary revascularization includes PCI (percutaneous coronary intervention) or coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG).

questions.text: A 65 year old male patient presented to the emergency room with symptoms of palpitation, dizziness. On examination pulse is 180 beats per minute and his blood pressure is 70 mmHg systolic. The electrocardiogram (ECG) reveals a narrow QRS complex tachycardia with a regular heart rate. What should be the next course of action in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) DC cardioversion

Explanation:

  • In this patient, immediate cardioversion is the most appropriate next step in the management.

 

DC cardioversion

  • Electrical cardioversion (DC cardioversion) is used to terminate organized arrhythmias such as atrial fibrillation (AF) or ventricular tachycardia (VT). It is the treatment of choice for unstable tachyarrhythmias.
  • The electric current interrupts the arrhythmia, causing a brief asystole, usually followed by the return of sinus rhythm.
  • It is usually performed as an elective procedure under general anesthesia.
  • The shock is delivered immediately after the R wave to avoid triggering ventricular fibrillation (VF), which may occur if applied during ventricular repolarization (T wave).
  • High-energy shocks may cause chest wall pain post-procedure.
  • If there is no urgency, it is best to start with a lower-energy shock (around 50 joules) and increase if necessary.

 

Adenosine (Option B) is commonly used for the acute termination of supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) episodes. However, it is not the preferred initial treatment for a patient with signs of hemodynamic instability and low blood pressure. Adenosine can cause a transient period of asystole when administered, which can further compromise the patient's blood pressure.

Valsalva Maneuver (Option C) involves straining against a closed glottis, can be attempted as a non-invasive method to terminate certain types of supraventricular tachycardias.

Verapamil (Option D) is a calcium channel blocker that can be effective in terminating certain types of supraventricular tachycardias, such as atrioventricular nodal reentrant tachycardia.

questions.text: What would be the most appropriate approach for a patient experiencing chest pain for the past 3 hours, where an ECG shows ST depression in anterior chest leads and T wave inversion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Aspirin with heparin

Explanation:

  • As the patient presented within 3 hours of the onset of chest pain, which suggests an acute coronary syndrome (ACS) and the ECG findings of ST depression in anterior chest leads and T wave inversion are consistent with myocardial ischemia..
  • Aspirin is an antiplatelet agent that inhibits platelet aggregation and Heparin is an anticoagulant that prevents the formation and propagation of blood clots. It is administered promptly to patients suspected of having ACS to minimize ongoing thrombosis.

Management of NSTEMI-ACS:

  • Management of NSTEMI involves evaluating patients with a low likelihood of ischemia in emergency settings, continuous ECG monitoring, stress testing, and serum troponin assessments, while those who meet criteria for NSTE-ACS are admitted for further monitoring and medical treatment aimed at stabilizing their condition and preventing future events.

Medical management

Anti-ischemic therapy:

  • Sublingual glyceryl trinitrate/nitroglycerin:
    • DOC for unstable angina
    • For ischemic discomfort
  • IV beta-blockers (Atenolol, Metoprolol):
    • They reduce the oxygen demand of the myocardium
    • They relieve pain, reduce arrhythmias, and reduce short-term mortality
  • Verapamil and diltiazem:
    • Given if symptoms are not relieved by full dose beta blockers and nitrates
    • They decrease the heart rate
  • IV morphine sulfate or diamorphine:
    • For analgesia
  • Antiemetics like metoclopramide (For symptomatic relief)
  • Nifedipine or amlodipine (If chest discomfort persists)
  • Atorvastatin and other HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors: Reduces occurrence of MI and recurrences of acute coronary syndrome
  • Ezetimibe or alirocumab, evolocumab:
    • Given if unresponsive to full dose statins
    • They reduce LDL cholesterol and prevent further cardiovascular events

Antithrombotic therapy:

  • Antiplatelet drugs:
    • Cyclooxygenase inhibitor: aspirin
    • Platelet P2Y12 receptor inhibitor: clopidogrel

Anticoagulants:

  • Unfractionated heparin.
  • Low molecular heparin: enoxaparin.
  • Direct thrombin inhibitor: bivalirudin.
  • Synthetic factor Xa inhibitor: fondaparinux.

Invasive management

  • Done if the medical management fails and symptoms do not improve.
  • Coronary arteriography must be done within 48 hours of presentation.
  • Coronary revascularization includes PCI (percutaneous coronary intervention) or coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG).

 

PCI (percutaneous coronary intervention) (Option A) is a preferred treatment option for patients with ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI).

Thrombolysis with alteplase (Option B) is primarily indicated for patients with STEMI who present within a specific time window and are not candidates for primary PCI.

While arrhythmias can be a complication of ACS, prophylactic treatment for arrhythmias (Option C) is not the primary management strategy in the acute phase. The focus initially is on addressing the underlying ischemia and preventing further thrombosis through antiplatelet and anticoagulant therapy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents to the clinic with complaints of increasing fatigue and shortness of breath. Upon auscultation, the physician detects a pan systolic murmur that is best heard at the right side of the heart. The murmur radiates to the axilla and is louder during inspiration. The patient denies any history of fever, chest pain, or recent infections. What is the most probable diagnosis for this patient's condition based on the described findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Tricuspid Regurgitation

Explanation:

  • Tricuspid regurgitation is characterized by a pan systolic murmur heard best along the right side of the heart and it radiates to the right of the sternum. Additionally, tricuspid regurgitation is often secondary to other conditions affecting the right side of the heart, such as pulmonary hypertension or right heart failure.
  • The characteristics of a pan systolic murmur heard at the right side of the heart and radiating to the axilla, along with the absence of signs of aortic stenosis, mitral valve prolapse, and ventricular septal defect, point toward tricuspid regurgitation as the most likely diagnosis in this case. It's important to consider the entire clinical picture and potentially perform further tests (e.g., echocardiography) to confirm the diagnosis and assess the severity of the condition.

 

Aortic Stenosis (Option A) Systolic ejection murmur, crescendo-decrescendo pattern, radiating to carotids, best heard at the right upper sternal border
Mitral Valve Prolapse (Option B) Late systolic murmur is best heard at the apex, not a pan systolic murmur. Typically preceded by a non-ejection click, and intensity and duration increases with maneuvers that decrease ventricular volume.
Ventricular Septal Defect (Option C) Harsh, holosystolic murmur heard, best at the left lower sternal border, as blood flows from the higher-pressure left ventricle to the lower-pressure right ventricle.

questions.text:
Correct sequence after p wave:

A - ‘a’ wave

B - 1st heart sound

C - Rapid filling of ventricles

D - ‘t’ wave
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) ABDC

The correct sequence after the P wave is as follows:

  • A. The 'a' wave represents atrial contraction. It occurs during atrial systole when the atria contract to push blood into the ventricles.
  • B. The 1st heart sound, also known as S1, is the closure of the atrioventricular (AV) valves (mitral and tricuspid valves) at the beginning of ventricular systole. It marks the onset of ventricular contraction.
  • D. The 't' wave is a repolarization phase of the ventricles. It represents the relaxation and resetting of the ventricles after contraction.
  • C. After the 't' wave, the ventricles enter the diastole phase, during which they passively fill with blood from the atria. This is known as rapid ventricular filling.

 

Therefore, the correct sequence is ABDC: 'a' wave, 1st heart sound, rapid filling of ventricles, and 't' wave.

 

Jugular Venous Pressure (JVP) Waveform

a wave
  • Caused by atrial systole.
  • Atrial contraction results in a temporary halt in venous inflow.
  • Some blood flows back into the veins, causing a rise in venous pressure.

c wave
  • Arises from the increase in atrial pressure during isovolumetric ventricular contraction.
  • Pressure is transmitted through the closed and bulging tricuspid valve.

x descent
  • Ventricular systole pulls the tricuspid valve down

v wave
  • Corresponds to the rise in atrial pressure as blood fills the atria.
  • Occurs during diastole while the tricuspid valve is still closed.

y descent
  • Opening of tricuspid valve causing emptying of right atrium into ventricle

 

Respiration Influence:

  • Venous pressure decreases during inspiration due to negative intrathoracic pressure, and rises during expiration.

questions.text: Water hammer pulse is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Aortic regurgitation

Explanation: Water hammer pulse is seen in Aortic regurgitation.

Signs of Aortic Regurgitation

Muller Sign

It is a visible systolic pulsation of the uvula

Rosenbach sign

Systolic pulsations of the Liver

Gerhardt's sign

Systolic pulsations of the Spleen

Quincke's sign

Repeatedly alternating blushing and blanching of capillaries in the nail folds upon palpation (Capillary Pulsations)

Landolphi sign

Alternating systolic constriction and diastolic dilatation of pupils

Traube Sign

It is pistol shot sounds that are heard while auscultating over the femoral artery.

Water-Hammer pulse/ Corrigan's pulse

Strong pulse that rises quickly and then drops off suddenly.

Duroziez Sign

It is a to-and-fro murmur heard while auscultating the femoral artery.

De-Musset sign

The jarring motion of the head with each heartbeat

 

Aortic stenosis (Option A): Severe aortic stenosis is associated with pulsus parvus et tardus, characterized by a carotid pulse that rises slowly and peaks late due to restricted blood flow through the narrowed valve, which is distinct from the bounding water hammer pulse seen in aortic regurgitation.

Aortic stenosis and aortic regurgitation (Option C): In cases where aortic stenosis and aortic regurgitation coexist, the stenosis reduces the stroke volume ejected into the aorta, limiting the high-amplitude and rapid upstroke typical of a water hammer pulse seen in isolated aortic regurgitation.

Mitral regurgitation (Option D): Chronic mitral regurgitation shows a sharp, low-volume pulse due to reduced forward cardiac output, while acute mitral regurgitation may present with a narrow pulse pressure. Neither scenario produces the rapid upstroke and collapse characteristic of a water hammer pulse.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a known history of DM and HTN on regular medications presents with a history of progressively worsening dyspnoea on exertion. On examination, there’s elevated JVP, positive hepatojugular reflux, crackles at the lung bases, hepatomegaly, ascites and pedal oedema. What is your provisional diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Heart failure
Explanation: The patient’s symptoms, including progressively worsening dyspnea on exertion, elevated jugular venous pressure (JVP), positive hepatojugular reflux, crackles at the lung bases, hepatomegaly, ascites, and pedal edema, are indicative of heart failure.

Clinical features of Congestive Heart Failure:

  • Cardiac output decreased
  • Stroke volume decreased
  • Heart rate increased
  • Increased sympathetic drive leading to palpitations and diaphoresis
  • Orthopnea
  • Paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea

Clinical Features of Left-Sided vs. Right-Sided Congestive Heart Failure (CHF)

Left-Sided Heart Failure

Right-Sided Heart Failure

Causes:

  • Ischemic heart disease (myocardial infarction).
  • Hypertension
  • Dilated cardiomyopathy.
  • Aortic or mitral valve disease.

Causes:

  • Left-sided heart failure (most common cause).
  • Chronic lung diseases (COPD, pulmonary hypertension).
  • Pulmonary embolism.
  • Right ventricular infarction.

In left-sided heart failure, the left ventricle cannot effectively pump blood to the body, leading to a backup of blood into the lungs.

 

Clinical features:

This primarily results in pulmonary symptoms.

  • Exertional dyspnea
  • Orthopnea
  • Paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea

 

Pulmonary Congestion:

  • Crackles (rales) heard on auscultation due to fluid in the alveoli.
  • Cough
  • Wheezing (cardiac asthma).
  • Fatigue and Weakness
  • Decreased Exercise Tolerance
  • Limited physical activity due to breathlessness and fatigue.
  • S3 Gallop

 

Cool Extremities: Reduced cardiac output may cause poor peripheral circulation, leading to cold, pale skin.

In right-sided heart failure, the right ventricle fails to pump blood effectively into the pulmonary circulation, leading to systemic venous congestion. It is often secondary to left-sided heart failure or conditions affecting the lungs (cor pulmonale).

 

Clinical Features:

  • Peripheral Edema
  • Jugular Venous Distension (JVD)
  • Hepatomegaly
  • B/L pitting pedal edema
  • Kussmaul sign: JVP elevation on inspiration
  • Ascites
  • Nocturia
  • Weight Gain
  • Anorexia and Nausea

 

 

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (Option B): While hypertrophic cardiomyopathy can cause dyspnea, the patient’s clinical signs of elevated JVP, hepatojugular reflux, crackles, hepatomegaly, ascites, and pedal edema are more indicative of heart failure due to volume overload, which is not a characteristic feature of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

Mitral regurgitation (Option C): Although mitral regurgitation can lead to heart failure, the signs observed here (e.g., ascites, pedal edema, crackles) indicate a more generalized failure of the heart to pump blood effectively, which is more consistent with heart failure (particularly congestive heart failure) rather than isolated mitral regurgitation.

Portal hypertension (Option D) can occur secondary to right heart failure, but the progressive dyspnea, along with the extensive signs of systemic congestion (e.g., elevated JVP, ascites, hepatojugular reflux), points toward a primary cardiac condition like heart failure.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a radiological finding in a patient with left heart failure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Focal oligemia

  • Focal oligemia, also known as Westermark’s sign, is a radiological finding associated with pulmonary embolism, not left heart failure.

Area of focal oligemia (Westermark’s sign) (white arrow), with prominent right descending pulmonary artery (Palla’s sign) (black arrow)

Radiographic Changes in Left Heart Failure:

  • Pulmonary venous dilation and congestion (Option C)
  • Cephalization of pulmonary veins: Upper lobe vessels become more prominent due to redistribution of blood flow (Option D)
  • Kerley B (septal) lines: Horizontal lines caused by interstitial edema (Option A)
  • Thickened interlobar fissures
  • Pulmonary interstitial edema: Blurring of vascular margins and peribronchial cuffing
  • Pulmonary alveolar edema: Bat-wing or butterfly pattern of opacities
  • Pleural effusion
  • Cardiomegaly (increased cardiothoracic ratio)

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with an episode of acute onset dizziness and loss of consciousness, which lasted for a few seconds, followed by a regain of full consciousness. There were no similar episodes in the past. Which of the following is a true statement regarding this scenario?

choices.text: ECG to rule out atrial fibrillation
If ECG is normal, CT scan should be done
Vestibular neuritis is a possible condition that can cause these symptoms

questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - ECG to rule out atrial fibrillation:

  • The patient’s presentation of acute onset dizziness and loss of consciousness, which lasted only a few seconds and was followed by full recovery, suggests a transient loss of consciousness episode, likely syncope. This could be due to arrhythmias (atrial fibrillation, sinus node dysfunction, atrioventricular block, ventricular tachyarrhythmia) or structural cardiac abnormalities, making an ECG crucial in this case to rule out cardiac causes.

Syncope:

  • Transient, self-limited loss of consciousness due to acute global impairment of cerebral blood flow.
  • Rapid onset, brief duration, and spontaneous, complete recovery.
  • Categories of Syncope Causes:
    • Neurally mediated syncope (reflex or vasovagal syncope)
    • Orthostatic hypotension
    • Cardiac syncope
  • Initial Evaluation of Syncope:
    • Detailed history and thorough questioning of eyewitnesses.
    • Complete physical and neurologic examination.
    • Measure blood pressure and heart rate in the supine position and after 3 minutes of standing to assess for orthostatic hypotension.
    • ECG Indications:
      • If there is suspicion of syncope due to arrhythmia or underlying cardiac disease.
      • Relevant electrocardiographic abnormalities include bradyarrhythmias, tachyarrhythmias, AV block, acute myocardial ischemia, old myocardial infarction, long QT, and bundle branch block.

If ECG is normal, CT scan should be done (Option B): A CT scan would only be required if a seizure or transient ischemic attack (TIA) is suspected. Given that the episode lasted only a few seconds, the patient has no history of similar events, and there are no lasting neurological deficits, a CT scan is not typically needed at this point.

Tilt-table testing (Option C) is generally reserved for patients with recurrent or unexplained syncope. It is not typically used for a single isolated episode of syncope, especially in the absence of a history of similar events.

Vestibular neuritis (Option D) typically causes dizziness and a sense of spinning (vertigo), but it does not generally lead to loss of consciousness. Since the patient’s primary symptom is syncope (brief loss of consciousness), vestibular neuritis is not the most likely diagnosis in this case.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male patient has been diagnosed with hypertension. On examination, there is no existing cardiovascular disease, no hypertension-mediated organ damage (HMOD), and renal function is normal. He should be immediately started on pharmacological management if his blood pressure is more than
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - >140/90 mmHg

  • According to the American Heart Association (AHA) guidelines for hypertension management:

Indications for Immediate Pharmacological Treatment:

Adults aged 18-79 years with:

  • Systolic Blood Pressure (SBP): ≥140 mmHg
  • Diastolic Blood Pressure (DBP): ≥90 mmHg

In patients with no cardiovascular disease, no hypertension-mediated organ damage (HMOD), and normal renal function, immediate pharmacological therapy is initiated if the BP is ≥140/90 mmHg.

AHA Hypertension Grading

 

Category

Systolic BP (mmHg)

Diastolic BP (mmHg)

Normal

<120

<80

Elevated

120–129

<80

Hypertension Stage 1

130–139

80–89

Hypertension Stage 2

≥140

≥90

Hypertensive Crisis

>180

>120

ACC/AHA Guidelines for Hypertension Management

Indications for Use of antihypertensives
  • Secondary prevention of recurrent CVD events in patients with clinical CVD (defined as CHD, CHF, stroke) and BP ≥130/≥80 mmHg
  • Primary prevention in patients with an estimated 10-year ASCVD risk ≥10% and BP ≥130/≥80 mmHg
  • Primary prevention of CVD and low CVD risk in patients with BP ≥140/ ≥90 mmHg

Blood Pressure Goal in Treating Hypertension
  • BP target < 130/80 mmHg for adults with confirmed hypertension and known CVD or 10-year ASCVD event risk ≥10%

Exceptions to Therapeutic Target of <130/80 mmHg
  • Age >80 years
  • Blood pressure <140/90 mmHg in previously untreated hypertensive patients who experience an ischemic stroke or TIA
  • Acute therapy for most hypertensive urgencies and emergencies

Abbreviations:

  • ASCVD - atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease
  • CHD - coronary heart disease
  • CHF - congestive heart failure
  • CVD - cardiovascular disease

Patient type

First Drug

Add a Second Drug If Needed to Achieve the target BP

If a Third Drug is Needed to Achieve the target BP

Black patients (African ancestry): All ages

CCB or thiazide diuretic

ARB or ACE inhibitor

Combination of CCB + ACE inhibitor or ARB + thiazide diuretic

 

 

 

White and other non-black Patients: Younger than 60 years

ARB or ACE inhibitor

CCB or thiazide diuretic

White and other non-black patients: 60 years and older

CCB or thiazide diuretic

ARB or ACE inhibitor

Abbreviations:

  • CCB - Calcium channel blocker
  • ACE - Angiotensin converting enzyme
  • ARB - Angiotensin receptor blocker

Hypertension with other associated conditions

Initial drug of choice

Hypertension and diabetes

ARB or ACE inhibitor

Hypertension and chronic kidney disease

ARB or ACE inhibitor

Note: in black patients, good evidence for the renal protective effects of ACE inhibitors

Hypertension and clinical coronary artery disease

β-Blocker plus ARB or ACE inhibitor

Hypertension and stroke history

ARB or ACE inhibitor

Hypertension and heart failure

Regardless of blood pressure, ARB or ACE inhibitor + β-blocker + diuretic + spironolactone. A dihydropyridine CCB can be added if needed for BP control.

Pneumonic: ABDS

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient presented with chest pain, exertional dyspnea and syncope. He was diagnosed with a case of aortic stenosis and his chest x-ray was taken which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Post stenotic dilatation of aorta

Explanation:

  • Based on the given clinical presentation of chest pain, exertional dyspnea, and syncope, along with the diagnosis of aortic stenosis and chest x-ray findings, the most likely diagnosis in this case is post-stenotic dilatation of the aorta.

Aortic Stenosis

  • Symptom onset:
    • AS is clinically significant when the aortic valve orifice narrows to ~1 cm².
    • Severe AS can remain asymptomatic for years due to LV compensation.
  • Symptom progression: Often develops in the sixth to eighth decades; patients with bicuspid aortic valves may experience symptoms 10-20 years earlier.
  • Clinical Manifestations of Aortic Stenosis:
    • Triad: Exertional dyspnea, Angina pectoris, Syncope on exertion
    • Early symptoms: Fatigue and reduced exercise tolerance.
    • Advanced stages:
      • Orthopnea
      • Paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea
      • Pulmonary edema.
    • Late Findings:
      • RV failure
      • Systemic venous hypertension
      • Hepatomegaly
      • Atrial fibrillation
      • Tricuspid regurgitation

Post-Stenotic Aortic Dilatation (PSAD)

Definition:

  • Post-stenotic aortic dilatation refers to the enlargement of the aortic vessel wall distal to a stenotic or malformed aortic valve. It typically involves the ascending aorta, with a diameter greater than 4.0 cm, and is characterized by a progressive increase in size of more than 0.3 cm per year.

Risk:

  • It is considered a precursor to serious conditions like aortic dissection and rupture, which can be fatal.

Aetiology:

  • PSAD can occur in patients with aortic stenosis (AS) or aortic regurgitation (AR), and even in those with a normal aortic valve (e.g., in the case of a bicuspid aortic valve, BAV), or after aortic valve replacement (AVR).
  • PSAD is not solely related to the severity of AS but may have a genetic basis, alongside mechanical stresses placed on the aortic wall.
  • The bicuspid aortic valve is an independent risk factor for both AS and progressive aortic dilatation.

Imaging findings:

  • Dilatation of the aorta immediately distal to the stenosis.
  • Normal or narrowed aortic segment proximal to stenosis.
  • Additional findings depend on aetiology.


Incorrect Options:

Aortic root dilatation (Option A) is typically asymptomatic and discovered incidentally, but in rare cases, it can lead to severe complications like aortic dissection, rupture, or congestive heart failure due to aortic insufficiency. This is not the given scenario.

Widening of the aortic knob (Option B) is seen in congenital heart diseases, aortic dissection, systemic hypertension, post-stenotic dilatation, etc. However, the location of the given lesion is not of the aortic knob.

Widening of the vascular pedicle (Option C): The vascular pedicle is measured between parallel lines drawn from the point at which the superior vena cava intersects the right main bronchus and a line drawn at the takeoff of the left subclavian artery from the aorta. This is not the given radiograph.

questions.text: The device seen in the following image is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Cardiac pacemaker

Explanation:

  • The device shown in the x-ray is a cardiac pacemaker.

Cardiac Conduction Devices (CCDs)

  • Implantable Cardioverter Defibrillators (ICD):
    • Function: Delivers electrical shocks to treat dysrhythmias and restore normal sinus rhythm.
    • Types:
      • Transvenous ICDs (T-ICD): Leads placed at the junction of the brachiocephalic vein/superior vena cava and right ventricle (RV). Can be combined with biventricular pacemakers for Cardiac Resynchronization Therapy (CRT).
      • Subcutaneous ICDs (S-ICD): No transvenous lead insertion. The pulse generator is placed subcutaneously, and the shock is delivered via a left parasternal subcutaneous lead.
  • Components of CCDs:
    • Pulse Generator: Provides the electrical signals.
    • Electrode: Sends electrical impulses to the heart.
    • Lead Wires: Connect the electrode to the pulse generator, with different tips for attachment to the heart.
      • Active Fixation: Leads with helical tips screw into the myocardium.
      • Passive Fixation: Leads anchor onto heart trabeculae through fibrosis.
  • Chest Radiography for CCD Evaluation:
    • Preferred imaging modality for assessing CCD location, lead integrity, and complications.
    • Two Views Required:
      • Posterior-Anterior (PA) View: Provides a 2D view for lead integrity.
      • Lateral (LAT) View: Essential for evaluating lead tip location and distinguishing between leads in the right or left ventricle.
  • Purpose of Imaging:
    • To ensure correct positioning of leads, diagnose complications, and confirm device functionality for maximal therapeutic benefit.

Chemoport device (Option B) Implantable ports, commonly referred to as chemoports, totally implantable central venous access ports, or Port-A-Caths, are a type of central venous catheter designed for patients needing extended venous access. These devices provide a long-term solution for central venous access, offering a distinct advantage over peripherally inserted central catheters (PICC).
 



Options C and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient came to the hospital complaining of palpitations. During the examination, a diastolic murmur is detected in the left third intercostal space, along with the presence of a pistol shot sound over the femoral arteries. What is the diagnosis here?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Aortic regurgitation

Explanation:

  • The diastolic murmur and the pistol shot sound over the femoral artery along with palpitations signify the diagnosis of aortic regurgitation.

Signs of Aortic Regurgitation

Muller Sign

It is a visible systolic pulsation of the uvula

Rosenbach sign

Systolic pulsations of the Liver

Gerhardt's sign

Systolic pulsations of the Spleen

Quincke's sign

Repeatedly alternating blushing and blanching of capillaries in the nail folds upon palpation (Capillary Pulsations)

Landolphi sign

Alternating systolic constriction and diastolic dilatation of pupils

Traube Sign

It is pistol shot sounds that are heard while auscultating over the femoral artery.

Water-Hammer pulse

Strong pulse that rises quickly and then drops off suddenly.

Duroziez Sign

It is a to-and-fro murmur heard while auscultating the femoral artery.

De-Musset sign

The jarring motion of the head with each heartbeat

 

Blood Pressure
  • Elevated systolic pressure and decreased diastolic pressure result in increased arterial pulse pressure.
  • Atrio-ventricular malformation and Atrio-ventricular ﬁstula also show low diastolic BP due to continuous Korotkoﬀ sounds.
  • Positive Hill’s sign is an abnormal difference in BP in the upper limb and lower limb.

On Palpation
  • Heaving LV impulse is noted, which is displaced laterally and inferiorly
  • Diastolic and Systolic Thrills were noticed at the left lower sternal border and suprasternal notch, respectively.

On Auscultation

  

Heart Sounds
  • A2 is absent
  • In the Bicuspid aortic valve, systolic ejection sound is present
  • Sometimes, A4 is also heard

Murmurs
  • A decrescendo diastolic murmur, best heard when sitting up and leaning forward, is an early diastolic murmur that becomes holo-diastolic as the condition progresses to a severe stage.
  • Musical diastolic murmur is aortic cusp fluttering in the regurgitant flow.
  • Mid-diastolic murmur
  • Austin Flint murmur is a soft, low-pitched, mid- to end-diastolic murmur caused by mitral valve displacement due to AR.
  • Ejection systolic murmur is commonly heard in AR along with AS.

Incorrect Options:

Aortic stenosis (Option B) presents with a midsystolic ejection murmur at the upper sternal border.

Tricuspid regurgitation (Option C) presents with a holosystolic murmur at the lower left sternal border.

Mitral regurgitation (Option D) presents with a systolic murmur at the apex of the heart with radiation to the left axilla.

questions.text: A person with dyspnea has a slight limitation in physical activity and doing ordinary activity causes symptoms but he is asymptomatic at rest. To which class does he belong, based on the New York Heart Association functional classification?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Class II

Explanation:

  • The given scenario belongs to Class II in the New York Heart Association classification for heart failure.

New York Heart Association (NYHA) Classification

Class

Symptoms

I (Option A)
  • No limitation of physical activity.
  • No symptoms with ordinary exertion (e.g. shortness of breath when walking, climbing stairs etc).

II
  • Slight limitation of physical activity.
  • Ordinary activity causes symptoms.

III (Option C)
  • Marked limitation of physical activity.
  • Less than ordinary activity causes symptoms.
  • Asymptomatic at rest.

IV (Option D)
  • Inability to carry out any physical activity without discomfort.
  • Symptoms at rest.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old woman who had a heart attack 2 years ago is currently experiencing a cough and difficulty breathing while walking short distances. Physical examination revealed dullness upon percussion and reduced breath sounds on the right side. A chest x-ray indicated the presence of moderate pleural effusion. Thoracocentesis, guided by ultrasound, was performed and the laboratory results are provided below.

Pleural fluid findings:


	Appearance: turbid
	pH: 7.1
	Protein: 3.2 g/dL
	Lactate dehydrogenase: 80 U/L (normal serum LDH- 50-150 U/L)
	Pleural fluid protein/serum protein ratio: 0.34
	Pleural fluid LDH /serum LDH: 0.3
	Glucose: 54 mg/dL
	WBC count: 4000 cells/µL with >50% lymphocytes
	Adenosine deaminase: 30 U/L
	AFB smear microscopy: Negative
	Gram staining and microscopy: No organisms, no pus cells
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Congestive heart failure

Explanation:

  • The above case with the given clinical findings is suggestive of the diagnosis of congestive heart failure. The effusion is transudative in nature here according to Light’s criteria.

Congestive Heart Failure: Clinical features

  • Cardiac output decreased
  • Stroke volume decreased
  • Heart rate increased
  • Increased sympathetic drive leading to palpitations and diaphoresis
  • Orthopnea
  • Paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea

Clinical Features of Left-Sided vs. Right-Sided Congestive Heart Failure (CHF)

Left-Sided Heart Failure

Right-Sided Heart Failure

Causes:

  • Ischemic heart disease (myocardial infarction).
  • Hypertension
  • Dilated cardiomyopathy.
  • Aortic or mitral valve disease.

Causes:

  • Left-sided heart failure (most common cause).
  • Chronic lung diseases (COPD, pulmonary hypertension).
  • Pulmonary embolism.
  • Right ventricular infarction.

In left-sided heart failure, the left ventricle cannot effectively pump blood to the body, leading to a backup of blood into the lungs.

Clinical features:

This primarily results in pulmonary symptoms.

  • Dyspnea
  • Exertional dyspnea).
  • Orthopnea
  • Paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea

Pulmonary Congestion:

  • Crackles (rales) heard on auscultation due to fluid in the alveoli.
  • Cough
  • Wheezing (cardiac asthma).
  • Fatigue and Weakness
  • Decreased Exercise Tolerance
  • Limited physical activity due to breathlessness and fatigue.
  • S3 Gallop
  • Cool Extremities: Reduced cardiac output may cause poor peripheral circulation, leading to cold, pale skin.

In right-sided heart failure, the right ventricle fails to pump blood effectively into the pulmonary circulation, leading to systemic venous congestion. It is often secondary to left-sided heart failure or conditions affecting the lungs (cor pulmonale).

Clinical Features:

  • Peripheral Edema
  • Jugular Venous Distension (JVD)
  • Hepatomegaly
  • B/L pitting pedal oedema
  • Kussmaul sign: JVP elevation on inspiration
  • Ascites
  • Nocturia
  • Weight Gain
  • Anorexia and Nausea

 

 

Pleural fluid Analysis

Light's Criteria

Differentiates transudative from exudative pleural effusions based on LDH and protein levels in pleural fluid.

  • An exudative pleural effusion meets at least one of the following:
    1. Pleural fluid protein/serum protein > 0.5
    2. Pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH > 0.6
    3. Pleural fluid LDH exceeds two-thirds of the normal upper limit for serum.
  • ~25% of transudates may be misidentified as exudates.
  • If exudative criteria are met but a transudative condition is suspected, measure protein difference; if >31 g/L (3.1 g/dL), likely transudative.

Parapneumonic pleural effusion (Option A) has increased in WBCs, especially neutrophils and the appearance is cloudy.

Malignant pleural effusion (Option B) and tubercular pleural effusion (Option D) are exudative in nature

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a 45-year-old man who experiences chest pain and difficulty breathing that worsens when lying down but improves when sitting upright, and has muffled heart sounds during examination?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Pericardial effusion

Explanation:

  • The above presentation of breathlessness on lying down and it being relieved on sitting, and the X-ray given which shows an enlarged cardiac silhouette is suggestive of a probable diagnosis of pericardial effusion.

Pericardial effusion:

  • Pericardial effusion can lead to cardiac tamponade if rapid.
  • Faint heart sounds and a large cardiac silhouette on X-ray.

Chest X-ray showing waterbottle configuration in Pericardial effusion

  • Electrical alternans is a classic ECG finding in pericardial effusion, particularly when it leads to cardiac tamponade.
  • It manifests as beat-to-beat variations in the amplitude of the QRS complexes, reflecting the heart's movement within the fluid-filled pericardial space.
  • This finding is indicative of significant fluid accumulation and increased intrapericardial pressure, which impedes the heart's ability to fill properly during diastole.

ECG showing Electrical alternans

White arrows showing variations in the amplitude of QRS complexes

Incorrect Options:

Tetralogy of Fallot (Option B) shows a boot-shaped heart on an x-ray.

Transposition of great arteries (Option C) shows an egg-on-string appearance on x-ray.

Pulmonary hypertension (Option D) shows a pruned tree appearance of the pulmonary vasculature.

questions.text: Identify the tachycardia depicted in the given ECG.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Atrial flutter

Explanation:

  • The above ECG is that of atrial flutter since it shows narrow QRS complexes and sawtooth-shaped waves.
     

Atrial Flutter

Features
  • Atrial flutter is characterized by a large re-entry circuit, usually within the right atrium, encircling the tricuspid annulus originating from the cavotricuspid isthmus.
  • The atrial rate is approximately 300 beats per minute.
  • It is typically associated with 2:1, 3:1, or 4:1 AV block, resulting in ventricular rates of 150, 100, or 75 beats per minute.

ECG Features
  • The ECG shows saw-tooth flutter waves, often referred to as "F-waves."
  • With a 2:1 AV block, flutter waves may be buried in QRS complexes and T waves, making them difficult to identify.

Diagnosis
  • Atrial flutter should be suspected in narrow-complex tachycardia at a rate of 150 beats per minute.
  • Carotid sinus pressure or intravenous adenosine may help reveal flutter waves by temporarily increasing the degree of AV block.

Management

1. Rhythm Control:

  • Acute Management:
    • Hemodynamically Unstable Patients: Synchronized cardioversion.
    • Stable Patients:
      • Electrical cardioversion (if no intracardiac thrombus).
      • Pharmacological cardioversion:
        • Antiarrhythmic drugs:
          • Amiodarone
          • Class IA: Procainamide, Quinidine, Disopyramide
          • Class IC: Flecainide, Propafenone
        • Calcium Channel Blockers: Verapamil, Diltiazem
        • Beta-Blockers: Metoprolol, Carvedilol, Esmolol
  • Long-Term Management:
    • Radiofrequency catheter ablation of the cavotricuspid isthmus.

2. Rate Control:

  • First-Line Agents:
    • Calcium Channel Blockers (e.g., Verapamil, Diltiazem)
    • Beta-blockers (e.g., Metoprolol, Carvedilol, Esmolol)
    • Digoxin (use cautiously due to toxicity).
  • Goal: Heart rate < 110 beats per minute.

3. Anticoagulation:

  • Assess stroke risk using the CHADS2-VASC score:
  • Anticoagulation Recommendations:
    • 2 or more points: Strong recommendation for anticoagulation.
    • 1 point: Consider either aspirin or full anticoagulation.


Incorrect Options:

In atrial fibrillation (Option A), the QRS complexes are irregularly irregular, is RR intervals vary.

Ventricular tachycardia (Option C) has broad QRS complexes

Ventricular Fibrillation (Option D) has no identifiable P wave or QRS complexes.

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Ventricular tachycardia

Explanation:

  • The given ECG shows ventricular tachycardia with wide, regular QRS complexes and a rate typically over 100 bpm.

 

Ventricular tachycardia

Pathology:

  • VT is defined as three or more consecutive premature ventricular contractions (PVCs) with a heart rate of over 100 bpm. It can be either monomorphic (all QRS complexes appear similar) or polymorphic (QRS complexes vary in shape).
  • Monomorphic VT is often related to a reentry circuit around a myocardial scar, typically after myocardial infarction, while polymorphic VT, especially Torsades de Pointes, is related to prolonged QT intervals, ischemia, or electrolyte imbalances.

ECG Findings:

  • Monomorphic VT: Wide QRS complexes (>120 ms), regular rhythm, and consistent morphology across leads. The QRS axis may vary depending on the site of origin (e.g., LBBB or RBBB-like morphology).
  • Polymorphic VT: Continuously changing QRS morphology, often associated with prolonged QT intervals (in Torsades de Pointes).

Treatment:

  • Stable Monomorphic VT: Intravenous procainamide or amiodarone can be used.
  • Unstable Monomorphic VT: Immediate synchronized cardioversion is required.
  • Polymorphic VT (Torsades de Pointes): IV magnesium sulfate and correction of underlying electrolyte abnormalities (e.g., hypokalemia) are crucial, along with discontinuation of QT-prolonging drugs.

Incorrect Options:

The above is not a normal ECG (Option A) as it has tachycardia, absent P wave, and vast QRS complexes.

Ventricular fibrillation (Option B) usually has no identifiable QRS complex hence the given ECG does not show ventricular fibrillation.

Misplaced leads (Option D) do not produce the given ECG.

questions.text: HV interval in the below given His bundle electrogram is for conduction:

choices.text: From AV node to bundle of His
From a bundle of His and bundle branches to ventricles

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) From the bundle of His and bundle branches to ventricles

Explanation:

  • The HV interval represents the time it takes for electrical conduction to occur from the His bundle and bundle branches to the ventricles of the heart.

A typical His bundle electrogram includes the following components:

  • A: Atrial deflection
  • H: His deflection
  • QRS: Ventricular depolarization

The intervals measured are as follows:

  • P-H: The interval from the start of the P wave (either from a standard lead ECG or high atrial lead) to the initial rapid deflection of the His bundle spike. (Option B)
  • A-H: The interval from the onset of the atrial deflection on the His bundle electrogram (low RA) to the His bundle deflection. (Option A)
  • H-V: The interval from the first rapid deflection of the His bundle to the onset of ventricular depolarization, measured either from the His bundle electrogram or standard leads.

Option C is incorrect.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with recurrent episodes of chest pain which is seen only on exertion or exercise and lasts 2-5 minutes. He was assessed and was diagnosed with a case of stable angina however his BP was consistently elevated. What is the most appropriate antihypertensive for this patient
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Amlodipine

Explanation:

The most appropriate antihypertensive for a patient with stable angina and consistently elevated blood pressure would be Amlodipine.

  • It is particularly beneficial in patients with stable angina, as it can improve coronary blood flow by reducing vasospasm and decreasing myocardial oxygen demand.
  • Additionally, amlodipine has a favourable effect on blood pressure control, which makes it suitable for patients with both stable angina and hypertension.

Medical management of stable angina

Medication Class

Function/Mechanism

Indications

Nitrates

Sublingual nitroglycerin (0.4 or 0.6 mg)

Long-acting forms (oral, transdermal)
  • Systemic venodilation
  • Reduces LV end-diastolic volume and pressure
  • Releases nitric oxide (NO) to relax vascular smooth muscle
  • Angina relief
  • Preemptive use before activities
  • Improves exercise tolerance

Beta-Blocker (Option A)
  • Reduces heart rate, arterial pressure, and myocardial contractility
  • Improves survival post-MI
  • Angina relief
  • Reduces mortality and reinfarction rates

Calcium Channel Blockers
  • Coronary vasodilators
  • Reduces myocardial oxygen demand and arterial pressure
  • Dihydropyridines (e.g., amlodipine) and non-dihydropyridines (e.g., verapamil)
  • Angina treatment when beta-blockers are ineffective
  • Variant angina

Antiplatelet Drugs
  • Aspirin: inhibits platelet activation
  • Clopidogrel 75mg: blocks platelet aggregation
  • Reduces coronary events in high-risk populations
  • Stent placement


Thiazide (Option B) diuretics are a class of medications used to treat hypertension. They help reduce blood pressure by promoting diuresis and decreasing fluid volume. However, they may not be the most appropriate choice in this case since the patient already has stable angina, and thiazides are not specifically indicated for the treatment of angina.

Enalapril (Option C) is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor that is commonly used in the management of hypertension and are effective antihypertensive agent, they may not be the initial choice in this case, considering the patient's primary symptom of stable angina

questions.text: A postoperative cardiac surgery patient developed sudden hypotension, raised central venous pressure, and pulsus paradoxus at the 4th postoperative hour. The most probable diagnosis is.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Cardiac tamponade

Explanation:

  • Based on the symptoms described in the postoperative cardiac surgical patient, the most probable diagnosis is cardiac tamponade which is a medical emergency characterized by the accumulation of fluid or blood in the pericardial sac, which leads to compression of the heart and impaired cardiac function.

Cardiac Tamponade

Definition

A condition where the cardiac chambers are compressed by a tense pericardial effusion, limiting cardiac inflow. Fluid accumulation of as little as 200 ml to upwards of 2 L may lead to cardiac tamponade development.

Clinical Features

Beck's triad

  • Jugular Venous Distension: Due to increased central venous pressure. Prominent x descent and an absent y descent.
  • Hypotension: Resulting from impaired cardiac output.
  • Muffled Heart Sounds: Caused by fluid accumulation in the pericardial space, dampening heart sounds.

Other features

Pulsus paradoxus: A drop in systolic BP during inspiration, greater than 10 mm Hg.

Causes of Pulsus paradoxus:

  • Lung Conditions: Acute asthma, COPD, tension pneumothorax, pleural effusion, pulmonary embolism.
  • Heart Conditions: Cardiac tamponade, constrictive pericarditis.

Low-Pressure Cardiac Tamponade

Definition

This occurs when lower pericardial pressure leads to tamponade, often in cases of intravascular fluid depletion (e.g., hypovolemia).

Features

Jugular Venous Distension: Often absent

Pulsus Paradoxus: Rare

Requires a high degree of suspicion due to the absence of typical signs like jugular venous distension and pulsus paradoxus.

 

Incorrect Options:
